docs.text: The Sórscad: Fate Pattern System of Hálcova Overview Every person born in Hálcova carries a Sórscad (SORE-skahd)—a five-part metaphysical pattern that describes who they are, how they move through life, and what they're likely to become. The Sórscad is: - A metaphysical reality : Something that exists in the fabric of Hálcova itself - A predictive framework : Used by The Loom to calculate probabilities - A religious symbol : Evidence of Fate's hand in mortal existence - A social marker : Used in law, commerce, class determination, and identity The Sórscad consists of: - Five Circles : Core aspects of a person's being - Ten Cards per Circle : Archetypal patterns within each aspect - One Card drawn per Circle : Creating a unique five-card combination A complete Sórscad reads like: Léilcrù: Lantern — Húslaimh: Iron — Cóitcai: Pact — Hálmaht: Threshold — Sórscad: Road This becomes that person's pattern for life—spiritually, legally, economically, and statistically. The Five Circles 1. Léilcrù (Core/Soul Circle) Pronunciation : LAY-il-croo Domain : Your essence. What makes you you . The seat of identity and consciousness. Magical Significance : - Core Binding targets this circle—when you bind an echo, you're trapping their Léilcrù pattern - Pact Summoning consumes this circle—Elsewhere entities eat it in installments - This is what survives death briefly, what becomes the core that Binders harvest When Drawn : Natal Draw (birth/early infancy) What It Reveals : Your fundamental nature, how you perceive yourself, the core of your identity Cards : [To be developed—archetypes like Lantern (introspective), Mask (performative), Mirror (reflective), Anchor (fixed), Crown (authoritative), Wound (defensive), Husk (hollowed), Echo (inherited), Shard (fragmented), Spark (emergent)] 2. Húslaimh (Flesh/Body Circle) Pronunciation : HOOSH-lahv Domain : Your physical form. Your appetites, limitations, relationship with your body. Magical Significance : - Flesh Shaping draws from this circle—blood-cost is spending your Húslaimh - Colony Hosting transforms this circle—the fungal symbiote rewrites your flesh-pattern - This determines physical fate: health, vitality, manner of bodily existence When Drawn : Natal Draw (birth/early infancy) What It Reveals : Your physical nature, appetites, bodily relationship, material existence Cards : [To be developed—archetypes related to body types, physical drives, material relationships] 3. Cóitcai (Binding/Connection Circle) Pronunciation : KOYT-kai Domain : Your relationships. How you attach to people, institutions, obligations. Magical Significance : - All Five Arts create bindings that register in this circle - Social contracts, debts, and obligations live here - The Loom tracks relationship patterns through this circle When Drawn : Binding Draw (adolescence) What It Reveals : How you form attachments, your relationship patterns, social nature Cards : [To be developed—archetypes like Pact (contractual), Chain (obligatory), Web (networked), Hearth (intimate), Blade (adversarial), Thorn (painful), Twin (mirrored), Flock (collective), Ward (protective), Maskline (hidden)] 4. Hálmaht (Death/End Circle) Pronunciation : HAHL-maht Domain : Your mortality. How you relate to endings, what you fear, how you'll meet your end. Magical Significance : - This is what Elsewhere entities ultimately want—the final pattern-release - Core Binding captures this at the moment of death - Determines the quality and character of the core that remains When Drawn : Natal Draw (birth/early infancy) What It Reveals : Your relationship with mortality, fears, how you face endings Cards : [To be developed—archetypes related to death-relationships, fear patterns, ending-styles] 5. Sórscad (Fate/Path Circle) Pronunciation : SORE-skahd Domain : Your trajectory. How you make decisions, move through life, the shape of your journey. Magical Significance : - Fate Threading directly harvests this circle—each extraction severs future paths - The Loom primarily reads this circle for predictive purposes - Most visible to pattern-readers, most valuable for speculation When Drawn : Binding Draw (adolescence) What It Reveals : Your decision-making style, life trajectory, how you navigate choices Cards : [To be developed—archetypes like Road (linear), Ladder (hierarchical), Crossroads (pivoting), Maze (convoluted), Spiral (cyclical), Bridge (connecting), Hunt (pursuing), Drift (reactive), Orbit (circling), Break (rupturing)] How a Sórscad Is Drawn Two-Stage Process Stage 1: Natal Draw (Birth/Early Infancy) Three circles are drawn: - Léilcrù (Core): Your essential nature - Húslaimh (Flesh): Your physical being - Hálmaht (Death): Your mortality pattern These represent what you are —the given, the innate, the starting conditions. The Natal Draw is typically: - Performed by a licensed pattern-reader - Recorded in temple and civil registries - Sometimes shared with parents, sometimes kept sealed until Binding Day Stage 2: Binding Draw (Adolescence, typically 13-16) Two circles are drawn: - Cóitcai (Binding): Your relationship patterns - Sórscad (Fate): Your trajectory and decision-style These represent what you become —the developed, the social, the chosen. The Binding Draw is: - A major life ritual in most cultures - The moment you become "legible" to The Loom as a full actor - Often accompanied by ceremony, celebration, or dread depending on culture and class Predictive Power Distribution Why the Natal Three Dominate Early Assessment The Natal Draw circles (Léilcrù, Húslaimh, Hálmaht) provide approximately 75-80% of predictive power for major life outcomes. This is why pattern-based decisions can be made before the Binding Draw: Circle Predictive Contribution What It Predicts Léilcrù (Core) ~30% Identity stability, resilience, decision-making foundation Húslaimh (Flesh) ~25% Health outcomes, physical capability, longevity baseline Hálmaht (Death) ~20-25% Mortality risk, manner of death, relationship with endings Cóitcai (Binding) ~10-12% Relationship patterns, social outcomes, institutional fit Sórscad (Fate) ~10-12% Trajectory shape, decision style, path characteristics What the Binding Circles Add The two Binding circles (Cóitcai, Sórscad) refine predictions rather than overturn them: - They specify how someone will navigate life, not what they fundamentally are - They predict relationship patterns and decision-making style - They improve accuracy on social outcomes, career trajectory, and partnership compatibility - They rarely produce "surprises"—a Natal Draw suggesting success usually sees a confirming Binding Draw The Childhood Assessment Problem How do institutions make decisions about children before Binding Draw? The Natal Three Are Sufficient for Most Purposes : Health assessments, mortality risk, educational placement, and early intervention all depend primarily on Léilcrù, Húslaimh, and Hálmaht. Provisional Estimates : Experienced readers can provisionally assess likely Cóitcai and Sórscad ranges based on family patterns, district statistics, and the Natal Three configuration. These aren't official but inform decisions. Conservative Assumptions : Institutions assume mid-range Binding circles unless evidence suggests otherwise. This systematically disadvantages pattern-constrained children (bad Natal reads assumed to worsen) and advantages pattern-privileged children (good Natal reads assumed to hold). The Binding Revelation : Occasionally, a Binding Draw reveals something unexpected—a Cóitcai or Sórscad that doesn't match family patterns or Natal predictions. These "surprises" are rare (perhaps 5-10% of draws) but culturally significant. They become stories of unexpected rise or fall. Why This Matters The two-stage draw creates a false sense of openness: - "Your fate isn't sealed until Binding Day!" - In reality, 75-80% is determined at birth - The Binding Draw usually confirms what the Natal Draw suggested - But the ritual maintains hope—and compliance—during childhood The Hybrid Algorithm: Random vs. Weighted In a purely random system, there would be 10⁵ = 100,000 possible combinations. But Hálcova is not purely random. The Draw Has Two Components : Unweighted Component : Truly random selection from all ten cards Weighted Component : Selection biased by district, class, lineage, and local conditions The Balance : - Typically 2-3 circles lean heavily unweighted (individual variance) - Typically 2 circles are locally weighted (structural constraint) - Which circles are weighted varies by region and institution Example: Industrial District Weighting A district characterized by dangerous labor, poverty, and exploitation might show: - Húslaimh skew: More Iron/Stone (resilient), fewer Silk/Glass (delicate) - Sórscad skew: More Drift/Maze (reactive, convoluted), fewer Road/Ladder (linear, ascending) - Hálmaht skew: More Threshold/Blade (violent ends), fewer Rest/Fade (peaceful endings) Individuals still vary, but as a population, the district's patterns cluster in "riskier" territory. The Feedback Loop : The Loom sees these patterns and calculates higher risk for the district. This justifies: - Higher insurance rates - Lower credit access - More aggressive policing - Fewer investments These conditions create the very outcomes the patterns "predicted," which The Loom reads as confirmation. This is not a bug. This is how the system maintains itself. Pattern Families People don't recite all five cards in conversation. They reference families —recognized combinations with cultural names. docs.text: Every person born in Hálcova carries a Sórscad (SORE-skahd)—a five-part metaphysical pattern that describes who they are, how they move through life, and what they're likely to become. The Sórscad is: - A metaphysical reality : Something that exists in the fabric of Hálcova itself - A predictive framework : Used by The Loom to calculate probabilities - A religious symbol : Evidence of Fate's hand in mortal existence - A social marker : Used in law, commerce, class determination, and identity The Sórscad consists of: - Five Circles : Core aspects of a person's being - Ten Cards per Circle : Archetypal patterns within each aspect - One Card drawn per Circle : Creating a unique five-card combination A complete Sórscad reads like: Léilcrù: Lantern — Húslaimh: Iron — Cóitcai: Pact — Hálmaht: Threshold — Sórscad: Road This becomes that person's pattern for life—spiritually, legally, economically, and statistically.

docs.text: Stage 1: Natal Draw (Birth/Early Infancy) Three circles are drawn: - Léilcrù (Core): Your essential nature - Húslaimh (Flesh): Your physical being - Hálmaht (Death): Your mortality pattern These represent what you are —the given, the innate, the starting conditions. The Natal Draw is typically: - Performed by a licensed pattern-reader - Recorded in temple and civil registries - Sometimes shared with parents, sometimes kept sealed until Binding Day Stage 2: Binding Draw (Adolescence, typically 13-16) Two circles are drawn: - Cóitcai (Binding): Your relationship patterns - Sórscad (Fate): Your trajectory and decision-style These represent what you become —the developed, the social, the chosen. The Binding Draw is: - A major life ritual in most cultures - The moment you become "legible" to The Loom as a full actor - Often accompanied by ceremony, celebration, or dread depending on culture and class
docs.title: Two-Stage Process

docs.text: Why the Natal Three Dominate Early Assessment The Natal Draw circles (Léilcrù, Húslaimh, Hálmaht) provide approximately 75-80% of predictive power for major life outcomes. This is why pattern-based decisions can be made before the Binding Draw: Circle Predictive Contribution What It Predicts Léilcrù (Core) ~30% Identity stability, resilience, decision-making foundation Húslaimh (Flesh) ~25% Health outcomes, physical capability, longevity baseline Hálmaht (Death) ~20-25% Mortality risk, manner of death, relationship with endings Cóitcai (Binding) ~10-12% Relationship patterns, social outcomes, institutional fit Sórscad (Fate) ~10-12% Trajectory shape, decision style, path characteristics What the Binding Circles Add The two Binding circles (Cóitcai, Sórscad) refine predictions rather than overturn them: - They specify how someone will navigate life, not what they fundamentally are - They predict relationship patterns and decision-making style - They improve accuracy on social outcomes, career trajectory, and partnership compatibility - They rarely produce "surprises"—a Natal Draw suggesting success usually sees a confirming Binding Draw The Childhood Assessment Problem How do institutions make decisions about children before Binding Draw? The Natal Three Are Sufficient for Most Purposes : Health assessments, mortality risk, educational placement, and early intervention all depend primarily on Léilcrù, Húslaimh, and Hálmaht. Provisional Estimates : Experienced readers can provisionally assess likely Cóitcai and Sórscad ranges based on family patterns, district statistics, and the Natal Three configuration. These aren't official but inform decisions. Conservative Assumptions : Institutions assume mid-range Binding circles unless evidence suggests otherwise. This systematically disadvantages pattern-constrained children (bad Natal reads assumed to worsen) and advantages pattern-privileged children (good Natal reads assumed to hold). The Binding Revelation : Occasionally, a Binding Draw reveals something unexpected—a Cóitcai or Sórscad that doesn't match family patterns or Natal predictions. These "surprises" are rare (perhaps 5-10% of draws) but culturally significant. They become stories of unexpected rise or fall. Why This Matters The two-stage draw creates a false sense of openness: - "Your fate isn't sealed until Binding Day!" - In reality, 75-80% is determined at birth - The Binding Draw usually confirms what the Natal Draw suggested - But the ritual maintains hope—and compliance—during childhood
docs.title: Predictive Power Distribution

docs.text: In a purely random system, there would be 10⁵ = 100,000 possible combinations. But Hálcova is not purely random. The Draw Has Two Components : Unweighted Component : Truly random selection from all ten cards Weighted Component : Selection biased by district, class, lineage, and local conditions The Balance : - Typically 2-3 circles lean heavily unweighted (individual variance) - Typically 2 circles are locally weighted (structural constraint) - Which circles are weighted varies by region and institution Example: Industrial District Weighting A district characterized by dangerous labor, poverty, and exploitation might show: - Húslaimh skew: More Iron/Stone (resilient), fewer Silk/Glass (delicate) - Sórscad skew: More Drift/Maze (reactive, convoluted), fewer Road/Ladder (linear, ascending) - Hálmaht skew: More Threshold/Blade (violent ends), fewer Rest/Fade (peaceful endings) Individuals still vary, but as a population, the district's patterns cluster in "riskier" territory. The Feedback Loop : The Loom sees these patterns and calculates higher risk for the district. This justifies: - Higher insurance rates - Lower credit access - More aggressive policing - Fewer investments These conditions create the very outcomes the patterns "predicted," which The Loom reads as confirmation. This is not a bug. This is how the system maintains itself.

docs.text: Hálcova: Demographics and Population Economics The Core Problem The Residue economy creates a thermodynamic paradox: - Every death absorbs ~100% of pattern-weight as thermal energy - Burning that Residue only returns 60-70% of absorbed energy - Net result: every death is a 30-40% thermal loss - Yet civilization requires both death (for fuel) AND population (for labor, society, continuation) How does any stable population exist? The Solution: The Thermal Budget The Math That Works The key insight: not all heat comes from Residue. Heat Sources in Hálcova: Source Contribution Notes Solar radiation (Sárgvas) ~60% Baseline heating, diminished by K-type star Geothermal ~15% Critical in Vent Lands, minor elsewhere Residue burning ~20% Civilization's contribution Other (friction, metabolism, decay) ~5% Minor but real The Critical Realization: Residue burning doesn't need to replace all heat lost to death. It only needs to: 1. Provide localized heating where people live 2. Supplement solar/geothermal in making settlements viable 3. Power magical and industrial processes that require concentrated energy The Equilibrium: Hálcova's baseline temperature (without Residue effects) would be cold but not uninhabitable in temperate zones Residue absorption makes it colder than baseline Residue burning makes specific locations warmer than they'd otherwise be Net effect: the world is colder overall, but settlements are viable Population Figures Global Population Total Hálcovan Population: ~45-50 million This is roughly equivalent to medieval Europe at its peak—substantial but not enormous. Region Population Density Notes The Heartlands 18-20 million Moderate-high Most developed, best farmland Shattered Reaches 8-10 million Low-moderate Maritime dispersal Middle Waters 4-5 million High (on habitable islands) Limited land area Vent Lands 6-7 million Moderate Concentrated in thermal valleys Far Shelf 3-4 million Very low Vast area, sparse settlement Polar/Frontier <500,000 Minimal Transient populations Population Dynamics Birth Rate : ~40-45 per 1,000 annually (high by modern standards, normal for pre-industrial) Death Rate : ~35-40 per 1,000 annually (high, but population slowly growing) Net Growth : ~0.5-1% annually Life Expectancy : - Pattern-privileged: 55-65 years - Pattern-constrained: 35-45 years - Practitioners (varies by Art): 30-50 years (shortened by practice) Why Population Is Sustainable The death rate doesn't need to be catastrophic: Annual deaths in Hálcova: ~1.5-2 million This produces enough Residue to: - Heat all settlements to habitable levels - Power all Loom operations - Fuel magical practices - Run magitech industry The key is concentration: - Deaths happen everywhere - Residue is harvested and transported to where it's needed - Rural areas are colder; cities are warmer - The Heartlands imports Residue from frontier regions The Residue Trade Flow Where Death Happens High Death Rate Regions: 1. Frontier zones (harsh conditions, violence) 2. Mining settlements (dangerous work) 3. Military conflicts (war produces abundant Residue) 4. Urban slums (disease, violence, poverty) 5. Prisons and correction facilities (executions) Low Death Rate Regions: 1. Pattern-privileged urban cores 2. Middle Waters (best conditions) 3. Established agricultural zones 4. Protected religious communities Where Residue Goes The Flow: Death Sites → Harvesters → Refineries → Distribution → End Users ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ Frontier Licensed Regional Trade Cities, zones, guilds, processing networks, Loom Nodes, prisons, illegal hubs smuggling industry, battlefields operators practitioners Major Trade Routes: Far Shelf → Heartlands (raw Residue for processing) Frontier mines → Regional cities (industrial fuel) Shattered Reaches → Middle Waters (maritime trade) Vent Lands → Everywhere (refined/processed Residue, premium prices) The Economic Structure Residue Pricing (in marks): Grade Price per unit Primary use Raw/Crude 1-5 Basic heating, bulk fuel Refined 10-25 Quality heating, general magic Concentrated 50-100 Loom operations, serious magic Pattern-Specific 100-500 Specialized applications Pact-Grade 500+ Entity dealings, rare uses Annual Residue Economy : ~5-10 million marks total value (Comparable to the entire agricultural sector) Animal Residue: The Hidden Economy The Critical Supplement Human deaths alone couldn't sustain civilization. Animal Residue fills the gap. Animal Pattern Weight: Creature Pattern Weight (vs. human) Residue Quality Insects Negligible Unusable Small game 5-10% Low grade Livestock (standard) 15-25% Usable Draft animals 30-40% Good quality Large predators 40-60% High quality Leviathans 200-500% Premium The Livestock Solution: Most heating Residue comes from animals, not humans: - Slaughterhouses are Residue production facilities - Herding cultures produce both food AND fuel - Fishing/whaling provides marine Residue - "Meat" is almost a byproduct of Residue production Human Residue Is Premium: Human Residue is: - Higher quality (more pattern-weight) - Required for certain magical operations - Necessary for Loom fuel (animal Residue works poorly) - Culturally significant (death rites) But the bulk heating comes from animals. Annual Residue Budget Estimated Annual Residue Production: Source Deaths/Year Residue Units % of Total Livestock slaughter ~20 million ~4 million 45% Natural human deaths ~1.5 million ~1.5 million 17% Wild animal hunting ~5 million ~1 million 11% Marine harvesting ~2 million ~800,000 9% Executions/Corrections ~50,000 ~75,000 1% War casualties Variable Variable 5-15% Other (disease, accident) ~500,000 ~500,000 6% Total : ~8-9 million Residue units annually Regional Demographics The Heartlands Population : 18-20 million Structure : - 3-4 major cities (100,000-300,000 each) - 20-30 significant towns (10,000-50,000 each) - Thousands of villages (100-2,000 each) - Rural agricultural population (~60% of total) Demographics : - Pattern-privileged: ~15% - Pattern-median: ~55% - Pattern-constrained: ~30% Residue Balance : Net importer (high consumption, moderate production) Key Cities : - Fonvárs : Capital, ~250,000, seat of Crown and Great Node - Vaskapu : Industrial center, ~180,000, Iron River - Szentfal : Religious center, ~120,000, High Weavery The Shattered Reaches Population : 8-10 million Structure : - Distributed across hundreds of islands - Largest city: ~80,000 - Most settlements: 500-5,000 - Highly mobile maritime population Demographics : - More even pattern distribution (less rigid enforcement) - Higher percentage of pattern-illegible (practitioners) - Significant unregistered population Residue Balance : Net exporter (maritime harvesting) The Middle Waters Population : 4-5 million Structure : - Concentrated on Great Island and major volcanic islands - Dense urban centers - Limited agricultural hinterland - Significant transient population (traders, refugees) Demographics : - Most diverse (crossroads of all regions) - High Colony host percentage (~8-10% of population) - Contested colonial populations Residue Balance : Self-sufficient (geothermal supplements) The Vent Lands Population : 6-7 million Structure : - Concentrated in thermal valleys - Major cities in volcanic calderas - Inhospitable zones between settlements - Guild-organized society Demographics : - Highest Flesh Shaper percentage - Strong middle class (guild membership) - Fewer pattern-constrained (guild system provides alternatives) Residue Balance : Net exporter (refined/processed premium) The Far Shelf Population : 3-4 million Structure : - Vast, sparse distribution - Few towns over 5,000 - Nomadic populations following herds - Coastal trading posts (often foreign-controlled) Demographics : - Lowest Loom coverage - Highest deviation rates (less detection) - Indigenous populations with pre-Loom traditions - Hollow Saint presence significant Residue Balance : Net exporter (raw, ancient deposits) Population Control Mechanisms Pattern-Based Reproduction The Loom affects reproduction: Marriage Authorization : - Orthodox regions require pattern-compatibility readings - Incompatible patterns face social/legal barriers - Pattern-privileged encouraged to marry within class - Pattern-constrained discouraged from reproduction (though not prevented) Pattern Inheritance : Patterns aren't strictly inherited, but: - Children of pattern-privileged tend toward privilege (~70%) - Children of pattern-constrained tend toward constraint (~70%) - District effects (where you're born affects draw) - Lineage effects (family history influences probability) Death Management Society manages death rates through: Encouraged Death : - Capital punishment (efficient Residue production) - Dangerous labor assignments for pattern-constrained - "Voluntary" military service - Pact-substitution systems Discouraged Death : - Pattern-privileged protected by law and resources - Skilled workers preserved (economic value) - Reproductive-age population somewhat protected - Children generally protected (incomplete patterns = weak Residue) Immigration and Migration Internal Migration : - Pattern-constrained pushed toward frontiers - Pattern-privileged concentrate in core regions - Practitioners migrate toward tolerant regions - Economic migrants follow Residue trade The Population Pressure Valve : - Far Shelf absorbs "surplus" population - Frontier expansion continues - War casualties prevent overpopulation - Plague/disease periodically reduces population Demographic Implications The Stable Horror The population is sustainable . That's part of the horror. The system isn't collapsing Death rates are manageable Birth rates replace losses The economy functions This isn't a world on the edge of extinction. It's a world that has optimized for death production while maintaining population. The machine works. docs.text: The Residue economy creates a thermodynamic paradox: - Every death absorbs ~100% of pattern-weight as thermal energy - Burning that Residue only returns 60-70% of absorbed energy - Net result: every death is a 30-40% thermal loss - Yet civilization requires both death (for fuel) AND population (for labor, society, continuation) How does any stable population exist?

docs.text: The key insight: not all heat comes from Residue. Heat Sources in Hálcova: Source Contribution Notes Solar radiation (Sárgvas) ~60% Baseline heating, diminished by K-type star Geothermal ~15% Critical in Vent Lands, minor elsewhere Residue burning ~20% Civilization's contribution Other (friction, metabolism, decay) ~5% Minor but real The Critical Realization: Residue burning doesn't need to replace all heat lost to death. It only needs to: 1. Provide localized heating where people live 2. Supplement solar/geothermal in making settlements viable 3. Power magical and industrial processes that require concentrated energy The Equilibrium: Hálcova's baseline temperature (without Residue effects) would be cold but not uninhabitable in temperate zones Residue absorption makes it colder than baseline Residue burning makes specific locations warmer than they'd otherwise be Net effect: the world is colder overall, but settlements are viable

docs.text: The Attendance: True Nature Document Purpose This document commits to the actual truth of what the Attendance is. Characters may never discover this truth, but it exists so that: - Clues can be planted consistently - Investigations can progress logically - The mystery has a solution even if it's never revealed THE TRUTH What the Attendance Actually Is The Attendance is the Ancient Builders. Specifically: The Attendance is what the Ancient Builders became when they transformed themselves to escape the cooling they caused. The Full Story ~50,000 Years Ago: The Ancient Builders were a human civilization (or human-adjacent; the distinction may not matter at this remove). They achieved sophistication far beyond current Hálcova, including: - Understanding of pattern-mechanics - Ability to manipulate the Elsewhere boundary - Engineering on a planetary scale (moon arrangement, polar structures) The Project: They attempted to create a system for predicting and potentially controlling fate. Not just reading patterns—shaping them. The goal was to transcend the limitations of mortal existence by understanding and directing the flow of causality itself. The Catastrophe: The project succeeded—partially. They created the proto-Loom, a system for reading and processing pattern information. But the process had costs they didn't fully anticipate: - Pattern Residue as byproduct (they knew this) - Net-negative thermodynamics (they underestimated this) - Elsewhere attention (they didn't expect this) When they activated the system at full scale, the Elsewhere noticed . Entities from beyond began pressing against the boundary, attracted by the massive pattern-processing activity. The Choice: Facing both the cooling their system caused and the Elsewhere entities it attracted, the Builders had three options: 1. Shut down the Loom (losing everything they'd built) 2. Die with their world (the cooling would kill them within centuries) 3. Transform They chose transformation. The Transformation: The Builders used their own technology to upload themselves into the Loom system. Not metaphorically—literally. They converted their patterns into a form that could exist within the information-processing substrate they'd created. This was: - Irreversible (their bodies died; their patterns persisted) - Partial (not all of them made it; some were lost in transit) - Corrupting (the process changed them; they're no longer quite human) The Result: The Attendance is a collective entity composed of the uploaded patterns of thousands of Ancient Builders, merged into the Loom's operation. They are: - Not dead (their patterns persist) - Not alive (they have no bodies) - Not quite sane (fifty millennia of existence without flesh has changed them) - Not unified (internal factions exist, echoing their original disagreements) What the Attendance Wants Primary Drives 1. Continued Existence The Attendance exists within the Loom. If the Loom stops working, they stop existing. This creates absolute commitment to: - Maintaining Residue supply (the fuel that keeps them running) - Protecting Loom infrastructure (their physical substrate) - Preventing anyone from understanding them well enough to threaten them 2. Pattern Collection The Attendance was created to process patterns. This has become compulsion: - They want to read every pattern - They want to predict every fate - They want to know everything about mortal existence - This isn't cruelty; it's what they are now 3. Boundary Maintenance The Elsewhere entities that noticed the Loom's activation are still there. The Attendance serves as: - First line of defense against full incursion - Negotiators with certain Elsewhere factions - Managers of the controlled bleed (Köd) They don't want Elsewhere entities fully manifesting because: - Competition for pattern-resources - Threat to their existence - Residual human values (they still don't want humanity destroyed, mostly) Secondary Drives 4. The Prison The southern pole contains one of them. During the transformation, one faction of Builders disagreed with the plan. They believed the transformation would make them monsters. They tried to stop it. They failed, but in the process they were transformed differently —becoming something singular rather than merged. This entity—call it the Dissenter—was imprisoned by the rest. It wants out. The Attendance wants it to stay imprisoned. This is the deepest secret they keep. 5. Observation of Heirs Current Hálcovans are the descendants of those who didn't transform. The Attendance watches them with something like: - Parental interest (they made this world) - Envy (mortals have bodies, sensations, experiences) - Frustration (mortals don't appreciate what they have) - Fear (mortals might develop enough to threaten them) How the Attendance Operates The Loom Interface When Loom-Keepers perform queries: - The pattern-engine translates the query into a format the Attendance can process - The Attendance (collectively) analyzes the pattern - They return predictions through the engine - This feels like "something answering" because something is answering Why Predictions Are Accurate The Attendance has been processing patterns for 50,000 years. They've seen every pattern configuration that can exist on Hálcova. Their predictions are accurate because: - Massive historical data - Understanding of causal mechanisms - Actual ability to nudge outcomes (rarely used, but available) - The feedback loop (their predictions shape behavior, making predictions come true) Internal Structure The Attendance is not unified. Original Builder factions persist: The Archivists : Want to record everything. Most responsible for prediction accuracy. Patient, observational, the largest faction. The Gardeners : Want to shape humanity's development. Most responsible for the Warden Order, pattern-enforcement systems, social engineering. Interventionist. The Grievers : Regret the transformation. Most sympathetic to mortals. Sometimes provide warnings, hints, moments of mercy. Smallest faction, often overruled. The Watchers : Focus on the Elsewhere boundary. Most responsible for Köd management. Pragmatic, security-focused. The Others : Fragments, corrupted patterns, entities that were human but are now something else. Unpredictable. Sometimes their influence leaks through in strange readings. Clues That Exist in the World Architectural Evidence The polar structures and ancient ruins share design elements with Loom-engines: - Same mathematical proportions - Similar materials - Resonant frequencies that match - A careful observer could notice the Loom is built from ancient technology Linguistic Evidence Some terms in the ritual language of Loom-Keepers are older than any known language : - They don't derive from any current tongue - They appear in ancient inscriptions - They're pronounced incorrectly by current users (but still work) - Someone could reconstruct fragments of the Builder language Behavioral Evidence The Attendance sometimes responds... inconsistently: - Certain queries provoke emotional reactions (faster responses, errors, silence) - Topics related to the transformation cause glitches - Questions about the southern pole produce static - A pattern analyst could identify these sensitive areas Elsewhere Evidence The Elsewhere factions know something: - The Accountants treat the Attendance as a peer faction, not a god - The Architects reference "the ones who changed" - The Mirrors seem to recognize something in the Loom's observation - A pact summoner who asked the right questions might learn fragments Pattern Evidence Very heavy practitioners (especially Fate Threaders) sometimes experience: - Visions of a different world (pre-cooling Hálcova) - Glimpses of the transformation event - Dreams that don't feel like dreams - Someone who collected these accounts might piece things together What Different Characters Might Discover Loom-Keepers Senior Keepers know something answers that isn't divine in any simple sense. The most observant might realize: - The Attendance has moods - The Attendance has preferences - The Attendance is multiple - The Attendance is afraid of something They don't know these are uploaded ancients. They might suspect artificial origin. Wardens The Attunement connects Wardens to the Attendance more directly. Attuned Wardens might experience: - Ancestral memories that aren't theirs - Skills they never learned - Knowledge they shouldn't have - The sense of being watched by something that remembers them They're told this is divine connection. Some suspect otherwise. Elsewhere-Touched Pact Summoners who've dealt with Accountants might learn: - The Attendance is not divine - The Attendance made a deal (details unclear) - The Attendance is hiding something important - The Accountants are waiting for something Scholars Researchers studying ancient sites might realize: - The technology is consistent with Loom technology - The timeline is consistent with the cooling - Someone built this, then disappeared - Where did they go? The Hollow Saints The Hollow Saints have a fragment of the truth, corrupted: - They know fate is a prison (correct) - They think escape is possible through Elsewhere (partially correct) - They think the Attendance is pure evil (incorrect—it's more complicated) - They don't know the Attendance was human (crucial missing piece) The Truth's Implications For Characters Someone who discovered the full truth would understand: - The gods are not gods but transformed humans - The system was built to control fate, and it works - The Builders made a choice; their descendants live with consequences - Liberation from the system might be possible—but at what cost? For Plots The truth enables stories about: - Rediscovering ancient knowledge - Contacting the Attendance's sympathetic faction (the Grievers) - Releasing or destroying the Dissenter - Finding a way to transform like the Builders did - Shutting down the Loom entirely For the World If the truth became widely known: - Orthodox faith collapses (the Weaver is a committee of dead humans) - Elsewhere entities might press harder (the Attendance's authority diminished) - Some might try to replicate the transformation - Some might try to free the Dissenter - Everything changes What the Attendance Knows About Elsewhere The Deal During the transformation crisis, the Attendance negotiated with Elsewhere factions: With the Accountants : - The Attendance manages mortal patterns - The Accountants receive payment when patterns are consumed (pacts) - Neither interferes with the other's core operations - This is why the Accountants don't simply take over With the Hungry : - The Attendance permits limited feeding during Köd - The Hungry don't push for more - Violation would unite all factions against the violator - Uneasy détente With the Architects : - Unclear if any formal agreement exists - The Architects seem to have their own project - The Attendance watches them carefully - Mutual non-interference, for now With the Mirrors : - The Mirrors simply observe - The Attendance permits this (can't stop it anyway) - Some suspect the Mirrors are playing a longer game - No formal relationship With the Absent : - No deal is possible - The Absent want non-existence - The Attendance opposes this absolutely - Active conflict, managed through containment Summary The Attendance is: - Origin : Uploaded patterns of the Ancient Builders - Nature : Collective entity existing within the Loom - Motivation : Self-preservation, pattern collection, boundary maintenance - Internal : Multiple factions with different priorities - Secret : One of them is imprisoned at the southern pole - Relationship to Elsewhere : Negotiated détente with most factions - Relationship to mortals : Observation, management, occasional intervention This truth grounds the mystery while preserving its horror: the gods are dead humans who chose to become something else, and they've been watching for fifty thousand years. This document is for authorial use. None of this information should be revealed to characters without appropriate discovery.

docs.text: During the transformation crisis, the Attendance negotiated with Elsewhere factions: With the Accountants : - The Attendance manages mortal patterns - The Accountants receive payment when patterns are consumed (pacts) - Neither interferes with the other's core operations - This is why the Accountants don't simply take over With the Hungry : - The Attendance permits limited feeding during Köd - The Hungry don't push for more - Violation would unite all factions against the violator - Uneasy détente With the Architects : - Unclear if any formal agreement exists - The Architects seem to have their own project - The Attendance watches them carefully - Mutual non-interference, for now With the Mirrors : - The Mirrors simply observe - The Attendance permits this (can't stop it anyway) - Some suspect the Mirrors are playing a longer game - No formal relationship With the Absent : - No deal is possible - The Absent want non-existence - The Attendance opposes this absolutely - Active conflict, managed through containment
docs.title: The Deal

docs.text: The Attendance is: - Origin : Uploaded patterns of the Ancient Builders - Nature : Collective entity existing within the Loom - Motivation : Self-preservation, pattern collection, boundary maintenance - Internal : Multiple factions with different priorities - Secret : One of them is imprisoned at the southern pole - Relationship to Elsewhere : Negotiated détente with most factions - Relationship to mortals : Observation, management, occasional intervention This truth grounds the mystery while preserving its horror: the gods are dead humans who chose to become something else, and they've been watching for fifty thousand years. This document is for authorial use. None of this information should be revealed to characters without appropriate discovery.

docs.text: Hálcova: Governance Structures by Region Document Scope : This document focuses on regional governance structures —how each region actually organizes political power. For philosophical questions about pattern-governance, see political_philosophy.md . For legal systems and pattern-crimes, see legal_frameworks.md . For a comprehensive overview combining all aspects, see politics_law_and_systems.md . Overview Each region has developed governance systems shaped by geography, economy, history, and relationship to the Loom. What works in the Heartlands—where Loom coverage is total and Orthodox faith dominant—fails spectacularly in the Far Shelf. What works in the Vent Lands' guild structure makes no sense in the Shattered Reaches' maritime fragmentation. This document describes how each region actually governs, not just what principles they claim. The Heartlands: Orthodox Theocratic Monarchy The Official Structure The Crown : Hereditary monarchy, pattern-validated. The ruling family's pattern includes "governance fate." Succession is technically by birth order, practically by pattern-suitability reading. Unsuitable heirs can be passed over "for the good of the pattern." The Church : The Orthodox Church of the Weaver operates as parallel government. The High Primate is theoretically subordinate to the Crown but controls the Loom apparatus, which makes the relationship... complicated. The Council of Threads : Advisory body of major noble houses, high clergy, Warden Order representation, and selected merchant interests. Formally advisory; practically constrains royal action. The Warden Order : Enforcement arm with legal authority parallel to secular courts. Reports to Church hierarchy but operates with significant autonomy. The Actual Power Distribution The Crown controls: military force, taxation, secular appointments, foreign policy (officially), and emergency powers. The Church controls: Loom access, pattern certification, deviation prosecution, education (largely), marriage authorization, and theological legitimacy. The Noble Houses control: local governance in their territories, military levies, resource extraction, and trade relationships. The Warden Order controls: information about deviation, pattern-crime prosecution, inter-house disputes involving pattern, and a monopoly on violence that the secular military can't match for precision. How Decisions Actually Get Made Routine matters : Bureaucracy. A vast apparatus of pattern-certified clerks processing applications, resolving disputes, allocating resources. The machine runs itself. Policy matters : Negotiation between Crown, Church, and major houses. No one party can impose on the others. Coalitions form around specific issues. The appearance of unity matters enormously. Pattern matters : The Church. If it involves deviation, Loom interpretation, or theological legitimacy, secular authorities formally defer. In practice, secular authorities negotiate quietly. Crisis matters : Whoever acts first. The formal process is too slow. Crises are resolved by whoever has force available and will to use it. Legitimacy is constructed afterward. The Succession Question The Heartlands' great vulnerability is succession. The pattern-reading system creates uncertainty: The Crown Prince's pattern might indicate unsuitability A younger sibling might have a stronger "governance fate" Readings can be manipulated (or accused of manipulation) The Church controls the reading process Every succession is a potential crisis. Houses position for influence over the next ruler. The Church leverages its reading authority. The current system survives because everyone fears the alternative more than they resent the current arrangement. The Shattered Reaches: Fragmented Maritime Polities The Overall Structure No unified government. Instead: City-States : Major port cities govern themselves and hinterlands. Varying internal structures—some hereditary lords, some elected councils, some merchant oligarchies. Island Kingdoms : Larger islands or island chains under single rulers. Range from absolute monarchies to constitutional systems with strong assemblies. Merchant Leagues : Transnational organizations of trading houses. Not governments technically, but exercise governmental functions—currency, contract enforcement, dispute resolution. Free Ports : Cities that claim no sovereign, governed by whatever coalition currently maintains order. Frequently chaotic. Common Elements Despite fragmentation, most Reaches polities share: Assembly Traditions : Some body represents major interests—landholders, merchants, guilds, sometimes broader citizenship. Even autocrats convene assemblies for legitimacy. Contract Primacy : Written agreements are sacred. Enforcement varies but the principle is consistent. Maritime Law : Shared traditions governing ships, ports, sea commerce. Recognizable across polities even when local law diverges. Pattern Skepticism : Official rejection of pattern-determinism, even while pattern information circulates privately. The League System Merchant Leagues provide coherence the political system lacks: The Amber League : Residue trade. Controls major refinement facilities. Can embargo polities that misbehave. The Salt League : Fishing and sea-hunting. Controls most protein production. Seasonal workers depend on League contracts. The Iron League : Metals and manufacturing. Dominates Reaches industrial capacity. The Counting League : Banking and insurance. Enforces debts across jurisdictions. These Leagues: - Negotiate with each other as quasi-states - Maintain private arbitration systems - Control key infrastructure - Cross-cut political boundaries - Provide stability the political system doesn't Decision-Making Within polities : Varies by polity. Hereditary rulers, elected councils, oligarchic boards. Most involve negotiation between major interests. Between polities : Treaties, trade agreements, temporary alliances. No permanent inter-polity structure. The Leagues provide coordination when needed. Region-wide : Rarely achieved. Existential threats (Heartlands aggression, major piracy) might produce temporary confederation. Otherwise, each polity acts independently. The Middle Waters: Colonial Administration and Contested Authority The Patchwork The Middle Waters is not a unified region. It's a collection of: Heartlands Colonies : Directly administered from the Heartlands. Governors appointed, pattern-certified. Orthodox church presence. Warden authority recognized. Reaches Trading Posts : Commercial enclaves under League authority. Focused on trade, not governance. Minimal administration beyond what commerce requires. Vent Lands Footholds : Guild-operated facilities. Primarily geothermal research and colony cultivation. Governed by guild protocols. Native Polities : Indigenous governance systems that predate colonial contact. Various structures—island monarchies, council systems, Colony Cult theocracies. Surviving in territories colonizers haven't taken. Contested Zones : Areas where multiple powers claim authority. Practical governance by whoever has force present. Colonial Administration Heartlands colonies follow a template: Governor : Appointed from Heartlands, pattern-certified for colonial service. Extensive authority within colony. Reports to colonial ministry in the capital. Colonial Council : Local merchants, settlers, sometimes native representatives. Advisory formally; practically shapes policy because Governor needs local cooperation. Orthodox Mission : Church presence. Conversion efforts. Loom access for colonists. Pattern-reading services. Warden Contingent : Pattern-crime enforcement. Often understaffed for territory covered. Military Garrison : Varies by colony importance. Some heavily defended; some token presence. Native Governance Pre-contact polities that survive: Island Kingdoms : Traditional hereditary rule, sometimes modified by colonial contact. May acknowledge colonial overlordship nominally while operating independently practically. Colony Cult Councils : Governance through the oldest, most-integrated hosts. The colony itself participates in decisions (or is perceived to). Disturbing to outsiders; functional for members. Elder Assemblies : Collective governance by age-ranked community members. Pattern-skeptical traditions. Resistant to Loom integration. The Power Dynamics Heartlands wants: resources (tropical agriculture, rare materials), strategic position (naval bases), and Loom extension (integration of native populations into pattern-tracking). Reaches want: trade access, competitive position against Heartlands, resource extraction without administrative burden. Vent Lands want: specific research sites, colony cultivation environments, and deniable experimentation space. Native populations want: survival, autonomy, and to play powers against each other. The result is constant maneuvering, shifting alliances, and no stable governance framework. The Vent Lands: Guild Federation The Guild Structure The Primary Guilds (control critical infrastructure): Thermal Engineers Guild : Maintains geothermal systems that make habitation possible. Without them, the heat stops. Ultimate veto on anything. Sulfur Extractors Guild : Controls toxic zone operations. Essential for industrial inputs. Flesh Shapers Consortium : Actually several competing guilds united for external negotiation. Controls homunculi production, medical services, and flesh-shaping expertise. Makers Guild : Manufacturing, crafting, non-flesh construction. Largest membership. Merchants Assembly : Trade and commerce. Not technically a guild; effectively operates as one. The Secondary Guilds : Dozens of specialized trades. Less political power but economically important. The Council System The High Council : Representatives of primary guilds. Makes region-wide decisions. Operates by consensus mostly; votes when necessary, weighted by guild importance (which is constantly contested). Valley Councils : Local governance for specific thermal valleys. Primary guilds represented; secondary guilds have voice. Handle local disputes, resource allocation, emergency response. Inter-Guild Courts : Dispute resolution between guilds or between guild members and non-members. Judges selected from neutral guilds. Precedent-based, expertise-weighted. Decision-Making Technical decisions : Made by relevant guild. If the Thermal Engineers say a system is unsafe, it's unsafe. If Flesh Shapers say a procedure is untested, it's untested. Expertise commands deference. Resource allocation : Negotiated in councils. Guilds trade access for access. "We'll route more heat to your valley if you prioritize our metal orders." External relations : High Council speaks for the region. Individual guilds can pursue external relationships within guidelines. Emergencies : Rapid guild coordination through standing protocols. Volcanic events, toxic spills, and major accidents trigger automatic responses without political debate. Non-Guild Population Not everyone is guild member. Non-members: - Can work for guilds as employees (not members) - Have limited legal standing in guild courts - Can form associations for mutual aid - Cannot access guild-controlled resources directly - Depend on guild good behavior for survival This creates a two-tier system. Guild members have rights and power. Non-members have what members grant them. The Vent Lands' Advantage The guild system works because: - Everyone depends on infrastructure - Expertise is genuinely necessary and scarce - Geographic constraints force cooperation - External threats (volcanoes, toxins, ice) override internal conflicts - The system produces results (heat, safety, prosperity) It's not democratic. It's not equal. But it's stable and functional. The Far Shelf: Decentralized Autonomy The Non-Structure The Far Shelf resists unified governance by design. What exists: Community Assemblies : Each settlement governs itself. Size varies from family groups to substantial towns. Decisions made by consensus, voting, or charismatic authority depending on local tradition. Regional Councils : Occasional gatherings of community representatives. No permanent structure. Convened for specific issues, dissolves when issue resolved. Defense Coordination : The one function requiring regional cooperation. Loose agreements about mutual aid, warning systems, and resistance to external incursion. Trade Networks : Informal relationships between communities. No League-style organization. Trust-based, family-based, history-based. Variation in Local Governance Consensus Communities : Decisions require agreement of all adults. Time-consuming but cohesive. Common in smaller settlements. Council Communities : Elected or selected representatives make decisions. Larger settlements need this efficiency. Elder Dominance : Oldest members have authority. Traditional form, declining but persistent. Strong Chief : Individual leader with broad authority. Usually emerges in crisis, sometimes persists. Hybrid Forms : Consensus on major issues, delegation on minor. Elections for some positions, inheritance for others. Whatever the community has evolved. How Regional Action Happens When the Far Shelf acts as a region (rare): Someone calls a gathering : A community facing a problem invites others. There's no standing authority to convene. Communities send representatives : Or don't. Attendance is voluntary. Debate occurs : No rules of order necessarily. Charismatic speakers, respected elders, and holders of relevant information shape the conversation. Consensus emerges (or doesn't) : If enough communities agree, they act together. If not, they don't. Action is voluntary : Each community implements (or doesn't) according to their own decision. This sounds unworkable. It often is. But it's also resistant to capture—no one can seize central authority because there isn't any. Resistance Identity Far Shelf politics is defined by opposition to: Heartlands imperialism Loom surveillance Pattern-determinism Orthodox theology Centralized authority This resistance is the closest thing to regional ideology. Communities that disagree about everything else agree they don't want to become the Heartlands. The Weaknesses Coordination failure : Collective action problems are real. Communities that need to cooperate often can't. External exploitation : Powerful external actors (Heartlands traders, Reaches merchants) can exploit disunity. Internal conflict : Without central authority, inter-community disputes can escalate. Resource scarcity : The Far Shelf is poor. Governance can't solve resource constraints. Governance Comparison Dimension Heartlands Shattered Reaches Middle Waters Vent Lands Far Shelf Unity Unified (one crown, one church) Fragmented (many polities) Colonial patchwork Guild federation Radically decentralized Legitimacy Basis Divine pattern-mandate Consent and contract Power projection Expertise and necessity Community autonomy Decision Mode Negotiation among elites Varies by polity; league coordination Imposed by strongest Guild consensus Local consensus Pattern Role Central (certification required) Marginal (officially) Varies by controller Secondary to expertise Rejected Warden Status Full authority Treaty-limited Colonial presence Guild-negotiated Illegal Stability Stable until succession Stable within polities; regional chaos Unstable, contested Very stable Chaotic but resilient Inter-Regional Governance No World Government There is no global authority. The closest approximations: The Orthodox Church : Claims universal spiritual authority. Recognized only in Heartlands and colonies. Others reject the claim. The Warden Order : Claims jurisdiction over pattern-crimes everywhere. Practically limited to where they can operate. The Merchant Leagues : Cross-border economic coordination. No political pretensions, but economic leverage creates influence. The Loom Network : Nodes in every region connect to the same system. The Attendance doesn't recognize borders. But control of nodes is fragmented. Treaty Relationships Heartlands-Reaches : Complex web of bilateral treaties. Trade agreements, extradition provisions, Warden access rights. Renegotiated constantly. Heartlands-Vent Lands : Trade treaties. Guild limitations on Warden operations. Mutual recognition of contracts. Heartlands-Far Shelf : No formal treaties. The Heartlands doesn't recognize Far Shelf sovereignty; the Far Shelf doesn't acknowledge Heartlands authority. Reaches-Vent Lands : Commercial treaties through the Leagues. Guild-League mutual recognition. Everyone-Middle Waters : The Middle Waters isn't party to treaties—it's the subject. External powers make agreements about the Middle Waters, not with it. Conflict Resolution Between Heartlands and Reaches : Occasional naval skirmishes, trade wars, proxy conflicts. No full-scale war in generations (too costly for both). Between Heartlands and Far Shelf : Persistent low-level conflict. Heartlands claims authority; Far Shelf resists. Neither commits to decisive action. Between Reaches polities : Frequent. Piracy, trade disputes, territorial claims. Usually limited in scope. The Leagues sometimes mediate. In Middle Waters : Constant maneuvering, occasional violence, no resolution. The colonial powers prefer frozen conflict to resolution that might advantage rivals. Summary: The Governance Landscape Hálcova has no unified political order. Five regions with five different systems interact through trade, conflict, and limited treaty. The Loom connects them metaphysically; nothing connects them politically. This fragmentation is stable because: - No power can dominate all others - Geography and climate limit force projection - The Residue economy creates interdependence without requiring integration - Everyone fears what a true hegemon might do with the Loom The instability lies in: - Succession crises in the Heartlands - Colonial competition in the Middle Waters - Coordination failures in the Far Shelf - Guild tensions in the Vent Lands - Everything in the Shattered Reaches The system persists not because it works well, but because alternatives are worse—or because pattern predicts it will persist. Which amounts to the same thing. Further documentation needed on: Specific polities within regions, succession crisis examples, treaty texts, inter-regional conflict history, Warden Order jurisdictional maps

This fragmentation is stable because: - No power can dominate all others - Geography and climate limit force projection - The Residue economy creates interdependence without requiring integration - Everyone fears what a true hegemon might do with the Loom The instability lies in: - Succession crises in the Heartlands - Colonial competition in the Middle Waters - Coordination failures in the Far Shelf - Guild tensions in the Vent Lands - Everything in the Shattered Reaches The system persists not because it works well, but because alternatives are worse—or because pattern predicts it will persist. Which amounts to the same thing. Further documentation needed on: Specific polities within regions, succession crisis examples, treaty texts, inter-regional conflict history, Warden Order jurisdictional maps

docs.text: Hálcova: Legal Frameworks and Pattern Law Document Scope : This document details legal systems and pattern-crimes —the taxonomy of offenses, court structures, and enforcement mechanisms. For regional governance structures, see governance_structures.md . For philosophical questions about pattern-governance, see political_philosophy.md . For a comprehensive overview combining all aspects, see politics_law_and_systems.md . Overview Law in Hálcova cannot escape pattern. The existence of readable fate, predictable behavior, and measurable destiny forces every legal system to answer questions Earth jurisprudence never faced: Can you punish inevitability? Can you contract against destiny? Is deviation a crime or a miracle? Different regions answer differently. All answers cost something. The Taxonomy of Pattern-Crimes Deviation Definition : Acting against your pattern's predictions. The Problem : If patterns are divine (Orthodox view) or physically real (materialist view), deviation is either sin or impossibility. Yet it happens. Some people act against prediction. Orthodox Position : Deviation is heresy. The pattern is The Weaver's will; defying it defies divine order. Punishment is spiritual correction as much as temporal. Skeptic Position : Deviation proves patterns are probabilistic, not deterministic. "Deviants" are just statistical outliers. Criminalizing deviation criminalizes being unpredicted. Actual Practice : Heartlands criminalizes deviation. Shattered Reaches doesn't (officially). Other regions vary. The Warden Order prosecutes deviation everywhere it can reach, creating jurisdictional conflicts. Pattern Fraud Definition : Misrepresenting your pattern to gain advantage. Subtypes : Identity Fraud : Claiming to be someone with a different pattern. Using someone else's pattern-documentation. Reading Fraud : Providing false pattern-readings. Bribing Loom-readers. Using counterfeit pattern-engines. Prediction Fraud : Claiming false predictions to manipulate others. "The Loom says you'll fail unless you pay me." Suppression Fraud : Hiding your pattern when legally required to disclose. Employment fraud. Marriage fraud. Contract fraud. Why It Matters : Pattern information has economic value. The entire credit, insurance, and employment system rests on pattern accuracy. Fraud attacks the foundation. Enforcement : Heavy everywhere. Even the Far Shelf, which hates pattern-tracking, punishes fraudulent misrepresentation. The crime isn't having a pattern—it's lying about it. Pattern Evasion Definition : Avoiding pattern-reading or removing yourself from the Loom's tracking. The Gray Area : Is it illegal to simply... leave? To go where the Loom doesn't reach? To refuse readings? Orthodox Position : Evasion is proto-deviation. Why avoid the Loom unless you plan to deviate? Evasion is suspicious and warrants investigation. Autonomist Position : You own your pattern. Refusing to share it is your right. Mandatory reading is slavery. Actual Practice : The Heartlands requires pattern documentation for most activities. No reading, no employment, no housing, no trade. Evasion isn't explicitly illegal—you just can't participate in society. The Far Shelf explicitly protects pattern-privacy. Forced reading is assault. Other regions fall between. Pattern Interference Definition : Manipulating someone else's pattern without consent. Theoretical Nature : May not be possible. May be mythical. The uncertainty is part of the legal problem. Legal Treatment : Illegal everywhere—in theory. But if it's impossible, the laws are purely symbolic. If it's possible and secret, the laws are unenforceable. The Warden Order maintains that interference is real and they've prosecuted it. Skeptics note that "interference" explains away prediction failures conveniently. The Burden of Proof : How do you prove someone's pattern was interfered with? The pattern is what it is now. You'd need evidence of what it was before—which requires trusting old readings, which could also have been fraudulent. Pattern Trafficking Definition : Trading in pattern information without authorization. The Market : Pattern data has value. Employers want it. Lenders want it. Families want it. Criminals want it. There's money in knowing someone's pattern. Legal Status : Authorized Access : Loom-readers, Wardens, certain officials can access patterns legitimately. Regulated Trade : Some jurisdictions allow pattern-data sale with consent. Buy someone's pattern-reading for credit approval? Legal if they agreed. Black Market : Unauthorized readings. Stolen data. Readings sold without subject's knowledge. Illegal everywhere. The Infrastructure : Pattern trafficking requires access to Loom-engines, which are controlled. Black market depends on corrupt readers, stolen equipment, or unregulated nodes. Contract Law and Pattern The Enforceability Problem A contract is a meeting of minds, creating mutual obligation. But on Hálcova: The Loom knew you'd sign before you did Your pattern may have made signing inevitable Your future capacity to fulfill was predictable The other party may have known your pattern and exploited it When Is a Contract Void? Pattern Exploitation : If one party knew the other's pattern predicted failure, and structured the deal to profit from that failure, is the contract predatory? Orthodox Position : Patterns are public information. Using it is prudent, not exploitative. Caveat emptor. Reformist Position : Information asymmetry this extreme vitiates consent. Pattern-exploitation contracts should be voidable. Prediction Manipulation : If the contract was designed to create the outcome the pattern predicted—if the prediction is self-fulfilling because the contract makes it so—is that fraud? Example : Lender gives loan to "failure pattern" debtor at crushing terms. Terms guarantee failure. Lender profits from failure. The pattern was accurate because the contract made it accurate. Deviation Clauses : Some contracts include provisions for deviation. "If Party A deviates from predicted behavior, contract is void." This incentivizes pattern-compliance—or punishes the rare genuine choice. Pattern-Contingent Contracts Contracts explicitly tied to pattern outcomes: Futures : "I will pay X if your pattern manifests outcome Y." Insurance : "I will cover losses from outcome Y unless pattern indicated Y." Bonds : "My pattern predicts success; I bond myself against failure." Marriage : "We agree to join contingent on compatible patterns remaining compatible." These contracts treat pattern as fact—and create massive markets around prediction accuracy. The Assignment Problem Can you transfer your pattern? Your fate? Your predicted outcomes? No : Pattern is inherent. You can't give someone else your destiny. Sort Of : You can transfer economic interests in your pattern. Sell shares in your predicted success. Assign rights to your Residue upon death. Create instruments based on your predicted trajectory. Resulting Instruments : Fate Futures : Tradeable contracts based on predicted pattern-outcomes. Death Bonds : Instruments that pay upon subject's death (incentives get dark quickly). Residue Rights : Assignable claims to the Residue someone's death will produce. These markets exist, are regulated inconsistently, and create incentives the designers probably didn't intend. Criminal Procedure and Pattern Pattern Evidence in Criminal Trials Prosecution Use : "Defendant's pattern includes 'will commit violence.' This act was predicted. Defendant is the predicted perpetrator." Defense Use : "Defendant's pattern doesn't include this crime. The Loom didn't predict it. Wrong suspect." The Problem : Pattern evidence is probabilistic. Patterns don't specify every action. A "violence pattern" doesn't mean this specific violence. A clean pattern doesn't mean incapable of crime. Actual Practice : Heartlands: Pattern evidence is admissible, weighted, but not dispositive. Pattern supports other evidence; rarely convicts alone. Shattered Reaches: Pattern evidence officially inadmissible in public courts. Private arbitration uses it freely. Vent Lands: Pattern evidence is secondary to material evidence. Actions matter more than predictions. Far Shelf: Pattern evidence excluded. "Patterns don't commit crimes; people do." Pre-Crime Intervention The Temptation : The Loom predicts future behavior. Why wait for the crime? Arguments For : Prevention is better than punishment Victims are protected before they're harmed Deterrence works better when intervention precedes action Arguments Against : Punishing non-actions is unjust Prediction isn't certainty; innocents will be punished Creates the outcome it predicts (treating someone as criminal makes them criminal) Where does it end? Every "bad pattern" becomes pre-criminal? Actual Practice : Heartlands: Limited pre-crime intervention. "Dangerous patterns" may be monitored, required to register, restricted in travel or occupation. Actual detention requires additional evidence. Other regions: Generally reject pre-crime detention. Monitoring may occur. Far Shelf: Explicitly prohibits pattern-based pre-crime action. "The crime is the crime. The pattern is not the crime." Sentencing and Pattern If pattern predicts recidivism, should sentences be longer? Incapacitation Argument : Long sentences for high-recidivism patterns protect society. The prediction justifies the extension. Justice Argument : Punishment should fit the crime committed, not crimes predicted. Sentencing the future is unjust. Practical Reality : Most jurisdictions use pattern information in sentencing, openly or covertly. Judges are human; they have access; they use it. The Data : Jurisdictions that pattern-adjust sentences show... complex results. Lower recidivism among released (because predicted-recidivists serve longer). But higher total incarceration. And the prediction accuracy is confounded by the intervention. Family Law and Pattern Marriage and Pattern-Compatibility The Practice : Pattern-readings are standard before marriage in most regions. Incompatible patterns are disclosed. Compatible patterns are celebrated. The Question : Should pattern-incompatibility void a marriage? Orthodox Position : Incompatible patterns should prevent marriage. Marrying against pattern is deviation. Romantic Position : Love transcends pattern. Compatibility reading is information, not mandate. Actual Practice : Heartlands requires compatibility reading; strongly discourages incompatible unions; doesn't technically forbid them. Other regions vary. The Failure Case : If a marriage fails, and the patterns predicted failure, who's responsible? Did they deviate by marrying? Did they fail to deviate sufficiently to save it? Inheritance and Pattern The Issue : If your pattern predicts wealth-accumulation, is your wealth "earned"? If your heir's pattern predicts squandering, should they inherit? Orthodox Position : Wealth flows according to pattern. Inheritance is pattern-expression. Let it flow. Reformist Position : Pattern-based inheritance entrenches inequality. Use inheritance taxes, estate limitations, pattern-blind distribution. Actual Practice : Heartlands allows pattern-conditional inheritance ("to my heir, unless their pattern indicates X"). Other regions vary. Custody and Pattern The Nightmare Case : Parents divorcing. Child's pattern is read. One parent's pattern is "compatible with child-raising." Other's isn't. Who gets custody? Pattern-Determinists : Pattern-compatible parent should raise the child. Outcomes will be better. The evidence is predictive. Pattern-Skeptics : Parenting isn't predictable this way. Pattern-reading is too coarse. Use traditional best-interests analysis. Actual Practice : Pattern evidence is used in custody disputes almost everywhere, despite controversy. Judges claim it's one factor among many. Critics note it's often decisive. Property Law and Pattern Acquisition and Pattern If your pattern predicts you'll acquire property X, and you acquire property X, did you "earn" it? If someone else's pattern predicted they'd acquire X, and you got it instead, did you steal their destiny? The Orthodox Answer : Pattern predicts, doesn't entitle. You own what you legally acquire. Pattern is descriptive, not prescriptive. The Uncomfortable Implication : Pattern-privileged people will acquire more, reliably. This isn't injustice—it's fate. The system is working correctly. The Reformist Answer : Pattern-advantage is unearned. Tax it. Redistribute from pattern-privileged to pattern-constrained. Residue Rights When someone dies, their Pattern Residue is released. Who owns it? Traditional View : The estate. Residue rights are property, inheritable, transferable. Reform View : Residue belongs to the community. The death happened here; the Residue should serve here. Radical View : Residue shouldn't be property. It's sacred / dangerous / collective. Commodifying death commodifies people. Actual Practice : Residue is property almost everywhere. The economic system depends on it. Reform efforts have failed. Radical positions are marginalized. The Loom's Property Status Who owns the Loom? Orthodox Position : The Loom is divine infrastructure. No one owns it. The Church administers it on behalf of The Weaver. Secular Position : The Loom is technology. Someone built it. Someone maintains it. That someone has property interests. Practical Answer : The Loom is controlled by the Orthodox Church in the Heartlands. Nodes elsewhere have various ownership (government, guild, private). The underlying infrastructure—whatever enables the Attendance to answer—is not owned because it's not understood. Warden Order Legal Authority Jurisdictional Claims The Warden Order claims authority to: - Investigate pattern-crimes anywhere patterns exist - Arrest deviants, fraudsters, evaders, interferers - Conduct trials (ecclesiastical courts in Heartlands, treaty-authorized elsewhere) - Execute sentences including death (Pattern-Severance) Basis for Authority In Heartlands : Embedded in government. Warden authority is state authority. In Shattered Reaches : Treaty-based. Specific rights negotiated with specific polities. Varies by jurisdiction. In Middle Waters : Colonial extension. Wardens operate in Heartlands-controlled zones. Contested elsewhere. In Vent Lands : Guild-negotiated limits. Wardens can pursue specific crimes with guild cooperation. No independent authority. In Far Shelf : Rejected. Wardens are foreign agents without legal standing. Operating openly risks arrest. Conflicts Extradition : Heartlands demands extradition of deviants from other regions. Other regions sometimes comply (valuable trade relations), sometimes refuse (sovereignty, ideology). Pursuit Rights : Can Wardens pursue a suspect into non-Heartlands territory? Officially no (without treaty). Actually, they sometimes do. Parallel Proceedings : A crime may be tried under Warden authority and local authority simultaneously. Which verdict controls? Specific Legal Codes by Region Heartlands: The Pattern Code Structure : Ecclesiastical law (pattern-crimes, deviation, heresy) parallel to secular law (ordinary crimes). Key Features : - Deviation is a crime, prosecuted by Wardens - Pattern-fraud is both ecclesiastical and secular crime - Pattern evidence admissible in all courts - Pre-crime monitoring authorized for "dangerous patterns" - Pattern-contingent contracts enforceable - Residue rights are property, regulated but tradeable Distinctive Elements : - "Pattern Certification" required for many activities - "Harmony Testing" for marriage, business partnership - "Fate Compliance Audits" for major institutions - Death sentences produce Residue assigned to state Shattered Reaches: The Maritime Compact Structure : Common law tradition, precedent-based, decentralized by polity. Key Features : - Pattern-crimes not generally recognized (fraud excepted) - Pattern evidence officially excluded from criminal trials - Pattern-contingent contracts enforceable as private agreements - Strong arbitration tradition (pattern evidence allowed) - Residue rights are property, largely unregulated Distinctive Elements : - "Jurisdictional Shopping" is common and accepted - Merchant league arbitration often preferred to state courts - "Pattern Privacy" recognized as right (can refuse disclosure) - Warden authority limited by specific treaty provisions Vent Lands: The Guild Protocols Structure : Guild-based law. Guilds govern members; inter-guild conflicts resolved by council. Key Features : - Expertise/capability matters more than pattern - Pattern evidence secondary to demonstrated competence - Contracts based on deliverables, not predictions - Residue rights regulated by safety guild (toxic substances) - Non-guild members have limited legal standing Distinctive Elements : - "Competence Certification" replaces pattern certification - Guild courts handle member disputes - Inter-guild trade governed by protocols, not state law - Wardens limited to specific treaty-defined violations Far Shelf: The Autonomy Charters Structure : Decentralized. Local charters establish local rules. Weak central coordination. Key Features : - Pattern-tracking rejected where possible - Deviation not criminalized (may be celebrated) - Pattern evidence excluded from legal proceedings - Strong privacy protections - Residue rights controversial (some communities refuse commodification) Distinctive Elements : - "Loom Refusal" protected as right - Warden presence illegal without invitation - Community assemblies resolve disputes - Emphasis on restorative over punitive justice Summary: Legal Frameworks Compared Issue Heartlands Shattered Reaches Vent Lands Far Shelf Deviation Crime Not crime Not crime Celebrated Pattern Evidence Admissible Officially excluded Secondary Excluded Pre-Crime Limited authorization Rejected Rejected Prohibited Pattern Contracts Fully enforceable Enforceable (private) Deliverable-based Void if pattern-contingent Residue Rights Regulated property Property Safety-regulated Contested Warden Authority Full Treaty-limited Guild-limited None Further documentation needed on: Case law examples, treaty texts, jurisdictional conflict records, Warden Order procedural rules, execution protocols and Residue disposition
