docs.text: Hálcova: Political Philosophy in a Fate-Real World Document Scope : This document explores philosophical questions about governance in a world where fate is real and readable. For regional governance structures, see governance_structures.md . For legal systems and pattern-crimes, see legal_frameworks.md . For a comprehensive overview combining all aspects, see politics_law_and_systems.md . The Fundamental Problem Every political philosophy on Earth assumes a baseline: people are created equal, or they aren't, but either way you can't prove it by reading their metaphysical signature at birth. Hálcova doesn't have that luxury. The Sórscad exists. It's readable. It predicts outcomes with uncomfortable accuracy. This breaks political philosophy at its foundations and forces reconstruction from first principles. The Questions That Matter What Does "Equality" Mean? On Earth : Equality typically means equal moral worth, equal rights, equal standing before the law—regardless of observable differences in capability or circumstance. On Hálcova : Observable differences include fate itself . The Loom can tell you, with measurable accuracy, whether this person will contribute to society or drain it, create value or destroy it, help or harm. The Problem : If equality means "treat everyone the same regardless of pattern," you're ignoring real information. A lender who ignores pattern when making loans will be outcompeted by one who doesn't. An employer who ignores pattern will hire worse workers. The system punishes equality. If equality means "treat everyone according to their pattern," you've created a caste system justified by prophecy. Pattern becomes destiny not because fate is fixed, but because everyone acts as if it is. Possible Positions : Pattern Realism : Patterns are real, differences are real, and pretending otherwise is foolish. Equality is a comfortable lie. Governance should optimize for outcomes, which means differential treatment. Pattern Skepticism : Patterns predict partly because people believe them. True equality requires ignoring patterns—which is costly but morally necessary. Someone has to pay the cost of treating people as if they had equal worth. Pattern Complexity : Equality doesn't mean "same treatment." It means "equal consideration of interests." A constrained pattern doesn't mean someone deserves less consideration—it means they need different support. What Does "Justice" Mean? On Earth : Justice typically involves assigning responsibility for actions, determining appropriate responses to harm, and ensuring fair distribution of benefits and burdens. On Hálcova : The Loom predicted the action. Did the person choose it, or was choice an illusion? Can you punish someone for doing what they were always going to do? Can you reward someone for inevitability? The Problem : If actions are genuinely fated, punishment is incoherent. You're punishing someone for being what they were always going to be. That's not justice—it's suffering added to suffering. If actions are genuinely chosen despite prediction, then deviants prove choice exists. But most people don't deviate. Are they choosing to comply, or unable to resist? Possible Positions : Consequentialist Justice : Don't worry about desert. Justice is about outcomes. Punish if punishment prevents future harm. Reward if reward produces future benefit. The person's "choice" is irrelevant; what matters is what works. Expressivist Justice : Punishment expresses social condemnation regardless of metaphysics. We punish not because the criminal "deserves" it, but because punishment communicates values. The audience matters more than the target. Restorative Justice : Forget punishment. Justice is about repairing harm. If someone's pattern predicted they'd harm others, the pattern doesn't matter—the harm does. Restore the victim; reintegrate the harmer; move on. Fatalist Justice : Accept that justice is impossible in any meaningful sense. What we call "justice" is actually just pattern-expression. The Loom predicted we'd punish; we punish; the prediction is confirmed. Don't pretend there's more. What Does "Consent" Mean? On Earth : Consent means voluntary agreement, free from coercion, based on adequate information. On Hálcova : The Loom knows whether you'll consent before you do. If someone manipulates you into "consenting," but the Loom predicted you'd be manipulated, did you consent? Can a pattern-constrained person ever meaningfully consent to anything? The Problem : Every pact, contract, and political arrangement rests on consent. If consent is illusory, every agreement is void. But if we treat consent as illusory, we've justified unlimited coercion (nothing matters anyway) or unlimited paternalism (we know better than you what you'll choose). Possible Positions : Experienced Consent : What matters is the subjective experience of choosing. Even if the choice was predicted, the person experienced deliberation, weighed options, and felt like they decided. That's consent enough. Structural Consent : Individual consent is less important than structural fairness. If the process that produces "consent" is rigged—if pattern-constrained people are systematically pushed toward agreements that harm them—then individual consent legitimizes nothing. Predictive Consent : Use the Loom to determine what someone would consent to under ideal conditions. If you know they'd agree to X if they fully understood it, you can act as if they've agreed. (This is terrifying but internally consistent.) Consent Skepticism : Consent is a useful fiction. Treat agreements as binding because a system of binding agreements works better than the alternative—not because consent is metaphysically meaningful. What Legitimizes Authority? On Earth : Authority is typically legitimized by: divine mandate, consent of the governed, tradition, expertise, or force. On Hálcova : The Loom adds new possibilities. Perhaps authority is legitimized by pattern—some people are fated to lead. Perhaps it's legitimized by Loom-sanction—the Attendance approves certain rulers. Perhaps it's legitimized by prediction—whoever rules is whoever was going to rule. The Problem : If the Loom can identify "leadership patterns," why wouldn't you use them? A ruler with a leadership pattern will lead better. Ignoring pattern information seems foolish. But pattern-based selection creates a closed loop. Leaders with "leadership patterns" rule because of their patterns, which means their ruling confirms their patterns, which legitimizes pattern-based selection. Possible Positions : Pattern-Merit : Leadership patterns are real and valuable. The best governance selects for pattern, trains those selected, and assigns authority based on predicted competence. Democracy is pattern-denial; meritocracy is pattern-acknowledgment. Anti-Pattern Democracy : The whole point of democratic governance is that it doesn't pre-select based on inherent qualities. Anyone can lead; the governed choose. Using pattern information corrupts the process. Loom Theocracy : The Attendance knows. It can identify not just leadership patterns but correct decisions. True governance asks the Loom and implements the answer. Human judgment is noise. Pragmatic Legitimacy : Who cares about philosophical legitimacy? Governance is legitimate if it works—if it maintains order, produces prosperity, and retains sufficient support to continue. Everything else is decoration. Legitimacy Theories by Region The Heartlands: Orthodox Theocratic Legitimacy The Theory : The Weaver assigned patterns, including rulers' patterns. The current ruling families rule because their patterns indicated rulership. Resisting their authority is resisting divine design. The Great Loom Node validates rulers. A proper ruler's pattern is read publicly; the Attendance confirms their fate includes governance. Challenges to authority are pattern-deviations—heresies as well as crimes. The Practice : Hereditary rule reinforced by pattern-reading. Succession crises resolved by Loom consultation. The Orthodox church legitimizes temporal authority; temporal authority protects church interests. The Tensions : What happens when a ruler's heir has an unsuitable pattern? What happens when the Loom predicts a ruler's failure? Who interprets the Loom's answers—and who checks the interpreters? The Critique : This system conflates "what will happen" with "what should happen." A pattern that predicts rulership doesn't make rulership right—it makes it likely. The Heartlands has collapsed the difference. The Shattered Reaches: Consent and Contract Legitimacy The Theory : Authority derives from agreement, not from pattern. The governed choose their governors, directly or through representatives. Contracts bind because parties agreed, regardless of what their patterns predicted. Pattern information is available but isn't supposed to be decisive. A merchant with a "failure pattern" can still trade, still contract, still participate—and if they succeed, their success is theirs. The Practice : City-states with varying governance models: direct assemblies, elected councils, hereditary positions constrained by charters, merchant leagues with voting weighted by stake. Pattern-based discrimination exists but is contested. Laws restricting pattern-discrimination coexist with private pattern-based pricing. The Tensions : Consent-based legitimacy assumes meaningful choice. Does it exist? Wealthy individuals and leagues have more power than their "one vote" suggests. Pattern-discrimination in private spheres undermines public equality. The Critique : The Shattered Reaches pretends pattern doesn't determine outcomes, while pattern actually determines outcomes through markets, reputation, and social sorting. Their equality is formal, not substantive. The Middle Waters: Colonial and Contested Legitimacy The Theory : Multiple legitimacy theories compete because multiple powers compete. Heartlands colonial governors claim Loom-sanctioned authority. Shattered Reaches merchant outposts claim contractual authority. Native island polities claim traditional authority. Colony Cults claim biological authority (the colony knows; the colony provides). The Practice : Overlapping jurisdictions, competing legal systems, forum shopping. A dispute might be resolved by Orthodox church court, merchant arbitration, traditional elder council, or colony-mediated consensus depending on who you ask and who has power. The Tensions : No single legitimacy framework commands universal acceptance. Power determines which framework applies in specific cases. The native population's frameworks are systematically disadvantaged. The Critique : The Middle Waters reveals that legitimacy theories are post-hoc justifications for power. Whoever wins the conflict gets to claim their theory was correct all along. The Vent Lands: Resource and Expertise Legitimacy The Theory : Authority derives from capability, specifically from controlling the geothermal resources that make the Vent Lands habitable. Those who understand the vents, who can keep the heat flowing and the toxins managed, have legitimate authority because everyone else will die without them. Pattern is acknowledged but less determinative—the Vent Lands need engineers, not destiny-readers. Expertise matters more than prophecy. The Practice : Guild-based governance. The Thermal Engineers' Guild, the Sulfur Extractors' Guild, the Flesh Shaper Guilds (multiple, competing) form councils that make decisions by expertise-weighted negotiation. Political power flows to those who control critical infrastructure. Challenge a guild's authority, and discover how cold you get when the heat stops flowing. The Tensions : Expertise-legitimacy justifies technocracy. Those without technical skills are second-class citizens. Guilds have economic interests beyond the common good. What counts as "expertise" is defined by those who already have power. The Critique : The Vent Lands has replaced pattern-aristocracy with expertise-aristocracy. The content changed; the structure didn't. The Far Shelf: Resistance and Autonomy Legitimacy The Theory : Authority derives from defending the community against outside threats, primarily Heartlands imperialism and Loom-system extension. Legitimate governance is governance that keeps the Far Shelf free—free from Orthodox control, free from comprehensive pattern-tracking, free from integration into the Residue economy's worst aspects. Deviation isn't crime here; it's virtue. Resisting pattern is resisting oppression. The Practice : Decentralized governance. Local assemblies with significant autonomy. Weak central coordination for external defense. Threadist and Hollow Saint influences openly present. Pattern-reading happens but isn't required. Loom coverage is thin and actively resisted. Some communities exist entirely off the Loom's network. The Tensions : "Freedom" often means freedom for the strong at the expense of the weak. Without Loom integration, coordination problems multiply. Resisting the Heartlands requires resources; resources require trade; trade requires compromise. The Critique : The Far Shelf's legitimacy theory is reactive—defined by what it opposes rather than what it proposes. Freedom from pattern-control is clear. Freedom for what is less so. Legal Frameworks The Core Problem: Intent and Prediction Earth legal systems typically require mens rea —a guilty mind. Did the person intend harm? Did they know what they were doing? Did they choose? On Hálcova, intent is partially knowable. The Loom can tell you if someone's pattern includes "will commit violence" or "will deceive." This breaks criminal law as usually conceived. Option A: Pattern-Predictive Policing If you can predict crime, why wait for it? Arrest people whose patterns indicate future harm. Punish them before they act. Problems : - Punishing non-actions is unjust by most frameworks. - Prediction isn't certainty; false positives will be punished for nothing. - Creates the outcome it predicts (treating someone as a criminal produces criminals). Option B: Pattern-Blind Law Ignore pattern information in legal proceedings. Judge only actions, not predictions. Treat everyone as if choice is real. Problems : - You're ignoring real information. - Recidivism prediction is useful; refusing to use it costs lives. - Disadvantages those who do use pattern information (private parties, other jurisdictions). Option C: Pattern-Weighted Sentencing Let pattern information affect sentencing, not guilt. Convict based on actions; sentence based on predicted future behavior. High-recidivism patterns get longer sentences (incapacitation) or different interventions (treatment if treatable). Problems : - Still punishing the pattern, not just the action. - Unequal sentences for identical crimes based on unchosen characteristics. - Pattern-constrained populations systematically receive harsher treatment. Option D: Pattern as Mitigating Factor If someone's pattern predicted their crime, they had less choice. Less choice means less responsibility. Less responsibility means lighter punishment. Problems : - Everyone can claim their pattern made them do it. - Rewards having "bad" patterns (reduces consequences). - Collapses the concept of responsibility entirely. Actual Legal Variation Heartlands : Pattern-weighted sentencing plus pattern-predictive intervention for "dangerous patterns." The Warden Order handles pattern-crimes (deviation, interference, evasion); secular courts handle ordinary crimes. Shattered Reaches : Officially pattern-blind, practically pattern-informed. Private arbitration uses pattern information openly. Public courts pretend not to. Middle Waters : Jurisdictional chaos. Colonial authorities, merchant courts, traditional systems, and cult mediation all compete. Pattern information matters depending on which system captures your case. Vent Lands : Expertise-based judgment. Guild courts handle guild members. Non-guild members have limited legal standing. Pattern matters less than demonstrated capability and contribution. Far Shelf : Local variation. Some communities ignore pattern entirely. Others use it for community-protective exclusion. Central coordination is minimal. Criminal Justice and Residue Production The Uncomfortable Intersection Executions produce Pattern Residue. The legal system that kills criminals is also a Residue production system. This creates incentives. The Observable Pattern : Jurisdictions with higher Residue demand have higher execution rates. Crimes that "merit" death penalty expand when Residue is scarce. Some jurisdictions explicitly auction execution rights (the death produces Residue; someone profits). Possible Responses : Accept and Regulate : Death is part of governance. Residue production is part of economy. Align them: execute those who deserve it; harvest the Residue; use proceeds for public good. Pretending otherwise is hypocrisy. Separate and Firewall : Residue from executions goes to neutral parties, not to the executing authority. Remove the incentive to execute for profit while acknowledging the Residue exists. Abolish Death Penalty : If execution creates economic incentive for execution, don't execute. Life imprisonment, exile, pattern-interference (if it exists), or other responses that don't produce Residue. Expose and Shame : Make the connection visible. Every death sentence comes with documentation of who profits from the Residue. Let public opinion regulate what law won't. The Heartlands Approach : Public Correction (execution for educational purposes) is an official practice. The Residue goes to the Loom infrastructure. The connection is explicit, defended on theological grounds: pattern-deviants have forfeited their pattern; their Residue serves the system they betrayed. The Far Shelf Approach : Minimal death penalty. Exile is preferred (they're not our problem anymore). When execution happens, communities often burn the body completely—waste the Residue rather than let it be harvested. A statement that death isn't commodity. Property and Pattern Who Owns What—and Why Does Pattern Matter? The Problem : Property rights assume you can own things, transfer things, and exclude others from things. But if your pattern determines your economic trajectory, are your property rights really yours ? If you were always going to be wealthy, is your wealth earned or destined? The Pattern-Property Intersection : Inheritance : Pattern-privileged families accumulate wealth across generations. Is this different from aristocracy? The wealth isn't legally tied to pattern—but pattern predicts who accumulates it. Contracts : Pattern information affects pricing. A loan to a "failure pattern" costs more. A job offered to a "success pattern" pays more. The free market efficiently incorporates pattern discrimination. Innovation : If your pattern includes "will invent," do you deserve patent rights? You didn't choose to be inventive. The pattern did the work. Possible Positions : Pattern-Libertarian : Property rights are property rights. If pattern helps you acquire property legally, the property is yours. Outcomes reflect pattern; so what? Trying to "correct" for pattern is theft. Pattern-Distributive : Property accumulation reflects pattern advantage, not just effort. Redistribute from pattern-privileged to pattern-constrained. The lucky shouldn't keep all their luck. Pattern-Communitarian : Property is social, not individual. The community as a whole decides allocation. Pattern information helps allocate efficiently—give resources to those whose patterns will use them well. Pattern-Skeptic : Refuse to let pattern information affect property distribution. Tax wealth regardless of pattern. Provide baseline regardless of pattern. Accept inefficiency as the price of not creating caste-by-prophecy. Inter-Regional Politics The Trade Web Residue Flows : The Heartlands produces the most Residue (largest population, most warfare, most executions). They export refined Residue to regions that need it. The Middle Waters imports heavily (warm, less death, high demand for magitech). The Vent Lands imports minimally (geothermal reduces need, but high-grade Residue still valuable). The Shattered Reaches trades (imports raw, exports refined, profits on processing). The Far Shelf resists (minimal imports, local production, avoids dependency). Food Flows : The Middle Waters exports food (warmth enables agriculture). The Heartlands is roughly self-sufficient (large, diverse). The Shattered Reaches imports food (maritime diet supplemented by trade). The Vent Lands imports food (volcanic soil is limited). The Far Shelf struggles (short growing season, hunting-dependent). Labor Flows : Pattern-constrained populations migrate toward where they can survive: - Middle Waters (warmth, less Loom oversight) - Vent Lands (expertise matters more than pattern) - Far Shelf (freedom from pattern-tracking) Pattern-privileged populations concentrate where their patterns are valued: - Heartlands (pattern-merit advancement) - Shattered Reaches (commercial opportunities) The Power Balance Military Capacity : The Heartlands has the largest military, supplied by Residue abundance. They could conquer anyone—if they could project force across oceans and ice. The Shattered Reaches has the best navy. They can't match Heartlands on land, but they control the seas. The Vent Lands has fortress geography. No one can invade without crossing toxic zones and thermal hazards. The Middle Waters is contested, not defensible. Whoever controls the seas controls access. The Far Shelf has space. Conquest is possible; occupation is impractical. Current Equilibrium : No one can dominate everyone. The Heartlands could crush any single rival but not all simultaneously. The Shattered Reaches can raid and embargo but not conquer land. The Vent Lands can defend but not project. The result is persistent competition without resolution. The Warden Order as Transnational Authority What They Claim The Warden Order serves pattern-integrity across all regions. Deviation is a universal threat. Heresy knows no borders. The Order operates wherever patterns exist—which is everywhere. What They Actually Have Full legal authority in the Heartlands (embedded in government) Significant presence in the Shattered Reaches (treaty rights, port access) Limited presence in the Middle Waters (colonial zones only) Contested presence in the Vent Lands (guild resistance) Minimal presence in the Far Shelf (actively opposed) The Political Function The Order is a Heartlands institution claiming universal jurisdiction. Other regions accept it to varying degrees because: - Heartlands trade depends on Order-guaranteed contracts - Some deviation threats are real and cross-border - Opposing the Order means opposing the Heartlands - Internal factions find the Order useful against rivals The Resistance The Far Shelf explicitly rejects Order authority. The Vent Lands limit Order operations to specific zones. The Shattered Reaches nominally accepts but practically obstructs. The Middle Waters is battleground—Order presence varies by which power controls which territory. Summary: Political Philosophy Positions Question Orthodox (Heartlands) Contractarian (Reaches) Colonial (Middle Waters) Technocratic (Vents) Autonomist (Far Shelf) Equality Pattern determines worth Formal equality despite pattern Depends who's asking Expertise determines worth Pattern oppresses; resist Justice Pattern-deviation is crime Actions matter, not patterns Power determines Guild judgment Community decides Consent Pattern includes consent Real but fragile Manufactured Irrelevant to competence Essential to legitimacy Authority Divine pattern-mandate Agreement of governed Whoever wins Those who can Those who defend Further documentation needed on: Specific legal codes by region, treaty structures, Warden Order jurisdictional conflicts, pattern-discrimination case law, succession crisis examples

docs.title: The Far Shelf: Resistance and Autonomy Legitimacy

docs.text: Earth legal systems typically require mens rea —a guilty mind. Did the person intend harm? Did they know what they were doing? Did they choose? On Hálcova, intent is partially knowable. The Loom can tell you if someone's pattern includes "will commit violence" or "will deceive." This breaks criminal law as usually conceived. Option A: Pattern-Predictive Policing If you can predict crime, why wait for it? Arrest people whose patterns indicate future harm. Punish them before they act. Problems : - Punishing non-actions is unjust by most frameworks. - Prediction isn't certainty; false positives will be punished for nothing. - Creates the outcome it predicts (treating someone as a criminal produces criminals). Option B: Pattern-Blind Law Ignore pattern information in legal proceedings. Judge only actions, not predictions. Treat everyone as if choice is real. Problems : - You're ignoring real information. - Recidivism prediction is useful; refusing to use it costs lives. - Disadvantages those who do use pattern information (private parties, other jurisdictions). Option C: Pattern-Weighted Sentencing Let pattern information affect sentencing, not guilt. Convict based on actions; sentence based on predicted future behavior. High-recidivism patterns get longer sentences (incapacitation) or different interventions (treatment if treatable). Problems : - Still punishing the pattern, not just the action. - Unequal sentences for identical crimes based on unchosen characteristics. - Pattern-constrained populations systematically receive harsher treatment. Option D: Pattern as Mitigating Factor If someone's pattern predicted their crime, they had less choice. Less choice means less responsibility. Less responsibility means lighter punishment. Problems : - Everyone can claim their pattern made them do it. - Rewards having "bad" patterns (reduces consequences). - Collapses the concept of responsibility entirely.
docs.title: The Core Problem: Intent and Prediction

docs.text: Heartlands : Pattern-weighted sentencing plus pattern-predictive intervention for "dangerous patterns." The Warden Order handles pattern-crimes (deviation, interference, evasion); secular courts handle ordinary crimes. Shattered Reaches : Officially pattern-blind, practically pattern-informed. Private arbitration uses pattern information openly. Public courts pretend not to. Middle Waters : Jurisdictional chaos. Colonial authorities, merchant courts, traditional systems, and cult mediation all compete. Pattern information matters depending on which system captures your case. Vent Lands : Expertise-based judgment. Guild courts handle guild members. Non-guild members have limited legal standing. Pattern matters less than demonstrated capability and contribution. Far Shelf : Local variation. Some communities ignore pattern entirely. Others use it for community-protective exclusion. Central coordination is minimal.
docs.title: Actual Legal Variation

docs.text: Executions produce Pattern Residue. The legal system that kills criminals is also a Residue production system. This creates incentives. The Observable Pattern : Jurisdictions with higher Residue demand have higher execution rates. Crimes that "merit" death penalty expand when Residue is scarce. Some jurisdictions explicitly auction execution rights (the death produces Residue; someone profits). Possible Responses : Accept and Regulate : Death is part of governance. Residue production is part of economy. Align them: execute those who deserve it; harvest the Residue; use proceeds for public good. Pretending otherwise is hypocrisy. Separate and Firewall : Residue from executions goes to neutral parties, not to the executing authority. Remove the incentive to execute for profit while acknowledging the Residue exists. Abolish Death Penalty : If execution creates economic incentive for execution, don't execute. Life imprisonment, exile, pattern-interference (if it exists), or other responses that don't produce Residue. Expose and Shame : Make the connection visible. Every death sentence comes with documentation of who profits from the Residue. Let public opinion regulate what law won't. The Heartlands Approach : Public Correction (execution for educational purposes) is an official practice. The Residue goes to the Loom infrastructure. The connection is explicit, defended on theological grounds: pattern-deviants have forfeited their pattern; their Residue serves the system they betrayed. The Far Shelf Approach : Minimal death penalty. Exile is preferred (they're not our problem anymore). When execution happens, communities often burn the body completely—waste the Residue rather than let it be harvested. A statement that death isn't commodity.
docs.title: The Uncomfortable Intersection

docs.text: The Problem : Property rights assume you can own things, transfer things, and exclude others from things. But if your pattern determines your economic trajectory, are your property rights really yours ? If you were always going to be wealthy, is your wealth earned or destined? The Pattern-Property Intersection : Inheritance : Pattern-privileged families accumulate wealth across generations. Is this different from aristocracy? The wealth isn't legally tied to pattern—but pattern predicts who accumulates it. Contracts : Pattern information affects pricing. A loan to a "failure pattern" costs more. A job offered to a "success pattern" pays more. The free market efficiently incorporates pattern discrimination. Innovation : If your pattern includes "will invent," do you deserve patent rights? You didn't choose to be inventive. The pattern did the work. Possible Positions : Pattern-Libertarian : Property rights are property rights. If pattern helps you acquire property legally, the property is yours. Outcomes reflect pattern; so what? Trying to "correct" for pattern is theft. Pattern-Distributive : Property accumulation reflects pattern advantage, not just effort. Redistribute from pattern-privileged to pattern-constrained. The lucky shouldn't keep all their luck. Pattern-Communitarian : Property is social, not individual. The community as a whole decides allocation. Pattern information helps allocate efficiently—give resources to those whose patterns will use them well. Pattern-Skeptic : Refuse to let pattern information affect property distribution. Tax wealth regardless of pattern. Provide baseline regardless of pattern. Accept inefficiency as the price of not creating caste-by-prophecy.
docs.title: Who Owns What—and Why Does Pattern Matter?

docs.text: Residue Flows : The Heartlands produces the most Residue (largest population, most warfare, most executions). They export refined Residue to regions that need it. The Middle Waters imports heavily (warm, less death, high demand for magitech). The Vent Lands imports minimally (geothermal reduces need, but high-grade Residue still valuable). The Shattered Reaches trades (imports raw, exports refined, profits on processing). The Far Shelf resists (minimal imports, local production, avoids dependency). Food Flows : The Middle Waters exports food (warmth enables agriculture). The Heartlands is roughly self-sufficient (large, diverse). The Shattered Reaches imports food (maritime diet supplemented by trade). The Vent Lands imports food (volcanic soil is limited). The Far Shelf struggles (short growing season, hunting-dependent). Labor Flows : Pattern-constrained populations migrate toward where they can survive: - Middle Waters (warmth, less Loom oversight) - Vent Lands (expertise matters more than pattern) - Far Shelf (freedom from pattern-tracking) Pattern-privileged populations concentrate where their patterns are valued: - Heartlands (pattern-merit advancement) - Shattered Reaches (commercial opportunities)
docs.title: The Trade Web

docs.text: Military Capacity : The Heartlands has the largest military, supplied by Residue abundance. They could conquer anyone—if they could project force across oceans and ice. The Shattered Reaches has the best navy. They can't match Heartlands on land, but they control the seas. The Vent Lands has fortress geography. No one can invade without crossing toxic zones and thermal hazards. The Middle Waters is contested, not defensible. Whoever controls the seas controls access. The Far Shelf has space. Conquest is possible; occupation is impractical. Current Equilibrium : No one can dominate everyone. The Heartlands could crush any single rival but not all simultaneously. The Shattered Reaches can raid and embargo but not conquer land. The Vent Lands can defend but not project. The result is persistent competition without resolution.
docs.title: The Power Balance
The Warden Order as Transnational Authority

docs.text: The Warden Order serves pattern-integrity across all regions. Deviation is a universal threat. Heresy knows no borders. The Order operates wherever patterns exist—which is everywhere.
docs.title: What They Claim

docs.text: Full legal authority in the Heartlands (embedded in government) Significant presence in the Shattered Reaches (treaty rights, port access) Limited presence in the Middle Waters (colonial zones only) Contested presence in the Vent Lands (guild resistance) Minimal presence in the Far Shelf (actively opposed)
docs.title: What They Actually Have

docs.text: The Order is a Heartlands institution claiming universal jurisdiction. Other regions accept it to varying degrees because: - Heartlands trade depends on Order-guaranteed contracts - Some deviation threats are real and cross-border - Opposing the Order means opposing the Heartlands - Internal factions find the Order useful against rivals
docs.title: The Political Function

docs.text: The Far Shelf explicitly rejects Order authority. The Vent Lands limit Order operations to specific zones. The Shattered Reaches nominally accepts but practically obstructs. The Middle Waters is battleground—Order presence varies by which power controls which territory.

docs.text: Hálcova: Politics, Law, and the Systems Document Scope : This is the comprehensive reference combining governance structures, legal frameworks, and political philosophy into a single document organized by region. For focused treatments, see: governance_structures.md (regional power structures), political_philosophy.md (philosophical questions), and legal_frameworks.md (legal systems and crimes). Overview Every political system on Hálcova faces the same fundamental challenge: the Loom exists . The Loom reads patterns. It predicts behavior. It knows—or creates—fate. This isn't theology or philosophy. It's infrastructure. The predictions are accurate enough that ignoring them is economically irrational, and using them is morally catastrophic. Magic makes it worse. The Five Arts let people harvest the dead, reshape bodies, trade souls, cannibalize futures, and merge with alien organisms. Every political system must answer: Who gets to use these powers? Under what constraints? With what oversight? The answers vary. None of them work well. The Heartlands: Theocratic Integration Political Structure The Heartlands operates as a theocratic monarchy with parallel secular and ecclesiastical authority. The Crown handles mundane governance—taxation, military, foreign policy. The Orthodox Church of the Weaver handles pattern matters—Loom access, deviation prosecution, fate certification. In practice, nothing is cleanly divided. Pattern affects everything. A trade dispute involves pattern-certified contracts. A succession crisis requires Loom readings. A military campaign needs pattern-intelligence on enemy commanders. The Church has its fingers in every pie because pattern is in every pie. The Crown maintains legitimacy through pattern-validation. The ruling family's Sórscad includes "governance fate"—the Loom predicts they'll rule, therefore they should rule. Circular logic that holds because everyone with power benefits from it holding. The Council of Threads advises the Crown: major noble houses, high clergy, Warden Order representatives, selected merchants. Formally advisory. Practically, the Crown can't act against unified Council opposition. The Warden Order enforces pattern-compliance. They answer to Church hierarchy but operate with significant autonomy. Their Attunement gives them abilities no one else has—pattern-sense, deviation-detection, enhanced physical capacity. Magic Regulation The Heartlands doesn't ban magic. It monopolizes it. Core Binding : Licensed and regulated. The Orthodox Church maintains binding facilities where approved practitioners create echoes under supervision. Private binding is illegal but common. The Church controls Residue distribution—want to bind? Buy your Residue from approved sources, register your binding, submit to periodic inspections. Flesh Shaping : Heavily restricted. The Orthodox position is that bodies are Weaver-given; reshaping them is soft heresy. Medical applications permitted under Church supervision. Cosmetic or enhancement shaping illegal. Combat modifications are treason. Reality: thriving black market serves those with money to bribe. Pact Summoning : Officially forbidden. The Elsewhere is the enemy of divine order. Pact Summoners face execution without exception. Reality: The Warden Order's Attunement looks suspiciously like a pact. Certain old families have "ancestral arrangements." The rule is: official pacts are forbidden; institutional pacts are classified. Fate Threading : Capital heresy. No licenses. No exceptions. Threaders hunted with same intensity as deviants. The Warden Order has specialized units—Unravelers—trained specifically to identify and terminate Threaders. Colony Summoning : Tolerated at margins, prohibited at core. Legal in frontier areas. In the Heartlands proper, hosts face significant civil disabilities—can't hold office, can't testify in Church courts, can't access certain Loom services. Fate System Integration Pattern Certification : Required for most activities. Employment, housing, marriage, trade, travel—all require proof of pattern-reading and absence of deviation flags. Without pattern documentation, you don't legally exist. Pattern Evidence : Admissible in all courts. Pattern-prediction about defendant's likely behavior can support charges, justify pre-trial detention, influence sentencing. Deviation as Crime : The Heartlands criminalizes acting against your pattern's predictions. Deviation prosecution is selective—wealthy deviants negotiate rehabilitation; poor deviants face Correction. Pre-Crime Monitoring : "Dangerous patterns" can be flagged for monitoring. Registration requirements. Travel restrictions. Employment limitations. Creates the outcomes it predicts. The Warden Order Jurisdiction : Pattern-crimes anywhere the Order can reach. Deviation, fraud, evasion, interference, trafficking. Powers : Detain without civilian oversight. Conduct pattern-readings without consent. Enter premises without warrant. Execute Pattern-Severance for capital pattern-crimes. The Attunement : Links Wardens to the Loom. They can sense deviation, feel pattern-disturbance, detect magic use. Cost is lifespan, flexibility, and capacity for doubt. Law and Order Ecclesiastical Courts : Handle pattern-crimes, deviation, heresy, unauthorized magic. Penalties include penance, property forfeiture, exile, and Correction (public execution producing Residue assigned to Church). Secular Courts : Handle ordinary crimes. Penalties include fines, imprisonment, labor service, and execution (Residue goes to jurisdiction). Residue from Justice : Executions produce Residue. Jurisdictions with shortages have higher execution rates. The legal system has financial interest in death. The Shattered Reaches: Fragmented Pragmatism Political Structure No unified government. Dozens of city-states, island kingdoms, merchant leagues, free ports. The only commonalities are maritime orientation and contract fetishism. The Leagues provide regional coordination. Amber League (Residue), Salt League (fishing), Iron League (manufacturing), Counting League (banking). Not governments, but they exercise governmental functions—currency, contract enforcement, dispute resolution. Magic Regulation No unified policy. Common patterns emerge from commercial logic. Core Binding : Generally legal, lightly regulated. Registration and periodic inspection. Black markets for sensitive bindings. Flesh Shaping : Legal in most polities, regulated as medical practice. Guild certification required. Combat modifications restricted but available. Pact Summoning : Status varies wildly. Some criminalize all pacts. Some regulate as contracts. Most prohibit involuntary substitution—creates market for "voluntary" substitution from desperate people. Fate Threading : Generally unregulated. Pattern-skepticism extends to Threading. Colony Summoning : Legal almost everywhere, regulated as health and safety matter. Fate System Integration Pattern Privacy : Most polities recognize pattern as private information. Can refuse readings. Pattern discrimination prohibited in public accommodations. Reality: private parties use pattern constantly. Pattern Evidence : Officially inadmissible in public courts. Private arbitration uses it freely. No Pre-Crime : Punished for what you did, not what you might do. Exception: contract-based restrictions are enforceable. The Warden Order Operates under bilateral treaties. Specific crimes only. Local cooperation required. No Pattern-Severance without local authorization. Defined duration. Law and Order Contract Supremacy : Written agreements are sacred. Courts exist primarily to interpret and enforce contracts. Maritime Law : Shared traditions recognized across polities. Arbitration : Most disputes go to private arbiters. Faster, more expert, allows pattern evidence. The Middle Waters: Colonial Patchwork Political Structure Not a region with a government—a region with competing governments. Heartlands Colonies : Governors appointed, pattern-certified. Standard colonial administration. Reaches Trading Posts : League-operated commercial enclaves. Minimal government. Vent Lands Footholds : Guild-operated facilities. Governed by guild protocols. Native Polities : Surviving indigenous governance—island kingdoms, elder councils, Colony Cult communities. Contested Zones : Multiple powers claim authority. Governance by whoever has force present. Magic Regulation Depends on who's in charge. Heartlands rules in colonies. Reaches rules in posts. Guild protocols in Vent facilities. Indigenous traditions in native polities. Colony Cult areas treat Colony Summoning as sacred. Some native communities have Pact Summoning traditions predating Orthodox prohibition. Fate System Integration Fragmented and contested. Full integration in Heartlands colonies. Optional in Reaches posts. Available but without legal weight in Vent facilities. Varies in native polities—some integrated, some resist entirely. Native populations often understand Loom as colonizer infrastructure. Resistance to Loom is resistance to cultural imperialism. The Warden Order Full jurisdiction in colonies. Claims jurisdiction elsewhere; others don't recognize it. Pursuing suspects outside colonies means requesting cooperation or military operation. Law and Order Colonial law in Heartlands colonies—harsher penalties, fewer protections. Plural legal systems in contested zones. More political violence than any other region. The Vent Lands: Guild Technocracy Political Structure Guild Federation : Primary guilds control critical infrastructure. Thermal Engineers maintain geothermal systems. Sulfur Extractors handle toxic operations. Flesh Shapers Consortium dominates biological industries. Makers Guild handles manufacturing. Merchants Assembly manages trade. Non-Guild Population : Limited legal standing, can't access guild-controlled resources directly, depend on guild good behavior. Two-tier system with explicit hierarchy. Magic Regulation Expertise-driven through guild structures. Core Binding : Legal, guild-supervised. Remembrancers' Guild handles most binding. Flesh Shaping : The Vent Lands specialty. Multiple competing guilds. World's leaders in shaping. Things illegal in Heartlands are routine here. Pact Summoning : Not criminalized. Regulated as contracts. Specialist guilds advise on Elsewhere negotiation. Fate Threading : Unregulated. Some guilds employ Threaders for specific purposes. Colony Summoning : The other Vent Lands specialty. Colony Engineering advanced here. Hosting common and normalized. Fate System Integration Expertise Over Pattern : What you can do matters more than what you're predicted to do. Guild advancement depends on demonstrated capability. No Pattern-Crimes : Deviation isn't criminalized. Pattern fraud addressed through contract law. The Warden Order Guild-negotiated limits. Specific violations only. Guild cooperation required. No independent operations. Minimal presence. Law and Order Guild Justice : Members subject to guild discipline. Penalties include fines, status reduction, expulsion. Inter-Guild Courts : Disputes between guilds. Judges from neutral guilds. Precedent-based, expertise-weighted. Safety Focus : Much law concerns safety. Geothermal systems, toxic zones, volcanic hazards require regulation. The Far Shelf: Decentralized Resistance Political Structure No Central Government : By design. Settled by people who left or fled centralized regions. Community Assemblies : Each settlement governs itself. Decision-making varies—consensus, voting, elder authority, strong chiefs. Regional Coordination : Occasional gatherings for external threats. No standing structure. Magic Regulation Minimal to none. Local customs vary. Core Binding : Generally accepted. Ancestor veneration traditions make binding culturally comfortable. Flesh Shaping : Varies by community. Pact Summoning : Many communities have ongoing Elsewhere relationships predating Orthodox prohibition. Hollow Saints theology originated here. Fate Threading : Sometimes celebrated. Threading represents resistance to fixed fate. Colony Summoning : Accepted, especially in colder areas. Fate System Integration Active resistance. No Pattern Certification : Most communities don't require it. Some have no Loom access. Deviation Is Not Crime : Often virtue. Successful deviants admired. Pattern Privacy : Where Loom exists, pattern is deeply private. Forced reading is assault. The Warden Order No legitimate authority. Operating openly risks arrest or violence. Covert operations only. Some communities offer bounties for captured Wardens. Law and Order Community Justice : Each community handles own disputes. No regional courts. Restorative Focus : Repair harm, reintegrate offender, exile as last resort. External Threat Focus : Much "law" concerns how to respond to Heartlands incursion. Cross-Regional Dynamics Magic Flows Flesh Shapers trained in Vent Lands serve clients in Heartlands (discreetly) and Reaches (openly) Pact Summoners flee Heartlands for Far Shelf or Reaches Fate Threaders survive longest in Far Shelf Colony Hosts seek Vent Lands for advanced integration Core Binders practice everywhere; sophisticated work in Heartlands and Reaches Residue Flows Heartlands produces most, exports refined Reaches imports raw, exports refined, profits on processing Middle Waters imports heavily Vent Lands imports minimally Far Shelf resists trade Jurisdictional Conflicts Extradition : Heartlands demands; others sometimes comply, sometimes refuse. Hot Pursuit : Treaties say no; practice varies. Conflicting Judgments : A practitioner convicted in Heartlands may live legally in Reaches. The Uneasy Equilibrium No region can impose its system on others. Heartlands can't project force effectively. Reaches controls seas but not land. Vent Lands can defend but not attack. Far Shelf can absorb any invasion. The system persists because everyone fears what would replace it. Summary Tables Magic Regulation by Region Art Heartlands Shattered Reaches Middle Waters Vent Lands Far Shelf Core Binding Licensed, Church-supervised Legal, lightly regulated Varies by zone Legal, guild-supervised Accepted, unregulated Flesh Shaping Restricted, medical only Legal, guild-regulated Varies by zone Specialty, guild-led Varies by community Pact Summoning Capital crime Varies; substitution often banned Varies by zone Legal, guild-advised Often traditional Fate Threading Capital heresy Mostly unregulated Varies by zone Unregulated Sometimes celebrated Colony Summoning Tolerated with disabilities Legal, safety-regulated Varies; native Cults Specialty, normalized Accepted Fate System by Region Element Heartlands Shattered Reaches Middle Waters Vent Lands Far Shelf Pattern Certification Required Optional Varies by zone Available Rare/refused Pattern Evidence Admissible Inadmissible (public) Varies by zone Not used Rejected Deviation Status Crime Not crime Varies by zone Irrelevant Sometimes virtue Pre-Crime Authorized Prohibited Colonial zones only Not practiced Prohibited Warden Status Full authority Treaty-limited Colonial presence Guild-constrained Illegal The law is what power says it is. Power varies by where you stand. The only constants are cold, Residue, and the Loom's silent watching.
