docs.text: Hálcova: Flora, Fauna, and Ecology Overview Life on Hálcova evolved under conditions radically different from Earth: amber-orange light from a K-type star, cold temperatures, Pattern Residue permeating the environment, and five-moon tidal rhythms. The result is an ecosystem that would seem alien to human eyes—dark vegetation, cold-adapted creatures, and organisms that interact with the exotic matter that defines this world. The Light Environment Sárgvas Spectrum The K-type star provides: - Dominant orange-red light - Significant infrared - Reduced ultraviolet - Less total energy than a G-type star at equivalent distance Photosynthesis Adaptation Earth plants are green because chlorophyll absorbs red and blue light, reflecting green. Under Sárgvas: - Less blue light available to absorb - More red and infrared available - Organisms evolved to absorb different wavelengths The Result : Hálcova's photosynthetic organisms absorb across a wider spectrum, including more infrared. They reflect very little, appearing dark to human-equivalent eyes. Flora by Climate Zone Polar Transition Zone (Darkest) Coloration : Black to deep charcoal Reason : Maximum light absorption needed; every photon counts Dominant Forms : Black Lichen - Encrusting growth on rocks, ice-free surfaces - Survives temperatures to -50°C - Photosynthesizes during brief light periods - Contains Pattern Residue-processing compounds (one of the few organisms that can) Shadow Moss - Thick, carpet-forming moss - Nearly black, occasionally deep purple - Insulating properties (creatures nest in it) - Grows on soil, dead vegetation, abandoned structures Pole-Creep - Extremely slow-growing woody plant - Hugs ground, never exceeds 10cm height - Wood is incredibly dense (centuries of growth compressed) - Valued for specialized construction Temperate Zones (Dark Purple to Deep Red) Coloration : Purple, maroon, deep burgundy Reason : Balance between absorption efficiency and avoiding overheating during Láng Dominant Forms : Blackwood Trees - Coniferous trees with black bark, dark purple needles - Grow 20-40m tall in favorable conditions - Wood is hard, dark, valuable for construction - Needles contain compounds used in medicine Bloodgrass - Prairie-forming grass with deep red blades - Covers temperate lowlands - Turns nearly black in winter, red in summer - Feeds grazing herds Vein-Vine - Climbing plant with purple stems, dark red leaves - Wraps around other plants or structures - Produces small berries (edible, bitter) - Spreads aggressively in disturbed areas Duskflowers - Flowering plants in various dark hues - Bloom briefly during Láng - Pollinated by cold-adapted insects and small flying creatures - Some species cultivated for dyes, medicine, ritual use Forest Character : Temperate forests on Hálcova are dark, cathedral-like spaces. The canopy absorbs most light. Undergrowth is sparse where canopy is thick. Sound carries strangely. The amber light filtering through dark needles creates an atmosphere humans find either peaceful or oppressive. Middle Waters / Tropical Zone (Brightest) Coloration : Deep red, orange-red, occasional bright orange Reason : Can afford to reflect more light; heat management more important than maximum absorption Dominant Forms : Ember Palms - Tropical equivalent with frond-like leaves in orange-red - Multiple species adapted to various island conditions - Some produce edible fruit - Wood is light, used for boats and structures Fire Ferns - Groundcover in bright red-orange - Thrives in volcanic soil - Some varieties only grow near geothermal vents Coral Equivalent - Colonial organisms building reef structures - Colors vary: red, orange, yellow (brightest organisms on Hálcova) - Not related to Earth coral—convergent evolution - Create complex underwater ecosystems Steam Orchids - Flowering plants near geothermal features - Spectacular colors (by Hálcova standards): orange, red, occasional yellow - Rare, valuable, cultivated with difficulty - Associated with Colony Cults (fungi often grow in same conditions) The Color Gradient Zone Vegetation Color Reason Polar Black Maximum absorption High latitude Charcoal, deep purple High absorption, some reflection Temperate Purple, maroon, burgundy Balanced absorption/reflection Subtropical Deep red, wine More reflection for heat management Tropical Red, orange-red, orange Maximum reflection sustainable Fauna: General Principles Cold Adaptation All Hálcova fauna evolved for cold conditions: Insulation : - Thick fur, fat layers, or unique insulating structures - Some species have hollow hairs (trapped air insulation) - Aquatic species have dense, oily coats Metabolism : - Generally slower than Earth equivalents - Can survive long periods without food - Hibernation-like states common during Csend - Quick metabolic bursts for predation/escape Size Patterns : - Large body size common (better heat retention) - Small species rare except in Middle Waters - Pack/herd behavior provides shared warmth Pattern Residue Interaction Most fauna avoids Pattern Residue: Residue Sensitivity : - High concentrations cause stress, disorientation - Animals avoid death sites until Residue dissipates - Migration patterns route around high-Residue areas - Explains why polar regions lack megafauna (Residue too dense) Exceptions : - A few specialized species have evolved Residue tolerance - Some actually feed on or process Residue - These species are economically important (see below) Notable Fauna Megafauna Iron Elk ( Vastúlszarvas ) - Massive cervid, shoulder height 2.5m - Antlers span up to 3m - Dense, shaggy coat (dark grey to black) - Migrates seasonally across temperate tundra - Primary prey species for large predators - Domesticated variant used as draft animal (smaller, more docile) Glacier Bear ( Jégmedve ) - Largest land predator in most regions - 3m at shoulder when standing - White to pale grey coat - Hunts anything it can catch - Mostly solitary - Feared and respected; hunting one is a cultural milestone Tundra Mammoth-Equivalent ( Gyapjasszörny ) - Woolly, elephant-like creature - Smaller than Earth mammoths (3m shoulder height) - Herds in interior plateau and Far Shelf tundra - Hunted for meat, hide, ivory-equivalent tusks - Some domestication attempts (limited success) Deepwater Leviathan ( Mélyviziátrém ) - Marine megafauna in Central Ocean - Size uncertain (rarely seen intact) - Hunted for oil, meat, bone - Dangerous prey—ships lost pursuing them - May be multiple species grouped under one name Residue-Interacting Species The Ash Moth ( Hamuszita ) - Large moth (wingspan 30cm) - Attracted to Pattern Residue - Congregates at death sites - Appears to feed on or process ambient Residue - Presence indicates Residue concentration - Used by harvesters to locate deposits Residue Beetles ( Maradványbogár ) - Small beetle that burrows into Residue-rich soil - Concentrates Residue in its shell - Shells collected for alchemical use - Farming attempts ongoing (limited success) The Thermal Worm ( Hőféreg ) - Found in Vent Lands geothermal zones - Processes both Residue and thermal energy - Bodies are warm to the touch even after death - Used as portable heat sources (in containers) - One of the few creatures that thrives in high-Residue environments Fate Hounds ( Sorsebek ) - Canid species with unusual Pattern sensitivity - Can sense strong Sórscad patterns - Trained by Warden Order for tracking deviants - Wild packs avoid high-Residue areas - Domesticated individuals bond to handlers - Not actually "hounds"—name is traditional Colony-Related Organisms Spore Carriers - Various insects and small animals - Carry fungal spores as part of lifecycle - Some deliberately seek Colony hosts to infect - Ecosystem role unclear (possibly mutualistic with wild colonies) The Reef-Fungus Symbiosis - In Middle Waters, reef organisms and fungal networks intertwine - Neither can survive without the other - Creates hybrid structures that confuse biologists - Colony Cults consider these sacred Domesticated Animals Draft Elk ( Tehénszarvas ) - Domesticated Iron Elk variant - Smaller, calmer, bred for strength - Primary draft animal on mainland - Also milked (rich, fatty milk) - Cultural significance varies by region Ship Dogs ( Hajókutya ) - Medium-sized canid bred for ship work - Rat-catching, guarding, companionship - Webbed feet, water-resistant coat - Standard on Shattered Reaches vessels Furnace Birds ( Kemencemadár ) - Domesticated fowl - Lay eggs, eaten for meat - Kept inside during Csend (cannot survive deep cold) - Require heated housing in most regions Tunnel Pigs ( Alagutdisznó ) - Bred to survive underground - Fat reserves for lean times - Eat almost anything organic - Provide meat, fat, leather - Common in mining settlements Fungi and the Colony Question Natural Fungi Fungi are ubiquitous on Hálcova: - Decomposition in cold conditions requires specialized organisms - Fungi fill ecological niches that bacteria fill on warmer worlds - Many edible species (carefully distinguished from toxic ones) - Mycorrhizal networks connect forest ecosystems Colors : Unlike plants, fungi don't photosynthesize. They come in all colors—white, grey, brown, orange, blue, even bioluminescent. The Colony Organisms The fungi used in Colony Summoning are related to but distinct from natural fungi: Key Differences : - Process Pattern Residue (natural fungi avoid it) - Form symbiotic bonds with hosts (natural fungi don't) - Store "patterns" of consumed organisms (natural fungi just decompose) - Respond to host will (natural fungi have no such interaction) Origins Unknown : - Did Colony fungi evolve naturally? - Were they engineered by ancient civilization? - Did they come from the Elsewhere? - Are they somehow related to the thing imprisoned at the southern pole? Ecological Role : - Wild Colony organisms exist (feral colonies) - They consume dead matter and grow - Without hosts, they can spread unpredictably - Some regions have "colony zones"—areas where wild colonies have established - These zones are dangerous and economically valuable Ecosystem Dynamics Food Webs Temperate Terrestrial : Vegetation (Blackwood, Bloodgrass) ↓ Primary Consumers (Elk herds, small grazers) ↓ Secondary Consumers (Wolf-equivalents, small predators) ↓ Apex Predators (Glacier Bears, human hunters) Marine : Phytoplankton-equivalent ↓ Small fish, filter feeders ↓ Medium fish, cephalopods ↓ Large fish, marine mammals ↓ Leviathans, human fishers Seasonal Cycles Csend (Winter) : - Most animals hibernate or reduce activity - Predators hunt weakened prey - Frozen carrion preserved for later consumption - Residue accumulates (less biological processing) Olvadás (Thaw) : - Awakening, breeding season begins - Disease spreads from thawed pathogens - Migratory species return - Residue releases from ice (flora and fauna respond) Láng (Summer) : - Peak activity, breeding, feeding - Maximum biomass - Predation intense (building reserves) - Residue at peak atmospheric concentration Hanyatlás (Decline) : - Preparation for winter - Migration begins - Final feeding push - Residue begins precipitating Köd (Veil) : - Animal behavior changes (affected by Elsewhere bleed) - Some species become aggressive - Some become docile, disoriented - Colony organisms highly active - Ash Moths swarm (Residue precipitation attracts them) Pattern Residue Ecology The Cycle : 1. Death releases Residue 2. Residue disperses into environment 3. Most organisms avoid, some process 4. Ash Moths, Residue Beetles concentrate it 5. Precipitation during cold seasons removes from atmosphere 6. Concentrated deposits form over time 7. Human harvesting or natural processing eventually cycles it The Imbalance : - Humans harvest Residue and burn it (removes it from ecosystem) - This should warm the world over time - But population death produces more Residue - Current equilibrium maintained by death rate matching harvest rate - If population grew without increased death, world might warm - If death rate spiked without harvest, world would cool further Dangerous Organisms Predators Pack Runners ( Falkafutók ) - Wolf-equivalent that hunts in packs of 10-30 - Coordinate attacks with disturbing intelligence - Primarily prey on elk, will attack humans - Avoid settlements but waylay travelers Ice Stalkers ( Jégkúszó ) - Ambush predator in polar transition zones - White/grey coloration, nearly invisible on ice - Attacks from concealment - Primarily a threat to expeditions Venomous/Toxic Frost Vipers ( Fagyoskígyó ) - Cold-blooded snake that evolved antifreeze blood - Venom causes rapid hypothermia - Bites are often fatal without treatment - Found under snow, in burrows, anywhere dark Bitter Toads ( Keserűvarangy ) - Amphibian with toxic skin secretions - Causes severe illness if handled or eaten improperly - Some cultures prepare them as delicacy (carefully) - Toxin used in alchemy Disease Vectors Blood Gnats ( Vérszúnyog ) - Small biting insect - Emerges during Olvadás and Láng - Carries various blood-borne diseases - Flesh Shapers particularly vulnerable (blood smell attracts them) Spore Flies ( Spóralégy ) - Carries fungal spores (some harmful) - Can transmit colony infection (rarely) - Killed on sight near settlements - More common in Middle Waters Köd Phenomena During the fifth season, some animals exhibit disturbing behaviors: Elsewhere-Touched : - Animals near the bleed zones may be influenced - Erratic behavior, ignoring normal instincts - Some become aggressive without provocation - Some become docile, staring at nothing - Physical changes reported (extra eyes, wrong number of limbs) - Usually die shortly after Köd ends - Bodies avoided—contamination risk Human Interaction Hunting and Fishing Subsistence : - Fishing is primary protein source in coastal regions - Hunting supplements agriculture everywhere - Fur trade economically important - Whale-equivalent hunting for oil and materials Commercial : - Iron Elk ranching in temperate regions - Fish processing facilities in Shattered Reaches - Fur trading companies in Far Shelf - Residue creature harvesting (specialized industry) Agriculture Challenges : - Short growing season (Láng + parts of Olvadás/Hanyatlás) - Cold-resistant crops only - Heavy labor to prepare frozen ground - Residue-burning for greenhouse heat Crops : - Root vegetables (cold-resistant) - Hardy grains (low yield, essential) - Fungi cultivation (indoor, reliable) - Greenhouse crops (luxury, expensive) Middle Waters Advantage : - Longest growing season - Most diverse crops - Food exporter to other regions - Agricultural wealth drives political importance Conservation vs. Exploitation Tensions : - Some species hunted toward scarcity - Residue creatures particularly pressured (economic value) - Colony zones expanding (ecosystem disruption) - Climate management affects habitat Management Attempts : - Hunting seasons in some regions - Protected zones (rarely enforced) - Domestication programs for threatened species - Colony zone containment (mixed success) Further documentation needed on: Specific species details, domestication history, regional ecological variation, Elsewhere-touched organism studies, marine ecosystem depth

docs.text: Coloration : Deep red, orange-red, occasional bright orange Reason : Can afford to reflect more light; heat management more important than maximum absorption Dominant Forms : Ember Palms - Tropical equivalent with frond-like leaves in orange-red - Multiple species adapted to various island conditions - Some produce edible fruit - Wood is light, used for boats and structures Fire Ferns - Groundcover in bright red-orange - Thrives in volcanic soil - Some varieties only grow near geothermal vents Coral Equivalent - Colonial organisms building reef structures - Colors vary: red, orange, yellow (brightest organisms on Hálcova) - Not related to Earth coral—convergent evolution - Create complex underwater ecosystems Steam Orchids - Flowering plants near geothermal features - Spectacular colors (by Hálcova standards): orange, red, occasional yellow - Rare, valuable, cultivated with difficulty - Associated with Colony Cults (fungi often grow in same conditions)
docs.title: Middle Waters / Tropical Zone (Brightest)

docs.text: Zone Vegetation Color Reason Polar Black Maximum absorption High latitude Charcoal, deep purple High absorption, some reflection Temperate Purple, maroon, burgundy Balanced absorption/reflection Subtropical Deep red, wine More reflection for heat management Tropical Red, orange-red, orange Maximum reflection sustainable
docs.title: The Color Gradient

docs.text: All Hálcova fauna evolved for cold conditions: Insulation : - Thick fur, fat layers, or unique insulating structures - Some species have hollow hairs (trapped air insulation) - Aquatic species have dense, oily coats Metabolism : - Generally slower than Earth equivalents - Can survive long periods without food - Hibernation-like states common during Csend - Quick metabolic bursts for predation/escape Size Patterns : - Large body size common (better heat retention) - Small species rare except in Middle Waters - Pack/herd behavior provides shared warmth
docs.title: Cold Adaptation

docs.text: Most fauna avoids Pattern Residue: Residue Sensitivity : - High concentrations cause stress, disorientation - Animals avoid death sites until Residue dissipates - Migration patterns route around high-Residue areas - Explains why polar regions lack megafauna (Residue too dense) Exceptions : - A few specialized species have evolved Residue tolerance - Some actually feed on or process Residue - These species are economically important (see below)
docs.title: Pattern Residue Interaction

docs.text: Iron Elk ( Vastúlszarvas ) - Massive cervid, shoulder height 2.5m - Antlers span up to 3m - Dense, shaggy coat (dark grey to black) - Migrates seasonally across temperate tundra - Primary prey species for large predators - Domesticated variant used as draft animal (smaller, more docile) Glacier Bear ( Jégmedve ) - Largest land predator in most regions - 3m at shoulder when standing - White to pale grey coat - Hunts anything it can catch - Mostly solitary - Feared and respected; hunting one is a cultural milestone Tundra Mammoth-Equivalent ( Gyapjasszörny ) - Woolly, elephant-like creature - Smaller than Earth mammoths (3m shoulder height) - Herds in interior plateau and Far Shelf tundra - Hunted for meat, hide, ivory-equivalent tusks - Some domestication attempts (limited success) Deepwater Leviathan ( Mélyviziátrém ) - Marine megafauna in Central Ocean - Size uncertain (rarely seen intact) - Hunted for oil, meat, bone - Dangerous prey—ships lost pursuing them - May be multiple species grouped under one name
docs.title: Megafauna

docs.text: The Ash Moth ( Hamuszita ) - Large moth (wingspan 30cm) - Attracted to Pattern Residue - Congregates at death sites - Appears to feed on or process ambient Residue - Presence indicates Residue concentration - Used by harvesters to locate deposits Residue Beetles ( Maradványbogár ) - Small beetle that burrows into Residue-rich soil - Concentrates Residue in its shell - Shells collected for alchemical use - Farming attempts ongoing (limited success) The Thermal Worm ( Hőféreg ) - Found in Vent Lands geothermal zones - Processes both Residue and thermal energy - Bodies are warm to the touch even after death - Used as portable heat sources (in containers) - One of the few creatures that thrives in high-Residue environments Fate Hounds ( Sorsebek ) - Canid species with unusual Pattern sensitivity - Can sense strong Sórscad patterns - Trained by Warden Order for tracking deviants - Wild packs avoid high-Residue areas - Domesticated individuals bond to handlers - Not actually "hounds"—name is traditional
docs.title: Residue-Interacting Species

docs.text: Spore Carriers - Various insects and small animals - Carry fungal spores as part of lifecycle - Some deliberately seek Colony hosts to infect - Ecosystem role unclear (possibly mutualistic with wild colonies) The Reef-Fungus Symbiosis - In Middle Waters, reef organisms and fungal networks intertwine - Neither can survive without the other - Creates hybrid structures that confuse biologists - Colony Cults consider these sacred
docs.title: Colony-Related Organisms

docs.text: Draft Elk ( Tehénszarvas ) - Domesticated Iron Elk variant - Smaller, calmer, bred for strength - Primary draft animal on mainland - Also milked (rich, fatty milk) - Cultural significance varies by region Ship Dogs ( Hajókutya ) - Medium-sized canid bred for ship work - Rat-catching, guarding, companionship - Webbed feet, water-resistant coat - Standard on Shattered Reaches vessels Furnace Birds ( Kemencemadár ) - Domesticated fowl - Lay eggs, eaten for meat - Kept inside during Csend (cannot survive deep cold) - Require heated housing in most regions Tunnel Pigs ( Alagutdisznó ) - Bred to survive underground - Fat reserves for lean times - Eat almost anything organic - Provide meat, fat, leather - Common in mining settlements
docs.title: Domesticated Animals

docs.text: Fungi are ubiquitous on Hálcova: - Decomposition in cold conditions requires specialized organisms - Fungi fill ecological niches that bacteria fill on warmer worlds - Many edible species (carefully distinguished from toxic ones) - Mycorrhizal networks connect forest ecosystems Colors : Unlike plants, fungi don't photosynthesize. They come in all colors—white, grey, brown, orange, blue, even bioluminescent.
docs.title: Natural Fungi

docs.text: The fungi used in Colony Summoning are related to but distinct from natural fungi: Key Differences : - Process Pattern Residue (natural fungi avoid it) - Form symbiotic bonds with hosts (natural fungi don't) - Store "patterns" of consumed organisms (natural fungi just decompose) - Respond to host will (natural fungi have no such interaction) Origins Unknown : - Did Colony fungi evolve naturally? - Were they engineered by ancient civilization? - Did they come from the Elsewhere? - Are they somehow related to the thing imprisoned at the southern pole? Ecological Role : - Wild Colony organisms exist (feral colonies) - They consume dead matter and grow - Without hosts, they can spread unpredictably - Some regions have "colony zones"—areas where wild colonies have established - These zones are dangerous and economically valuable
docs.title: The Colony Organisms

docs.text: Temperate Terrestrial : Vegetation (Blackwood, Bloodgrass) ↓ Primary Consumers (Elk herds, small grazers) ↓ Secondary Consumers (Wolf-equivalents, small predators) ↓ Apex Predators (Glacier Bears, human hunters) Marine : Phytoplankton-equivalent ↓ Small fish, filter feeders ↓ Medium fish, cephalopods ↓ Large fish, marine mammals ↓ Leviathans, human fishers
docs.title: Food Webs

docs.text: Csend (Winter) : - Most animals hibernate or reduce activity - Predators hunt weakened prey - Frozen carrion preserved for later consumption - Residue accumulates (less biological processing) Olvadás (Thaw) : - Awakening, breeding season begins - Disease spreads from thawed pathogens - Migratory species return - Residue releases from ice (flora and fauna respond) Láng (Summer) : - Peak activity, breeding, feeding - Maximum biomass - Predation intense (building reserves) - Residue at peak atmospheric concentration Hanyatlás (Decline) : - Preparation for winter - Migration begins - Final feeding push - Residue begins precipitating Köd (Veil) : - Animal behavior changes (affected by Elsewhere bleed) - Some species become aggressive - Some become docile, disoriented - Colony organisms highly active - Ash Moths swarm (Residue precipitation attracts them)
docs.title: Seasonal Cycles

docs.text: The Cycle : 1. Death releases Residue 2. Residue disperses into environment 3. Most organisms avoid, some process 4. Ash Moths, Residue Beetles concentrate it 5. Precipitation during cold seasons removes from atmosphere 6. Concentrated deposits form over time 7. Human harvesting or natural processing eventually cycles it The Imbalance : - Humans harvest Residue and burn it (removes it from ecosystem) - This should warm the world over time - But population death produces more Residue - Current equilibrium maintained by death rate matching harvest rate - If population grew without increased death, world might warm - If death rate spiked without harvest, world would cool further
docs.title: Pattern Residue Ecology

docs.text: Pack Runners ( Falkafutók ) - Wolf-equivalent that hunts in packs of 10-30 - Coordinate attacks with disturbing intelligence - Primarily prey on elk, will attack humans - Avoid settlements but waylay travelers Ice Stalkers ( Jégkúszó ) - Ambush predator in polar transition zones - White/grey coloration, nearly invisible on ice - Attacks from concealment - Primarily a threat to expeditions
docs.title: Predators

docs.text: Frost Vipers ( Fagyoskígyó ) - Cold-blooded snake that evolved antifreeze blood - Venom causes rapid hypothermia - Bites are often fatal without treatment - Found under snow, in burrows, anywhere dark Bitter Toads ( Keserűvarangy ) - Amphibian with toxic skin secretions - Causes severe illness if handled or eaten improperly - Some cultures prepare them as delicacy (carefully) - Toxin used in alchemy
docs.title: Venomous/Toxic

docs.text: Blood Gnats ( Vérszúnyog ) - Small biting insect - Emerges during Olvadás and Láng - Carries various blood-borne diseases - Flesh Shapers particularly vulnerable (blood smell attracts them) Spore Flies ( Spóralégy ) - Carries fungal spores (some harmful) - Can transmit colony infection (rarely) - Killed on sight near settlements - More common in Middle Waters
docs.title: Disease Vectors

docs.text: During the fifth season, some animals exhibit disturbing behaviors: Elsewhere-Touched : - Animals near the bleed zones may be influenced - Erratic behavior, ignoring normal instincts - Some become aggressive without provocation - Some become docile, staring at nothing - Physical changes reported (extra eyes, wrong number of limbs) - Usually die shortly after Köd ends - Bodies avoided—contamination risk
docs.title: Köd Phenomena

docs.text: Subsistence : - Fishing is primary protein source in coastal regions - Hunting supplements agriculture everywhere - Fur trade economically important - Whale-equivalent hunting for oil and materials Commercial : - Iron Elk ranching in temperate regions - Fish processing facilities in Shattered Reaches - Fur trading companies in Far Shelf - Residue creature harvesting (specialized industry)
docs.title: Hunting and Fishing

docs.text: Challenges : - Short growing season (Láng + parts of Olvadás/Hanyatlás) - Cold-resistant crops only - Heavy labor to prepare frozen ground - Residue-burning for greenhouse heat Crops : - Root vegetables (cold-resistant) - Hardy grains (low yield, essential) - Fungi cultivation (indoor, reliable) - Greenhouse crops (luxury, expensive) Middle Waters Advantage : - Longest growing season - Most diverse crops - Food exporter to other regions - Agricultural wealth drives political importance
docs.title: Agriculture

docs.text: Tensions : - Some species hunted toward scarcity - Residue creatures particularly pressured (economic value) - Colony zones expanding (ecosystem disruption) - Climate management affects habitat Management Attempts : - Hunting seasons in some regions - Protected zones (rarely enforced) - Domestication programs for threatened species - Colony zone containment (mixed success) Further documentation needed on: Specific species details, domestication history, regional ecological variation, Elsewhere-touched organism studies, marine ecosystem depth
docs.title: Conservation vs. Exploitation

docs.text: Hálcova: Geography and Continental Structure Overview Hálcova's landmasses are arranged around the habitable equatorial band, with two major continents and three significant landmasses forming five distinct regions. The geography tells a story—the Heartlands and Shattered Reaches were once a single continent, torn apart by some ancient catastrophe. The rift that separated them became the Narrow Sea. The Shattered Heartlands Theory The Evidence Looking at the coastlines, the relationship is obvious: - The ragged eastern coast of the Greater Continent matches the western edge of the Shattered Reaches - Rock formations, mineral deposits, and fossil-equivalents continue across the gap - The Narrow Sea is a flooded rift valley, not a true ocean basin - Ancient ruins exist on both sides with matching architectural styles What Happened Unknown. Theories include: - Geological catastrophe (natural rift) - The same event that caused the cooling - Deliberate separation (by whom? why?) - Elsewhere incursion that physically tore reality - The creation of the Loom requiring tremendous energy release The shattering is ancient—tens of thousands of years at minimum. But the mystery feeds religious interpretation, political claims, and treasure-hunting expeditions. The Greater Continent (The Heartlands) Shape and Structure A crescent-shaped landmass curving from northwest to southeast, with the concave side facing the Middle Waters. The curve creates a natural harbor effect for the entire southern coast. Dimensions : Roughly 4,000 km along the outer curve, 800-1,200 km wide at various points. Major Geographic Features The Spine Mountains ( Gerincláncz ) A mountain range running along the curve of the continent, roughly following the crescent's arc. This range: - Blocks polar winds from the interior - Creates a rain shadow effect (northern interior is dry and cold; southern coast receives moisture) - Contains the highest peaks on Hálcova - Rich in mineral deposits, including concentrated Pattern Residue veins Notable Peaks : - The Watcher ( Az Őrszem ): Highest peak, visible from the sea on clear days. Site of an ancient observatory, now a Loom relay station. - The Broken Tooth ( Törött Fog ): A collapsed peak, evidence of ancient volcanic activity or something else. Hollow Saints claim it marks where "fate cracked." - The Twins ( Az Ikrek ): Two peaks of nearly identical height, separated by a pass. The main land route between northern and southern Heartlands. The Interior Plateau ( Fennsík ) Behind the Spine, a vast elevated plateau stretches toward the northern ice. Characteristics: - Elevation: 1,500-2,000m above sea level - Climate: Cold, dry, windy - Vegetation: Hardy tundra grasses, black lichen, scattered dwarf trees - Population: Sparse—nomadic herders, mining settlements, Warden outposts - Pattern Residue: High concentration (ancient battlefield sites, unexcavated) The River Valleys Major rivers cut through the Spine from the interior, creating the primary population centers. The Five Rivers : 1. The Gold ( Aranyi ): Largest river, drains to the southeast coast. The capital region. 2. The Iron ( Vasalj ): Northern river, flows to the Narrow Sea. Industrial heartland. 3. The Silent ( Csendi ): Flows north, disappears under the ice cap. Sacred to Ancestor Speakers. 4. The Broken ( Törötti ): Western river, fragmented into multiple channels. Difficult to navigate. 5. The Vein ( Véna ): Southern river, reddish sediment. Flesh Shaper territory—the sediment is mineral, not blood, but the association stuck. The Southern Coast The concave inner coast facing the Middle Waters. Characteristics: - Climate: Mildest on the continent (warm current arrival) - Terrain: Rolling hills, river deltas, natural harbors - Population: Dense—major cities, agricultural land, trade ports - Loom Coverage: Maximum—the Great Node is here The Northern Edge Where the continent meets the ice cap. Characteristics: - Climate: Extreme—permanent ice within 100km - Terrain: Glacial, unstable, constantly shifting - Population: Minimal—extraction outposts, Warden stations, exiles - Köd Effects: Partial bleed zone during the fifth season Political Geography The Heartlands contain multiple political entities, but shared characteristics: - Orthodox faith dominant - Loom integration in governance - Recognition of the Great Node's authority (in religious matters at minimum) - Interconnected through the river valley trade networks Specific nations/kingdoms to be developed separately. The Shattered Reaches Shape and Structure The "missing piece" of the original continent, now fragmented into one large island-continent and hundreds of smaller islands. The western coast clearly shows where it once connected to the Heartlands. Main Island : Roughly 1,500 km north-south, 600 km east-west Island Chains : Extending another 1,000 km eastward in clusters Major Geographic Features The Matching Coast The western edge of the main island—steep cliffs, deep fjords, a mirror of the Heartlands' eastern ragged coast. Sailors navigating the Narrow Sea see both coasts and understand they're traveling through a wound. The Interior Highlands The main island's interior is mountainous—a continuation of the Spine, now separated. Characteristics: - Peaks lower than the Spine (erosion, or the separation lowered them) - Heavy precipitation (maritime climate) - Dense, dark forests in the valleys (black-barked conifers) - Fast rivers with short courses to the sea The Fracture Zone The eastern portion of the main island and the inner island chains show evidence of additional breaking—smaller rifts, sea-filled valleys, unstable geology. Theories: - Secondary breaks after the main separation - Ongoing geological instability - The pattern continues to crack - Elsewhere influence weakening material reality The Island Chains Hundreds of islands extending eastward: The Near Chains : Close to the main island, connected by sea ice during Csend. Large islands with permanent populations, small islands used seasonally. The Middle Chains : Further out, less connected. Independent communities, sometimes isolated for entire winters. Strong Ancestor Speaker traditions. The Far Chains : Scattered islands approaching the Far Water. Sparse population, expedition staging points, pirate havens. Maritime Character The Shattered Reaches are defined by the sea: - Every settlement is coastal or river-accessible - Naval power determines political influence - Fishing and sea-hunting are primary food sources - Shipbuilding is the prestige industry - Sea ice creates seasonal connectivity (Csend connects islands; Olvadás isolates them) Political Geography Fragmented by design: - No continental-scale political unity - City-states control mainland harbors - Island kingdoms vary in size from single-island to chain-spanning - Merchant leagues provide economic coherence across political divisions - The Orthodox church is present but not dominant The Middle Waters Shape and Structure An archipelago of volcanic islands straddling the equatorial band. The warmest region on Hálcova—the only place that never freezes. The Great Island : Central caldera island, roughly 200 km diameter Major Islands : 20-30 islands of significant size (50+ km) Minor Islands : Hundreds of smaller islands, atolls, and reef formations Major Geographic Features The Caldera ( The Eye ) The Great Island is the rim and interior of a dormant supervolcano. The caldera itself is partially flooded, creating a protected inner harbor of extraordinary value. Characteristics: - Caldera diameter: ~50 km - Rim elevation: 500-1,500m above sea level - Inner harbor: Deep, protected, warm - Geothermal activity: Hot springs, steam vents, warm ground - Köd protection: The caldera experiences almost no Elsewhere effects The Protection Mystery : Why is the caldera protected during Köd? Theories: - Geothermal energy disrupts the bleed - Ancient warding built into the volcanic structure - High life density anchors reality - Something in the caldera that Elsewhere avoids - Combination of factors The truth may involve ancient engineering—the caldera shows signs of modification that don't match natural formation. The Reef Systems Cold-adapted reef analogues (not coral—something else) surround many islands. Characteristics: - Built by colonial organisms adapted to cold water - Create protected lagoons and channels - Rich fishing grounds - Navigation hazards for unfamiliar sailors - Possible Pattern Residue interaction (the organisms may process it somehow) The Thermal Vents Underwater volcanic vents heat surrounding waters. Where these occur: - Water temperature is significantly higher - Unique ecosystems develop - Fog banks form (warm water meeting cold air) - Strategic value for winter fishing grounds Climate Advantage Why the Middle Waters stay warm: Latitude : Equatorial position receives maximum Sárgvas energy Volcanic heat : Geothermal contribution to ground and water temperature Ocean currents : Warm water pools here rather than flowing away quickly Köd protection : Less Pattern Residue precipitation during the strange season Unknown factor : The caldera's protection extends partially to surrounding islands Political Geography The most contested territory on Hálcova: - Every major power wants presence here - Colonial holdings, trading posts, military bases from multiple regions - Native island cultures caught between imperial interests - Colony Cults have significant influence (warm, wet conditions favor fungi) - Religious diversity—Orthodoxy present but not dominant The Vent Lands Shape and Structure A continental fragment in the southern hemisphere, defined by extreme volcanic activity. Smaller than the Heartlands but geologically intense. Dimensions : Roughly 1,200 km north-south, 800 km east-west Coastline : Irregular, with many peninsulas and deep bays Major Geographic Features The Fire Range ( Tűzlánc ) An active volcanic mountain chain running the length of the landmass. Characteristics: - 20+ active volcanoes - Continuous geothermal activity (hot springs, geysers, fumaroles) - Lava flows reshape geography on human timescales - Ash falls fertilize surrounding valleys - Toxic gas zones in low-lying areas The Thermal Valleys Protected valleys between volcanic ridges where geothermal heat creates habitable conditions. Characteristics: - Warm year-round (geothermal, not solar) - Lush vegetation (by Hálcova standards) - Dense population concentration - Natural hot water for bathing, cleaning, industrial processes - Some valleys toxic or unstable (constant monitoring required) The Steam Fields Where glaciers meet geothermal zones. Characteristics: - Constant steam and fog - Unstable footing (ice over warm ground) - Flash floods when ice dams break - Bizarre ice formations (frozen steam, thermal-sculpted glaciers) - Disorienting travel conditions The Sulfur Flats Lowland areas where volcanic gases concentrate. Characteristics: - Yellow-crusted ground (sulfur deposits) - Toxic air at ground level - Uninhabitable without protection - Valuable mineral extraction (sulfur, other volcanic minerals) - Worked by protected crews or homunculi Economic Advantage The Vent Lands don't need Pattern Residue for heat: - Geothermal energy provides heating, cooking, industrial power - Independence from the Residue trade network - Wealth from unique resources (volcanic minerals, geothermal-forged metals) - Political independence from Orthodox/Loom institutional pressure - Fleshwright traditions developed here (blood doesn't freeze; more experimentation possible) Political Geography Unified by geography rather than conquest: - Thermal valleys function as semi-independent city-states - Volcanic activity forces cooperation (warning systems, refugee support) - Trade federation rather than empire - Orthodoxy present but weaker (they need the Vent Lands more than reverse) - Fleshwright guilds have unusual legal status and power The Far Shelf Shape and Structure The most distant inhabited continent, in the southern hemisphere. Large, relatively flat, and cold. Dimensions : Roughly 2,000 km east-west, 1,500 km north-south Coastline : Long and exposed, few natural harbors Major Geographic Features The Shelf Proper The continent is a vast, low-elevation landmass—a continental shelf that barely rises above sea level in many areas. Characteristics: - Elevation: 0-500m over most of the landmass - Terrain: Flat to gently rolling - Drainage: Poor—marshes, bogs, seasonal lakes - Permafrost: Underlies most of the interior The Southern Ice Edge The continent's southern coast merges into the southern ice cap. Characteristics: - No clear boundary between land and ice - Glaciers extend from the cap across coastal regions - Ice cliffs along some stretches - Full Köd bleed zone The Mineral Ranges Low mountain ranges in the continental interior. Characteristics: - Rich ore deposits (iron, copper, rare metals) - Difficult extraction (permafrost, short work season) - Mining settlements operate seasonally or with heavy Residue-burning for heat - Tensions between extraction interests and indigenous populations The Tundra Most of the continental interior. Characteristics: - Black and purple vegetation mat (tundra grasses, lichens) - Migrating herd animals - Nomadic populations following herds - Long winters, brief intense summers - Less Loom coverage than any other inhabited region Frontier Character The Far Shelf is the edge of the known world: - Last region to be contacted/colonized - Still incompletely mapped in the interior - Indigenous populations with pre-Loom traditions - Threadist movements began here (distance from Orthodox center) - Hollow Saints operate more openly - Warden Order presence thin and stretched The Survival Paradox The Far Shelf is the poorest, coldest inhabited region—yet it maintains independence from Heartlands integration. How? Resource Leverage Beneath the permafrost lie significant deposits: - Iron and copper in the Mineral Ranges - Rare metals essential for pattern-engine construction - Concentrated Pattern Residue from ancient death sites (frozen, preserved, unharvested for millennia) - The largest untapped Residue reserves on Hálcova The Far Shelf can't efficiently extract these resources, but neither can anyone else—without local cooperation. This creates bargaining power: "You want our minerals? Accept our terms." Decentralization as Defense There's nothing to conquer: - No capital city to capture - No central government to overthrow - No concentrated population to subjugate - Thousands of scattered settlements across hostile terrain Military conquest would require permanent occupation of territory larger than the Heartlands, in worse conditions, against populations that can simply withdraw into the interior. The logistics are impossible. Population Hardiness Generations of survival have created people genuinely harder to control: - Cold tolerance that outlasts occupying forces - Subsistence skills that don't depend on trade - Social structures that function without centralized hierarchy - Willingness to accept suffering that breaks invaders Cost-Benefit Calculation The Heartlands have done the math: - Conquest cost: Astronomical (logistics, casualties, ongoing occupation) - Conquest benefit: Marginal (resources still hard to extract, resistance ongoing) - Trade cost: Accepting Far Shelf independence and heterodoxy - Trade benefit: Access to resources without occupation costs Trade wins. The Far Shelf remains independent not through military strength but through being more trouble than it's worth. Hollow Saint Theology The region's dominant religious framework reframes poverty as virtue: - Suffering proves you're escaping fate's prison - Material deprivation is spiritual liberation - The cold that kills is also the cold that frees - Independence from the Loom is worth any physical cost This ideology makes the population resistant to the carrots that work elsewhere. They don't want integration. They want to be left alone to suffer freely. Political Geography Fragmented and contested: - Coastal trading posts controlled by distant powers - Interior effectively independent (hard to project power into tundra) - Indigenous confederacies resist external control - Colonial tensions with Heartlands interests - Religious heterodoxy tolerated by necessity The Seas The Narrow Sea Location : Between the Heartlands (east coast) and Shattered Reaches (west coast) Character : A flooded rift valley—the wound where the continents separated Characteristics : - Width: 200-400 km at various points - Depth: Deep central channel (the original rift), shallow coastal shelves - Currents: Complex—warm water entering from south, cold from north - Ice: Partially freezes during Csend (creates ice roads between landfalls) - Traffic: The busiest sea route on Hálcova Navigation Hazards : - Ice floes during Csend/Olvadás - Fog banks where water temperatures differ - Tidal races in narrow passages - Submerged rocks (the rift left debris) Strategic Value : - Controls trade between two major regions - Historical site of naval conflicts - Chokepoints fortified on both sides - Whoever controls the Narrow Sea influences continental politics The Central Ocean Location : Between the northern landmasses and the southern (the gap in the middle of the ring) Character : The largest open ocean, surrounding the Middle Waters Characteristics : - Width: Variable—2,000+ km in places - Depth: Deep ocean basins - Currents: The Great Thermal Loop circulates here (warm from Middle Waters, cold returns from poles) - Ice: Center stays liquid even in Csend (thermal upwelling) - Traffic: Moderate—dangerous crossing but necessary for inter-regional trade Navigation Hazards : - Distance (no landfalls for long stretches) - Storms (thermal gradient creates weather) - Cold (outside the Middle Waters warmth) - The Central Deep (a region where depth makes vessels feel uneasy—possible Elsewhere bleed) The Vent Strait Location : Between the Middle Waters and the Vent Lands Character : A warm-water channel kept ice-free by geothermal activity Characteristics : - Width: 300-500 km - Depth: Moderate (volcanic seafloor) - Currents: Warm outflow from Vent Lands geothermal sources - Ice: Never freezes - Traffic: Heavy year-round Navigation Hazards : - Underwater volcanic activity (occasionally) - Dense fog (warm water, cold air) - Crowded shipping lanes - Piracy (year-round accessibility means year-round predation) The Far Water Location : Between the Shattered Reaches and the Far Shelf Character : The widest, coldest, most dangerous crossing Characteristics : - Width: 3,000+ km at minimum - Depth: Variable—some shallow banks, some deep trenches - Currents: Cold, flowing from the southern ice - Ice: Ice-free in central regions, but icebergs drift through - Traffic: Light—only when necessary Navigation Hazards : - Distance (the longest unsupported crossing) - Cold (requires heavy Residue-burning for heat) - Storms (nothing breaks them across this distance) - Icebergs (unpredictable, ship-killing) - Isolation (rescue is unlikely) The Bitter Crossing Location : Connecting the Heartlands and Far Shelf via polar route Character : Impassable except when frozen Characteristics : - Route: Curves north through near-polar waters - Summer: Impossible—ice pack, bergs, no continuous route - Csend: Freezes solid—becomes an ice road - Duration: 60+ days to cross on foot/sled The Ice Road : - Historical primary connection before long-distance sailing - Still used for heavy cargo that can't risk sea voyage - Operates only during Csend (narrow window) - Crosses partial Köd bleed zone—travelers must finish before the fifth season - Warden outposts along the route (for safety and monitoring) The Polar Regions The Northern Cap Extent : Everything north of approximately 70° latitude equivalent Characteristics : - Permanent ice sheet (3-4 km thick in center) - No permanent human habitation in deep polar zone - Transition zone (ice edge to permanent ice) is seasonally accessible - Full Köd bleed during the fifth season What's There : - Ice - Concentrated Pattern Residue (ancient, unharvested) - Ruins under the ice (confirmed by expeditions) - Creatures adapted to extreme cold (rare, dangerous) - Something else (see: Polar Mystery) The Southern Cap Extent : Everything south of approximately 65° latitude equivalent (extends further north due to continental anchoring by the Far Shelf) Characteristics : - Permanent ice sheet (thinner than northern, 1-2 km) - Merges with the Far Shelf's southern coast - Slightly more accessible (land connection) - Full Köd bleed during the fifth season - Different character from the northern cap (see: Polar Mystery) What's There : - Ice - The Shelf's southern glaciers - Mineral deposits (inaccessible) - Something different from the north (see: Polar Mystery) The Polar Mystery The Core Truth : The two poles are not the same. The Northern Cap: The Wound - This is where the Elsewhere connects to Hálcova - The Köd bleed isn't entities "breaking through"—it's leakage from a permanent connection - The ice and cold may be natural, or may be attempting to seal/slow the leakage - Ancient ruins here may be from a civilization that understood the connection (and failed to close it) The Southern Cap: The Prison - Something is contained here - The Pattern Residue concentration is higher than it should be (deliberate accumulation) - The cold is more engineered than natural - Ancient structures here appear designed to hold, not to live - Whatever is contained was put there by someone who understood both the Elsewhere and the Loom The Implications : - Expeditions to the north find evidence of contact with the Elsewhere - Expeditions to the south find evidence of imprisonment - Very few people know both truths - The relationship between the wound and the prisoner is unclear (did one cause the other? are they related entities? is the prisoner there to guard the wound?) Ocean Currents: The Great Thermal Loop The System Water circulation in Hálcova's oceans follows a pattern shaped by temperature gradients, weak Coriolis effect, and geothermal sources. Surface Currents (Warm) The Middle Flow : - Warm water pools in the Middle Waters (equatorial heating + volcanic) - Surface flow moves north and south toward poles - Carries heat, moderating coastal temperatures - Provides moisture for precipitation - Supports marine life migration patterns Regional Branches : Southern Heartlands Current : Warm water reaches the Heartlands' concave coast, making it the mildest continental region. This is why civilization centered here first. Vent Lands Branch : Warm current meets geothermal outflow, creating exceptionally warm waters in the Vent Strait. Year-round ice-free, rich fishing. Shattered Reaches Split : Current divides around the main island. Western branch keeps inner channels warmer. Eastern branch cools quickly, making far islands colder. Far Shelf Failure : Current disperses before reaching the Far Shelf. No warm water arrives. Coldest coasts. Deep Currents (Cold) The Return Flow : - Surface water cools as it moves poleward - Cold water sinks at high latitudes - Deep current returns toward equator - Upwells in certain zones, bringing nutrients Regional Effects : The Northern Heartlands Coast : Cold return current makes these waters harsh. Fishing is dangerous but productive (nutrient-rich upwelling). The Central Deep Upwelling : Where cold water rises in the Central Ocean. Rich fishing, but far from land. Creates the "uneasy" zone where vessels feel observed. The Vent Upwelling : Where geothermal heat meets cold deep water. Massive nutrient concentration. The richest fishing grounds on Hálcova. Fog-shrouded, difficult to navigate. Seasonal Variations Láng (Summer) : - Surface currents strongest (maximum heating) - Ice retreat reveals more ocean surface - Trade routes fully open - Fish populations migrate with warm water Csend (Winter) : - Surface currents weakest - Ice formation begins at high latitudes - Currents may shift as ice blocks normal flows - Some routes become impassable Olvadás (Thaw) : - Meltwater influx disrupts currents - Unpredictable flows - Dangerous for shipping (currents don't follow normal patterns) - Rich nutrient release from melting ice Further documentation needed on: Specific coastline details, exact current speeds and patterns, submarine geology, maritime culture and technology
docs.title: Geography

docs.text: Hálcova's landmasses are arranged around the habitable equatorial band, with two major continents and three significant landmasses forming five distinct regions. The geography tells a story—the Heartlands and Shattered Reaches were once a single continent, torn apart by some ancient catastrophe. The rift that separated them became the Narrow Sea.
docs.title: Overview

docs.text: Looking at the coastlines, the relationship is obvious: - The ragged eastern coast of the Greater Continent matches the western edge of the Shattered Reaches - Rock formations, mineral deposits, and fossil-equivalents continue across the gap - The Narrow Sea is a flooded rift valley, not a true ocean basin - Ancient ruins exist on both sides with matching architectural styles
docs.title: The Evidence

docs.text: Unknown. Theories include: - Geological catastrophe (natural rift) - The same event that caused the cooling - Deliberate separation (by whom? why?) - Elsewhere incursion that physically tore reality - The creation of the Loom requiring tremendous energy release The shattering is ancient—tens of thousands of years at minimum. But the mystery feeds religious interpretation, political claims, and treasure-hunting expeditions.
docs.title: What Happened

docs.text: A crescent-shaped landmass curving from northwest to southeast, with the concave side facing the Middle Waters. The curve creates a natural harbor effect for the entire southern coast. Dimensions : Roughly 4,000 km along the outer curve, 800-1,200 km wide at various points.
docs.title: Shape and Structure

docs.text: The Spine Mountains ( Gerincláncz ) A mountain range running along the curve of the continent, roughly following the crescent's arc. This range: - Blocks polar winds from the interior - Creates a rain shadow effect (northern interior is dry and cold; southern coast receives moisture) - Contains the highest peaks on Hálcova - Rich in mineral deposits, including concentrated Pattern Residue veins Notable Peaks : - The Watcher ( Az Őrszem ): Highest peak, visible from the sea on clear days. Site of an ancient observatory, now a Loom relay station. - The Broken Tooth ( Törött Fog ): A collapsed peak, evidence of ancient volcanic activity or something else. Hollow Saints claim it marks where "fate cracked." - The Twins ( Az Ikrek ): Two peaks of nearly identical height, separated by a pass. The main land route between northern and southern Heartlands. The Interior Plateau ( Fennsík ) Behind the Spine, a vast elevated plateau stretches toward the northern ice. Characteristics: - Elevation: 1,500-2,000m above sea level - Climate: Cold, dry, windy - Vegetation: Hardy tundra grasses, black lichen, scattered dwarf trees - Population: Sparse—nomadic herders, mining settlements, Warden outposts - Pattern Residue: High concentration (ancient battlefield sites, unexcavated) The River Valleys Major rivers cut through the Spine from the interior, creating the primary population centers. The Five Rivers : 1. The Gold ( Aranyi ): Largest river, drains to the southeast coast. The capital region. 2. The Iron ( Vasalj ): Northern river, flows to the Narrow Sea. Industrial heartland. 3. The Silent ( Csendi ): Flows north, disappears under the ice cap. Sacred to Ancestor Speakers. 4. The Broken ( Törötti ): Western river, fragmented into multiple channels. Difficult to navigate. 5. The Vein ( Véna ): Southern river, reddish sediment. Flesh Shaper territory—the sediment is mineral, not blood, but the association stuck. The Southern Coast The concave inner coast facing the Middle Waters. Characteristics: - Climate: Mildest on the continent (warm current arrival) - Terrain: Rolling hills, river deltas, natural harbors - Population: Dense—major cities, agricultural land, trade ports - Loom Coverage: Maximum—the Great Node is here The Northern Edge Where the continent meets the ice cap. Characteristics: - Climate: Extreme—permanent ice within 100km - Terrain: Glacial, unstable, constantly shifting - Population: Minimal—extraction outposts, Warden stations, exiles - Köd Effects: Partial bleed zone during the fifth season
docs.title: Major Geographic Features

docs.text: The Heartlands contain multiple political entities, but shared characteristics: - Orthodox faith dominant - Loom integration in governance - Recognition of the Great Node's authority (in religious matters at minimum) - Interconnected through the river valley trade networks Specific nations/kingdoms to be developed separately.
docs.title: Political Geography

docs.text: The "missing piece" of the original continent, now fragmented into one large island-continent and hundreds of smaller islands. The western coast clearly shows where it once connected to the Heartlands. Main Island : Roughly 1,500 km north-south, 600 km east-west Island Chains : Extending another 1,000 km eastward in clusters
docs.title: Shape and Structure

docs.text: The Matching Coast The western edge of the main island—steep cliffs, deep fjords, a mirror of the Heartlands' eastern ragged coast. Sailors navigating the Narrow Sea see both coasts and understand they're traveling through a wound. The Interior Highlands The main island's interior is mountainous—a continuation of the Spine, now separated. Characteristics: - Peaks lower than the Spine (erosion, or the separation lowered them) - Heavy precipitation (maritime climate) - Dense, dark forests in the valleys (black-barked conifers) - Fast rivers with short courses to the sea The Fracture Zone The eastern portion of the main island and the inner island chains show evidence of additional breaking—smaller rifts, sea-filled valleys, unstable geology. Theories: - Secondary breaks after the main separation - Ongoing geological instability - The pattern continues to crack - Elsewhere influence weakening material reality The Island Chains Hundreds of islands extending eastward: The Near Chains : Close to the main island, connected by sea ice during Csend. Large islands with permanent populations, small islands used seasonally. The Middle Chains : Further out, less connected. Independent communities, sometimes isolated for entire winters. Strong Ancestor Speaker traditions. The Far Chains : Scattered islands approaching the Far Water. Sparse population, expedition staging points, pirate havens.
docs.title: Major Geographic Features

docs.text: The Shattered Reaches are defined by the sea: - Every settlement is coastal or river-accessible - Naval power determines political influence - Fishing and sea-hunting are primary food sources - Shipbuilding is the prestige industry - Sea ice creates seasonal connectivity (Csend connects islands; Olvadás isolates them)
docs.title: Maritime Character

docs.text: Fragmented by design: - No continental-scale political unity - City-states control mainland harbors - Island kingdoms vary in size from single-island to chain-spanning - Merchant leagues provide economic coherence across political divisions - The Orthodox church is present but not dominant
docs.title: Political Geography

docs.text: An archipelago of volcanic islands straddling the equatorial band. The warmest region on Hálcova—the only place that never freezes. The Great Island : Central caldera island, roughly 200 km diameter Major Islands : 20-30 islands of significant size (50+ km) Minor Islands : Hundreds of smaller islands, atolls, and reef formations
docs.title: Shape and Structure

docs.text: The Caldera ( The Eye ) The Great Island is the rim and interior of a dormant supervolcano. The caldera itself is partially flooded, creating a protected inner harbor of extraordinary value. Characteristics: - Caldera diameter: ~50 km - Rim elevation: 500-1,500m above sea level - Inner harbor: Deep, protected, warm - Geothermal activity: Hot springs, steam vents, warm ground - Köd protection: The caldera experiences almost no Elsewhere effects The Protection Mystery : Why is the caldera protected during Köd? Theories: - Geothermal energy disrupts the bleed - Ancient warding built into the volcanic structure - High life density anchors reality - Something in the caldera that Elsewhere avoids - Combination of factors The truth may involve ancient engineering—the caldera shows signs of modification that don't match natural formation. The Reef Systems Cold-adapted reef analogues (not coral—something else) surround many islands. Characteristics: - Built by colonial organisms adapted to cold water - Create protected lagoons and channels - Rich fishing grounds - Navigation hazards for unfamiliar sailors - Possible Pattern Residue interaction (the organisms may process it somehow) The Thermal Vents Underwater volcanic vents heat surrounding waters. Where these occur: - Water temperature is significantly higher - Unique ecosystems develop - Fog banks form (warm water meeting cold air) - Strategic value for winter fishing grounds
docs.title: Major Geographic Features

docs.text: Why the Middle Waters stay warm: Latitude : Equatorial position receives maximum Sárgvas energy Volcanic heat : Geothermal contribution to ground and water temperature Ocean currents : Warm water pools here rather than flowing away quickly Köd protection : Less Pattern Residue precipitation during the strange season Unknown factor : The caldera's protection extends partially to surrounding islands
docs.title: Climate Advantage

docs.text: The most contested territory on Hálcova: - Every major power wants presence here - Colonial holdings, trading posts, military bases from multiple regions - Native island cultures caught between imperial interests - Colony Cults have significant influence (warm, wet conditions favor fungi) - Religious diversity—Orthodoxy present but not dominant
docs.title: Political Geography

docs.text: A continental fragment in the southern hemisphere, defined by extreme volcanic activity. Smaller than the Heartlands but geologically intense. Dimensions : Roughly 1,200 km north-south, 800 km east-west Coastline : Irregular, with many peninsulas and deep bays
docs.title: Shape and Structure

docs.text: The Fire Range ( Tűzlánc ) An active volcanic mountain chain running the length of the landmass. Characteristics: - 20+ active volcanoes - Continuous geothermal activity (hot springs, geysers, fumaroles) - Lava flows reshape geography on human timescales - Ash falls fertilize surrounding valleys - Toxic gas zones in low-lying areas The Thermal Valleys Protected valleys between volcanic ridges where geothermal heat creates habitable conditions. Characteristics: - Warm year-round (geothermal, not solar) - Lush vegetation (by Hálcova standards) - Dense population concentration - Natural hot water for bathing, cleaning, industrial processes - Some valleys toxic or unstable (constant monitoring required) The Steam Fields Where glaciers meet geothermal zones. Characteristics: - Constant steam and fog - Unstable footing (ice over warm ground) - Flash floods when ice dams break - Bizarre ice formations (frozen steam, thermal-sculpted glaciers) - Disorienting travel conditions The Sulfur Flats Lowland areas where volcanic gases concentrate. Characteristics: - Yellow-crusted ground (sulfur deposits) - Toxic air at ground level - Uninhabitable without protection - Valuable mineral extraction (sulfur, other volcanic minerals) - Worked by protected crews or homunculi
docs.title: Major Geographic Features

docs.text: The Vent Lands don't need Pattern Residue for heat: - Geothermal energy provides heating, cooking, industrial power - Independence from the Residue trade network - Wealth from unique resources (volcanic minerals, geothermal-forged metals) - Political independence from Orthodox/Loom institutional pressure - Fleshwright traditions developed here (blood doesn't freeze; more experimentation possible)
docs.title: Economic Advantage

docs.text: Unified by geography rather than conquest: - Thermal valleys function as semi-independent city-states - Volcanic activity forces cooperation (warning systems, refugee support) - Trade federation rather than empire - Orthodoxy present but weaker (they need the Vent Lands more than reverse) - Fleshwright guilds have unusual legal status and power
docs.title: Political Geography

docs.text: The most distant inhabited continent, in the southern hemisphere. Large, relatively flat, and cold. Dimensions : Roughly 2,000 km east-west, 1,500 km north-south Coastline : Long and exposed, few natural harbors
docs.title: Shape and Structure

docs.text: The Shelf Proper The continent is a vast, low-elevation landmass—a continental shelf that barely rises above sea level in many areas. Characteristics: - Elevation: 0-500m over most of the landmass - Terrain: Flat to gently rolling - Drainage: Poor—marshes, bogs, seasonal lakes - Permafrost: Underlies most of the interior The Southern Ice Edge The continent's southern coast merges into the southern ice cap. Characteristics: - No clear boundary between land and ice - Glaciers extend from the cap across coastal regions - Ice cliffs along some stretches - Full Köd bleed zone The Mineral Ranges Low mountain ranges in the continental interior. Characteristics: - Rich ore deposits (iron, copper, rare metals) - Difficult extraction (permafrost, short work season) - Mining settlements operate seasonally or with heavy Residue-burning for heat - Tensions between extraction interests and indigenous populations The Tundra Most of the continental interior. Characteristics: - Black and purple vegetation mat (tundra grasses, lichens) - Migrating herd animals - Nomadic populations following herds - Long winters, brief intense summers - Less Loom coverage than any other inhabited region
docs.title: Major Geographic Features

docs.text: The Far Shelf is the edge of the known world: - Last region to be contacted/colonized - Still incompletely mapped in the interior - Indigenous populations with pre-Loom traditions - Threadist movements began here (distance from Orthodox center) - Hollow Saints operate more openly - Warden Order presence thin and stretched
docs.title: Frontier Character

docs.text: The Far Shelf is the poorest, coldest inhabited region—yet it maintains independence from Heartlands integration. How? Resource Leverage Beneath the permafrost lie significant deposits: - Iron and copper in the Mineral Ranges - Rare metals essential for pattern-engine construction - Concentrated Pattern Residue from ancient death sites (frozen, preserved, unharvested for millennia) - The largest untapped Residue reserves on Hálcova The Far Shelf can't efficiently extract these resources, but neither can anyone else—without local cooperation. This creates bargaining power: "You want our minerals? Accept our terms." Decentralization as Defense There's nothing to conquer: - No capital city to capture - No central government to overthrow - No concentrated population to subjugate - Thousands of scattered settlements across hostile terrain Military conquest would require permanent occupation of territory larger than the Heartlands, in worse conditions, against populations that can simply withdraw into the interior. The logistics are impossible. Population Hardiness Generations of survival have created people genuinely harder to control: - Cold tolerance that outlasts occupying forces - Subsistence skills that don't depend on trade - Social structures that function without centralized hierarchy - Willingness to accept suffering that breaks invaders Cost-Benefit Calculation The Heartlands have done the math: - Conquest cost: Astronomical (logistics, casualties, ongoing occupation) - Conquest benefit: Marginal (resources still hard to extract, resistance ongoing) - Trade cost: Accepting Far Shelf independence and heterodoxy - Trade benefit: Access to resources without occupation costs Trade wins. The Far Shelf remains independent not through military strength but through being more trouble than it's worth. Hollow Saint Theology The region's dominant religious framework reframes poverty as virtue: - Suffering proves you're escaping fate's prison - Material deprivation is spiritual liberation - The cold that kills is also the cold that frees - Independence from the Loom is worth any physical cost This ideology makes the population resistant to the carrots that work elsewhere. They don't want integration. They want to be left alone to suffer freely.
docs.title: The Survival Paradox

docs.text: Fragmented and contested: - Coastal trading posts controlled by distant powers - Interior effectively independent (hard to project power into tundra) - Indigenous confederacies resist external control - Colonial tensions with Heartlands interests - Religious heterodoxy tolerated by necessity
docs.title: Political Geography

docs.text: Location : Between the Heartlands (east coast) and Shattered Reaches (west coast) Character : A flooded rift valley—the wound where the continents separated Characteristics : - Width: 200-400 km at various points - Depth: Deep central channel (the original rift), shallow coastal shelves - Currents: Complex—warm water entering from south, cold from north - Ice: Partially freezes during Csend (creates ice roads between landfalls) - Traffic: The busiest sea route on Hálcova Navigation Hazards : - Ice floes during Csend/Olvadás - Fog banks where water temperatures differ - Tidal races in narrow passages - Submerged rocks (the rift left debris) Strategic Value : - Controls trade between two major regions - Historical site of naval conflicts - Chokepoints fortified on both sides - Whoever controls the Narrow Sea influences continental politics
docs.title: The Narrow Sea

docs.text: Location : Between the northern landmasses and the southern (the gap in the middle of the ring) Character : The largest open ocean, surrounding the Middle Waters Characteristics : - Width: Variable—2,000+ km in places - Depth: Deep ocean basins - Currents: The Great Thermal Loop circulates here (warm from Middle Waters, cold returns from poles) - Ice: Center stays liquid even in Csend (thermal upwelling) - Traffic: Moderate—dangerous crossing but necessary for inter-regional trade Navigation Hazards : - Distance (no landfalls for long stretches) - Storms (thermal gradient creates weather) - Cold (outside the Middle Waters warmth) - The Central Deep (a region where depth makes vessels feel uneasy—possible Elsewhere bleed)
docs.title: The Central Ocean

docs.text: Location : Between the Middle Waters and the Vent Lands Character : A warm-water channel kept ice-free by geothermal activity Characteristics : - Width: 300-500 km - Depth: Moderate (volcanic seafloor) - Currents: Warm outflow from Vent Lands geothermal sources - Ice: Never freezes - Traffic: Heavy year-round Navigation Hazards : - Underwater volcanic activity (occasionally) - Dense fog (warm water, cold air) - Crowded shipping lanes - Piracy (year-round accessibility means year-round predation)
docs.title: The Vent Strait

docs.text: Location : Between the Shattered Reaches and the Far Shelf Character : The widest, coldest, most dangerous crossing Characteristics : - Width: 3,000+ km at minimum - Depth: Variable—some shallow banks, some deep trenches - Currents: Cold, flowing from the southern ice - Ice: Ice-free in central regions, but icebergs drift through - Traffic: Light—only when necessary Navigation Hazards : - Distance (the longest unsupported crossing) - Cold (requires heavy Residue-burning for heat) - Storms (nothing breaks them across this distance) - Icebergs (unpredictable, ship-killing) - Isolation (rescue is unlikely)
docs.title: The Far Water

docs.text: Location : Connecting the Heartlands and Far Shelf via polar route Character : Impassable except when frozen Characteristics : - Route: Curves north through near-polar waters - Summer: Impossible—ice pack, bergs, no continuous route - Csend: Freezes solid—becomes an ice road - Duration: 60+ days to cross on foot/sled The Ice Road : - Historical primary connection before long-distance sailing - Still used for heavy cargo that can't risk sea voyage - Operates only during Csend (narrow window) - Crosses partial Köd bleed zone—travelers must finish before the fifth season - Warden outposts along the route (for safety and monitoring)
docs.title: The Bitter Crossing

docs.text: Extent : Everything north of approximately 70° latitude equivalent Characteristics : - Permanent ice sheet (3-4 km thick in center) - No permanent human habitation in deep polar zone - Transition zone (ice edge to permanent ice) is seasonally accessible - Full Köd bleed during the fifth season What's There : - Ice - Concentrated Pattern Residue (ancient, unharvested) - Ruins under the ice (confirmed by expeditions) - Creatures adapted to extreme cold (rare, dangerous) - Something else (see: Polar Mystery)
docs.title: The Northern Cap

docs.text: Extent : Everything south of approximately 65° latitude equivalent (extends further north due to continental anchoring by the Far Shelf) Characteristics : - Permanent ice sheet (thinner than northern, 1-2 km) - Merges with the Far Shelf's southern coast - Slightly more accessible (land connection) - Full Köd bleed during the fifth season - Different character from the northern cap (see: Polar Mystery) What's There : - Ice - The Shelf's southern glaciers - Mineral deposits (inaccessible) - Something different from the north (see: Polar Mystery)
docs.title: The Southern Cap

docs.text: The Core Truth : The two poles are not the same. The Northern Cap: The Wound - This is where the Elsewhere connects to Hálcova - The Köd bleed isn't entities "breaking through"—it's leakage from a permanent connection - The ice and cold may be natural, or may be attempting to seal/slow the leakage - Ancient ruins here may be from a civilization that understood the connection (and failed to close it) The Southern Cap: The Prison - Something is contained here - The Pattern Residue concentration is higher than it should be (deliberate accumulation) - The cold is more engineered than natural - Ancient structures here appear designed to hold, not to live - Whatever is contained was put there by someone who understood both the Elsewhere and the Loom The Implications : - Expeditions to the north find evidence of contact with the Elsewhere - Expeditions to the south find evidence of imprisonment - Very few people know both truths - The relationship between the wound and the prisoner is unclear (did one cause the other? are they related entities? is the prisoner there to guard the wound?)
docs.title: The Polar Mystery
Ocean Currents: The Great Thermal Loop

docs.text: Water circulation in Hálcova's oceans follows a pattern shaped by temperature gradients, weak Coriolis effect, and geothermal sources.
docs.title: The System

docs.text: The Middle Flow : - Warm water pools in the Middle Waters (equatorial heating + volcanic) - Surface flow moves north and south toward poles - Carries heat, moderating coastal temperatures - Provides moisture for precipitation - Supports marine life migration patterns Regional Branches : Southern Heartlands Current : Warm water reaches the Heartlands' concave coast, making it the mildest continental region. This is why civilization centered here first. Vent Lands Branch : Warm current meets geothermal outflow, creating exceptionally warm waters in the Vent Strait. Year-round ice-free, rich fishing. Shattered Reaches Split : Current divides around the main island. Western branch keeps inner channels warmer. Eastern branch cools quickly, making far islands colder. Far Shelf Failure : Current disperses before reaching the Far Shelf. No warm water arrives. Coldest coasts.
docs.title: Surface Currents (Warm)

docs.text: The Return Flow : - Surface water cools as it moves poleward - Cold water sinks at high latitudes - Deep current returns toward equator - Upwells in certain zones, bringing nutrients Regional Effects : The Northern Heartlands Coast : Cold return current makes these waters harsh. Fishing is dangerous but productive (nutrient-rich upwelling). The Central Deep Upwelling : Where cold water rises in the Central Ocean. Rich fishing, but far from land. Creates the "uneasy" zone where vessels feel observed. The Vent Upwelling : Where geothermal heat meets cold deep water. Massive nutrient concentration. The richest fishing grounds on Hálcova. Fog-shrouded, difficult to navigate.
