The legitimate Consortium's economic power and political influence shield members from prosecution. Internal discipline handles problems without external investigation. Even Wardens hesitate to pursue cases against Consortium members with powerful allies. This protection is not absolute—egregious violations can trigger response, and enemies within the Consortium may use Shadow activities against rivals. But the margin for misconduct is substantially wider than that enjoyed by ordinary criminals.
docs.title: The Consortium's Shadow (Vent Lands)

docs.text: Contraband movement constitutes the largest criminal activity by economic volume. Goods Smuggled Threadist texts and other prohibited materials enter Hálcova through Reaches ports, hidden in legitimate cargo or carried by dedicated smuggling vessels. Distribution networks move materials to final consumers. Illegal Elsewhere artifacts—objects created through or affected by Elsewhere contact—command high prices among collectors and practitioners seeking power outside official channels. Most such "artifacts" are frauds; genuine items are extraordinarily rare and dangerous. Untaxed luxury goods avoid Crown duties that add 20-40% to legitimate prices. Wine, fine textiles, exotic foods, and quality metalwork all move through smuggling channels. Restricted substances—drugs derived from Elsewhere-touched plants, compounds with magical properties, addictive materials prohibited for social control—reach consumers through smuggling networks. Human Smuggling Pattern-fugitives fleeing Correction or constrained labor seek passage to safety. Smugglers charge 1,000-10,000 marks depending on risk and destination. Success rates vary; captured fugitives face execution, captured smugglers face severe punishment. Illegal immigration—people seeking to enter Hálcova or move between regions without documentation—uses similar channels at lower prices. The slave trade, officially abolished throughout Hálcova, persists through criminal networks. Victims include war captives from border conflicts, debtors sold by creditors, and kidnapping victims. Slaves move through the same channels as other contraband.
docs.title: Smuggling

docs.text: Crimes against the pattern system carry extraordinary penalties and generate extraordinary profits. Certificate Forgery Quality pattern-certificate forgery requires specialized skills: knowledge of official document formats, access to appropriate materials, ability to create convincing verification marks. Professional forgers charge 500-5,000 marks per certificate; amateurs produce documents likely to fail inspection. Detection rates for quality forgeries remain low—perhaps 10-20% of forged certificates eventually trigger investigation. The penalty for both forger and user is execution, creating strong incentive for quality work and careful use. Pattern-Reading Fraud Fraudulent fortune-tellers claim ability to perceive pattern information they cannot actually access. This crime against both individual victims and pattern system integrity carries Correction as standard penalty. More sophisticated fraud involves false interpretation of genuine pattern information—readers who can perceive patterns but deliberately misinterpret them for profit. Detection is nearly impossible without catching the fraudster in explicit deception. Loom Manipulation Attempts Attempts to manipulate the Loom itself—to alter fate rather than merely predict it—constitute the most serious pattern-crime. Success is extraordinarily rare; most attempts produce no effect, trigger dangerous backlash, or attract Warden attention. Those caught attempting Loom manipulation face execution after extensive interrogation. The possibility of actual Loom manipulation drives both criminal enterprise and enforcement intensity. If fate itself could be bought, current social order becomes meaningless. This existential threat justifies extreme measures.
docs.title: Pattern-Crimes

docs.text: The darkest criminal enterprise on Hálcova: acquiring pattern-weighted individuals for pact substitution. The Market Demand Pact Summoners owe entities payment in pattern-weight. They can pay with their own cores, or they can substitute others. Entities don't care whose pattern they consume—only that it has sufficient weight. This creates demand for heavy patterns that far exceeds voluntary supply. The wealthy don't sell themselves. The desperate poor have light patterns. The gap between demand and willing supply is filled by coercion. Procurement Methods Kidnapping Operations : Organized crews identify heavy-pattern individuals (the pattern-privileged, successful merchants, minor nobility) and abduct them. Targets are held in secure locations until sold to entity-brokers. A successful kidnapping operation might net 10,000-50,000 marks for a truly heavy pattern. Security details exist specifically to prevent this. Some security personnel have been known to turn on their employers when the price is right. Debt Conversion : When pattern-privileged individuals fall into debt, creditors sometimes accept substitution rights as collateral. If the debt isn't repaid, the creditor can sell those rights. This is legal in most jurisdictions—a debt is a debt. Criminal organizations purchase distressed debt specifically to acquire substitution rights. Family Sales : Some families sell members—usually younger children with heavy patterns, spare heirs, or disgraced relatives. Gray-market in most jurisdictions, openly legal in a few. Brokers specialize in facilitating these transactions, providing discretion and documentation. Death Row Speculation : Condemned criminals' patterns become state property. The state auctions substitution rights for serious crimes. Speculators buy these rights and resell to summoners. Heavy-pattern criminals are worth more than light-pattern ones—creating incentives to ensure heavy-pattern individuals commit capital crimes. The Broker Networks Specialized intermediaries connect supply and demand: Matchmakers : Identify summoners with approaching payment deadlines and match them with available substitutes. Charge 10-20% of transaction value. Holders : Maintain secure facilities where kidnapped individuals are held pending sale. Charge per-day fees plus percentage of eventual sale. Transporters : Move substitutes from procurement to holding to final delivery. Critical for maintaining chain of custody and preventing escape or rescue. Legitimizers : Produce documentation making coerced substitution appear voluntary. Forged consent documents, fabricated debt records, falsified family authorization. Pricing Substitution prices reflect procurement difficulty, not pattern-weight alone: Category Typical Price Notes Light pattern, voluntary 50-500 marks Abundant supply, limited demand Medium pattern, voluntary 500-2,000 marks Some demand for routine pacts Medium pattern, coerced 2,000-5,000 marks Procurement costs included Heavy pattern, coerced 5,000-20,000 marks Significant risk premium Exceptional pattern 20,000-100,000 marks Rare, dangerous acquisition Law Enforcement Substitution trafficking occupies a legal gray zone: Voluntary substitution is legal (if documented) Kidnapping is illegal, but proving the connection to substitution is difficult Debt conversion is legal (contract law) Family sales vary by jurisdiction Entities don't testify about where their patterns came from Wardens investigate pattern-trafficking when it intersects their mandate—forced substitution violates pattern-integrity. But enforcement is selective. Heavy resources go to protecting the pattern-privileged; pattern-constrained victims receive less attention. The Silk Threads operate procurement networks in Fonvárs. The Coral Syndicate moves substitutes between regions. Even the Consortium's Shadow engages in body trafficking that sometimes ends in substitution rather than modified slavery. The Moral Horror This is a literal soul trade. The purchased individual will have their core consumed by an Elsewhere entity. They will die without residue, without the possibility of echo-binding, without any continuation. They will simply cease. And yet the market exists because the demand exists because pacts exist because Elsewhere exists. The horror isn't that evil people do evil things—it's that the system creates the incentives and the transactions follow.
docs.title: Soul Procurement and Substitution Trafficking

docs.text: Criminal violence ranges from individual attacks to organized warfare. Contract Killing Professional killers available through criminal networks charge rates based on target difficulty. A vulnerable pattern-constrained individual might cost 100-500 marks. A protected merchant costs 1,000-5,000 marks. A minor noble or official costs 5,000-15,000 marks. Killing a major figure—high noble, senior Church official, prominent Warden—requires 20,000+ marks and may simply be refused as too dangerous. Success rates for professional killers exceed 80% for accessible targets, dropping significantly for protected individuals. Investigation intensity following killings varies with victim status—pattern-constrained deaths often go uninvestigated. Protection Violence Criminal organizations maintain territory through demonstrated willingness to use violence. Businesses that refuse protection payments suffer arson, assault, or destruction of goods. Rival criminals who encroach on territory face assault, maiming, or death. This violence is usually instrumental rather than sadistic—enough to establish credibility, not so much as to trigger authority response. The most successful criminal organizations minimize violence while maximizing fear. Gang Warfare Conflicts between criminal organizations occasionally escalate to open warfare. Territory disputes, personal vendettas, and competition for lucrative operations can trigger sustained violence. Such conflicts attract authority attention and usually end through negotiation once costs exceed benefits. Warden Assassination Killing Wardens represents the most dangerous violent crime. Wardens protect each other, investigate murders intensively, and impose collective punishment on communities harboring assassins. Successful Warden assassination requires exceptional skill, planning, and luck—or willingness to sacrifice the killer. The Hollow Saints conduct most Warden assassinations. Commercial assassination of Wardens is theoretically possible but practically rare—the risks and costs exceed what most clients will pay.
docs.title: Violence

docs.text: Criminal provision of pleasure follows predictable patterns. Illegal Gambling Underground gambling houses offer games unavailable legally (higher stakes, forbidden betting targets, rigged outcomes) and access unavailable legally (pattern-constrained individuals excluded from licensed establishments). House profits come from standard gambling advantages plus occasional manipulation. Losers who cannot pay face violence or debt bondage. Unlicensed Prostitution Legal prostitution requires licensing, inspection, and substantial fees. Unlicensed operations avoid these costs while accepting risks: violence from customers without legal protection, disease without mandatory medical checks, exploitation by criminal organizations providing "protection." Most unlicensed sex workers are pattern-constrained individuals with limited economic alternatives. Some choose the work; others are coerced or trafficked. Drug Trade Substances derived from Elsewhere-touched plants or created through restricted processes circulate through criminal networks. Effects vary: some merely intoxicate, others enable perception of pattern information, others facilitate Flesh Shaping or other magical effects. Prices range from 1-5 marks for common intoxicants to 100+ marks for rare substances with magical properties. Addiction creates reliable customers; overdose deaths create investigatory problems.
docs.title: Vice

docs.text: Property crime ranges from opportunistic to organized. Residue Theft Stealing Residue—the essence of dead pattern-bearers—combines extraordinary value with extraordinary risk. Residue has legitimate uses in Church ritual and Loom maintenance; it also has prohibited uses including Elsewhere contact attempts and Flesh Shaping enhancement. Thieves target Residue during collection (immediately after death), transportation (moving from death site to Church storage), or storage (Church facilities, state repositories). Each presents different challenges and risks. Successful Residue theft can yield 10,000-100,000 marks depending on quantity and quality. Detection and capture yields execution after torture for information about buyers and methods. Art and Artifact Theft Wealthy Hálcovans accumulate valuable objects that can be stolen and sold. Pattern-woven tapestries, religious artifacts, historical items, and fine art all have criminal markets. Theft from noble houses requires overcoming security—guards, locks, and sometimes magical protections. Theft from Church facilities adds heresy to property crime. Successful thieves either have specific buyers arranged or sell through criminal networks at substantial discounts. Cargo Theft Goods in transit—whether overland by wagon or maritime by ship—present theft opportunities. Pirates attack ships; bandits attack wagon trains; dock workers pilfer cargo during loading and unloading. Most cargo theft involves ordinary goods resold at discount. High-value cargo (expensive manufactures, restricted materials) attracts more sophisticated theft with correspondingly higher risks and rewards.
docs.title: Theft

docs.text: Urban police forces handle ordinary crime: theft, assault, public disorder, and minor vice. Guard effectiveness varies by city, district, and individual officer. In practice, City Guards focus on crimes affecting pattern-privileged individuals and major disruptions to public order. Pattern-constrained victims often find Guards uninterested in investigation. Corruption is endemic—Guards supplement inadequate salaries with payments from criminals, victims, and both simultaneously. Guards investigating organized crime face limited resources, active obstruction, and personal danger. Most focus on manageable problems rather than challenging powerful criminal organizations.
docs.title: City Guard

docs.text: The Warden Order prioritizes pattern-crimes: certificate forgery, Loom manipulation attempts, and crimes by or against Elsewhere-touched individuals. Ordinary crime falls outside their mandate except when it intersects pattern concerns. Wardens bring superior resources, training, and determination to investigations within their scope. Criminal organizations avoid triggering Warden interest when possible; those who attract Warden attention face serious consequences. However, Warden capacity is limited. They cannot investigate every pattern-crime, cannot operate everywhere simultaneously, and cannot entirely overcome corrupt officials who protect criminal operations. Wardens are a threat to criminal enterprise, not an absolute barrier.
docs.title: Wardens

docs.text: Church investigation focuses on heresy and Residue theft. Crimes without religious dimension rarely attract Church attention; crimes threatening Church interests bring intensive response. Church investigators have access to resources—including pattern-readers and Elsewhere-touched individuals—unavailable to secular authorities. They also operate under different legal constraints, sometimes extracting confessions through methods secular courts would reject. Criminal organizations selling Threadist materials or stolen Residue face dual threats: secular criminal prosecution and Church heresy proceedings. The latter often proves more dangerous.
docs.title: Church Authorities

docs.text: Wealthy individuals and organizations hire private protection ranging from individual bodyguards to armed companies. This creates two-tier crime response: those who can afford protection receive it; those who cannot rely on inadequate public systems. Private security sometimes cooperates with criminal organizations—purchasing immunity rather than fighting threats. The line between private security and criminal enforcement blurs in some contexts.
docs.title: Private Security

docs.text: Major criminal organizations maintain internal rules governing member behavior.
docs.title: Criminal Codes

docs.text: Members of the Silk Threads follow rules enforced by internal discipline: No killing civilians without permission from Thread-Captains. Unauthorized violence attracts attention and disrupts operations. Violators face punishment ranging from fines to execution depending on consequences. Pay tribute to the Weaver. All operations contribute percentage of profits upward through the hierarchy. Failure to pay brings escalating pressure culminating in removal from the organization—often violently. Protect territory. Members defend assigned areas against rival criminals and maintain order ensuring continued profitable operation. Abandoning territory without permission constitutes serious offense. No cooperation with authorities. Informants face death—slowly, publicly, and as warning to others. Even members arrested and tortured are expected to reveal nothing.
docs.title: Silk Thread Code

docs.text: The Syndicate's decentralized structure produces looser rules: Honor contracts. Agreements between members are binding. Violation destroys reputation necessary for continued operation. The Council of Tides arbitrates disputes and punishes contract breakers. Share intelligence. Information affecting multiple Port Captains must be shared. Hoarding valuable intelligence violates the confederation's foundation. Don't betray Port Captains. Whatever conflicts exist within the Syndicate, external threats to Port Captains affect all. Members who cooperate with authorities against Port Captains face universal condemnation.
docs.title: Coral Syndicate Code

docs.text: The resistance movement's code reflects political rather than commercial priorities: Protect Threadists. The organization exists to defend those persecuted for belief. Members risk themselves before risking protected individuals. Target only oppressors. Violence against uninvolved civilians violates organizational principles and provides propaganda for enemies. Even in operations against legitimate targets, civilian casualties must be minimized. No innocent casualties. Operations likely to harm bystanders require exceptional justification. Members accept mission failure rather than innocent deaths when possible. Accept martyrdom if necessary. Captured members are expected to reveal nothing regardless of torture. Many carry means of suicide to ensure silence.
docs.title: Hollow Saint Code

docs.text: Criminal organizations don't exist separate from legitimate Hálcova—they're embedded within it, exploiting gaps and contradictions in official systems. Pattern-constrained individuals denied legal economic opportunity find criminal employment. Goods and services prohibited by law but desired by markets reach consumers through criminal channels. Corruption connects criminal operations to legitimate authorities. This integration makes criminal activity extraordinarily difficult to eliminate. Suppressing one organization creates opportunity for others. Removing corrupt officials proves temporary as successors face the same pressures. Prohibiting goods and services creates the criminal markets that supply them. For narrative purposes, criminal organizations provide characters operating outside legal constraints but within comprehensible structures. Crime bosses, smugglers, resistance fighters, and corrupt officials all inhabit spaces defined by both criminal and legitimate rules—spaces where stories of loyalty, betrayal, survival, and moral complexity naturally unfold. Further documentation needed: specific criminal figures and their histories, maps of criminal territories, detailed economics of particular criminal operations, investigation and prosecution procedures.
docs.title: Integration with Legitimate Society

docs.text: Economics and Class in Hálcova Overview Economics in Hálcova cannot be separated from fate. The Sórscad pattern determines access to credit, employment, insurance, and opportunity. Pattern Residue—the energy of dissolving fates—fuels magic and industry. Death is literally productive. This creates an economy where some people are worth more dead than alive, where peace is expensive, and where the institutions that predict your future have financial stakes in that prediction coming true. The Fate Market Pattern as Asset Your Sórscad is not just identity—it's capital. Pattern-Weight Some patterns are "heavier" than others: - More fate-significance - More likely to impact events - More valuable as Pattern Residue when released Heavy patterns belong to: - Those born into consequential circumstances - Those whose choices ripple outward - Those predicted for significant outcomes (positive or negative) Light patterns belong to: - Those born into marginal circumstances - Those whose choices affect few others - Those predicted for unremarkable outcomes The Market Implications Heavy patterns command higher prices in substitution deals (Pact Summoning) Heavy patterns produce more valuable Residue upon death Heavy patterns are worth more to The Loom (more data value) Heavy patterns are targets for various exploitation This creates a hierarchy: some lives have more market value than others, calculated and priced. Pattern Speculation Fate Futures Financial instruments that pay out based on whether predictions come true: "If subject achieves predicted career trajectory by age 30, contract pays X" "If subject dies by predicted cause within predicted window, contract pays Y" "If subject deviates significantly from pattern, contract is void" Who Trades These Insurance companies (hedging their risk assessments) Investment houses (speculating on populations) Criminal organizations (betting on specific outcomes they can influence) Governments (managing demographic predictions) Pattern Arbitrage Some patterns are mispriced. The Loom's predictions, while accurate on average, have errors in individual cases. Arbitrageurs look for: - Patterns undervalued by The Loom (capable people dismissed as low-potential) - Patterns overvalued by The Loom (impressive readings masking actual mediocrity) - Situations where environmental change will shift pattern-outcomes They invest in undervalued people—education, opportunity, resources—and profit when those people outperform predictions. This is legal. It's also morally ambiguous: you're betting on people, treating lives as investments, profiting from the gap between predicted and actual humanity. Credit and Debt Pattern-Based Lending All credit decisions incorporate Sórscad data: Interest Rates Pattern-privileged: Low rates. The Loom predicts they'll repay. Pattern-constrained: High rates. The Loom predicts elevated default risk. Pattern-illegible (practitioners): Variable. Their patterns are too contaminated for reliable prediction. Collateral What can you pledge? Physical assets (traditional) Future earnings (income garnishment) Pattern Residue rights (if you die, the lender harvests) Pact-substitution rights (you can be offered to an Elsewhere entity) Echo-binding rights (you can be bound after death) The last three are where lending gets dark. Poor borrowers often have nothing to pledge but themselves—their deaths, their souls, their eternal servitude as echoes. Debt Spirals The pattern-constrained start with high rates, struggle to repay, take on more debt to service existing debt, and eventually pledge increasingly extreme collateral. Endpoint possibilities: - Debt-bondage (working off the debt under contract) - Residue-pledge (worth more dead than alive) - Pact-transfer (sold to cover what you owe) - Echo-indenture (bound to serve after death) The system is designed to produce these endpoints. They're not failures of the system—they're the system working as intended. The Pact Economy Elsewhere Entities as Lenders Pact Summoning functions like supernatural credit: - You receive power now - You pay with your core later - Interest accrues (the more you use, the faster you pay) - Default is impossible (the entity always collects) Substitution as Currency Cores are fungible. The entity doesn't care whose core it gets. This creates: - Substitution markets : Where cores are bought and sold - Core brokers : Middlemen connecting those with cores to sell and summoners needing payment - Substitution pricing : Heavy patterns worth more, light patterns worth less - Procurement operations : Acquiring cores through various means (legal and otherwise) The Substitution Hierarchy From most to least valuable: 1. Exceptional patterns (seventh son of seventh son, etc.) 2. Heavy patterns from powerful lineages 3. Standard adult patterns 4. Light adult patterns 5. Child patterns (potential not yet realized) 6. Elderly patterns (mostly spent) 7. Animal patterns (weak, but abundant) This is a price list for souls. It exists. People consult it. How Heavy Patterns Become Available The economic puzzle: if heavy patterns are most valuable, why would their owners ever sell? The wealthy don't volunteer for soul-consumption. The answer is that heavy patterns aren't voluntarily sold—they're acquired through coercion . The Voluntary Market (Light Patterns) - The desperate poor sell their light patterns for immediate cash - Prices are uniformly low (supply is abundant, demand for weak patterns is limited) - Legal, regulated, depressing - Used for minor pacts, bulk entity-feeding The Coerced Market (Heavy Patterns) Heavy patterns enter the market through: Debt Bondage : Pattern-privileged who fall from grace. A noble house's debts can include the heirs' substitution rights. When creditors call the debt, they can sell those rights to entity-brokers. Criminal Procurement : Kidnapping for substitution is a significant black-market industry. Heavy-pattern individuals are targeted, held, and sold. This is why wealthy families maintain security details—and why those details sometimes turn. Legal Execution : Condemned criminals' patterns become state property. For serious crimes, the state auctions substitution rights. Heavy-pattern criminals are worth more dead than imprisoned. Family Arrangements : Some families sell members—typically younger children, spare heirs, or disgraced relatives. Legal in some jurisdictions, gray-market in others. Debt-for-Flesh Contracts : Borrowers who can't repay may convert debt to substitution obligation. They live until the creditor finds a buyer or a summoner with a bill coming due. Price Reflects Procurement Difficulty Substitution prices don't reflect seller valuation (heavy-pattern individuals wouldn't sell at any price). They reflect: - Procurement cost (bribes, kidnapping operations, legal fees) - Risk premium (criminal penalties if caught) - Scarcity (heavy patterns are rare AND well-protected) - Urgency (summoners in debt have deadlines) An entity doesn't care whether the core is volunteered or taken. It only cares about weight. The market serves that indifference. Employment and Opportunity Pattern-Gated Careers Many positions require specific pattern profiles: Explicit Requirements - "Must have Court-Field or Heights-Field classification" - "No Wound-Self or Shard-Self candidates" - "Minimum Road-Path or Ladder-Path trajectory" Implicit Screening Even without stated requirements, hiring decisions incorporate pattern data: - "We don't discriminate based on pattern—we just look at the whole candidate" - "Their pattern doesn't fit our company culture" - "The Loom predicts retention issues with that profile" Pattern Families and Stereotypes Certain pattern-combinations are associated with professions: "Lamplighters" (Lantern-Road-Pact-Duty-Court) - Bureaucrats, administrators, reliable employees - Boring but dependable - Automatically considered for stable positions "Storm-Children" (Spark-Crossroads-Twin-Rebel-Wild) - Artists, adventurers, troublemakers - Exciting but unreliable - Automatically excluded from positions requiring stability "Knot-Born" (Wound-Maze-Thorn-Fear-Street) - Criminals, laborers, expendables - Dangerous but useful - Automatically considered for dangerous or demeaning work These stereotypes become self-fulfilling. Denied legitimate opportunity, the Knot-Born turn to illegitimate work. Their criminal records confirm The Loom's predictions. The cycle continues. Labor Markets Pattern Segregation Different patterns concentrate in different industries: - Heights-Field patterns in management - Forge-Field patterns in manufacturing - Street-Field patterns in informal economy - Underbelly-Field patterns in criminal enterprise This isn't natural sorting—it's structural channeling. Each pattern is directed toward "appropriate" work from Binding Day onward. Wage Differentials Same work, different pay, based on pattern: - Pattern-privileged workers paid more (justified as "retention cost") - Pattern-constrained workers paid less (justified as "risk premium") - The gap is legal, documented, defended as actuarially sound The Pattern Residue Economy Production Pattern Residue is produced when patterns dissolve—primarily at death. Natural Production - Every death releases some Residue - More from heavy patterns - More from traumatic deaths - More from pattern-rich populations Sites of Concentration - Battlefields (mass death, often violent) - Plague zones (mass death, weakened patterns) - Execution grounds (controlled, harvestable) - Disaster sites (concentrated mortality) Manufactured Production The demand for Residue creates incentives: - War as industry (mass death with geographic concentration) - Plague management (letting disease run for harvest) - Capital punishment as production (not justice, but fuel) - Blood sports (entertainment plus Residue) The Residue Trade Harvesting Licensed harvesters extract Residue from death sites. Unlicensed harvesters do the same, illegally. Equipment required: - Collection apparatus (varies by tradition) - Storage containers (keeping Residue stable) - Transportation (Residue degrades; speed matters) Occupational hazards: - Exposure effects (too much contact changes you) - Competition (other harvesters, scavengers, authorities) - Moral weight (you're literally profiting from death) Refinement Raw Residue requires processing for most uses: - Purification (removing contaminants) - Stabilization (extending shelf life) - Concentration (increasing potency) - Packaging (making it tradeable) Refineries are industrial operations—factories of death-product. Distribution Residue reaches end users through: - Official channels (licensed trade, taxation, regulation) - Gray markets (legal but questionable sourcing) - Black markets (illegal, untaxed, often higher quality) Pricing Residue prices fluctuate based on: - Supply (peace = scarce; war = abundant) - Quality (pure vs. contaminated) - Source (some deaths produce better Residue) - Demand (more practitioners = higher prices) During prolonged peace, prices spike. Some institutions have incentives to prevent peace from lasting. The Moral Economy Who Benefits From Death The Loom (fuel for operation) Core Binders (fuel for anchors) Residue traders (profit margin) Magitech industries (raw material) Anyone using Residue-powered devices Who Provides Death The pattern-constrained (dying in wars, plagues, prisons) The poor (selling Residue rights for cash now) The condemned (executed for production) Populations deemed "surplus" The economy of Hálcova is built on bodies. Clean hands are expensive. Everyone is complicit at some remove. Class Structure The Pattern-Privileged Characteristics - Born with or drawn into favorable patterns - The Loom predicts success; institutions deliver it - Low interest rates, good jobs, favorable treatment How They Stay Privileged - Marry within pattern-class (maintaining lineage patterns) - Leverage pattern-capital into actual capital - Use wealth to insulate from pattern-deviation consequences - Support institutions that validate pattern-prediction Their Perspective - "The system works—look at my success" - "Pattern-discrimination is just actuarial accuracy" - "If their patterns predicted better, they'd do better" The Pattern-Constrained Characteristics - Born with or drawn into unfavorable patterns - The Loom predicts struggle; institutions ensure it - High interest rates, bad jobs, hostile treatment How They Stay Constrained - Denied opportunity that might disprove predictions - Forced into circumstances that confirm predictions - Accumulate debt, criminal records, health problems - Each confirmation further constrains next generation Their Perspective - "The system is rigged—look at my constraints" - "They decided what I'd be before I could decide anything" - "Success despite pattern proves nothing; they just call it deviation" The Pattern-Illegible Characteristics - Practitioners whose patterns are contaminated, faded, or transformed - The Loom can't predict them reliably - Treated with suspicion, opportunity, or both Types - Heavy Core Binders (layered patterns from echo-bleed) - Established Flesh Shapers (hollowed Húslaimh circles) - Deep Pact Summoners (faded Léilcrù from payment) - Depleted Fate Threaders (narrowed Sórscad from extraction) - Long-term Colony Hosts (hybrid patterns from transformation) Their Position - Some institutions exclude them (can't assess risk) - Some institutions seek them (unpredictability is useful) - They exist outside normal class structure - Often form their own communities and networks The Industrial Magitech Sector Residue-Powered Technology Pattern Residue isn't just for practitioners—it powers industry. Applications - Pattern-engines (The Loom and derivatives) - Communication systems (pattern-resonance transmission) - Transportation (Residue-fueled vehicles for high-priority use) - Manufacturing (certain processes require Residue catalyst) - Weapons (Residue-enhanced ammunition, siege equipment) The Magic-Industrial Complex Industries dependent on Residue form a political bloc: - They need steady supply (war, plague, execution) - They oppose peace when it threatens supply - They support policies that produce harvestable death - They lobby against restrictions on harvesting This isn't conspiracy—it's interest group politics. The people running these industries aren't monsters. They're responding to incentives. The incentives produce monstrous outcomes. Labor in Magitech Working with Residue changes you. Long-term exposure: - Physical effects (pallor, temperature sensitivity, pattern-interference) - Psychological effects (death-awareness, morbid outlook) - Social effects (stigma, isolation from non-exposed) Residue-industry workers are pattern-constrained almost by definition. The work confirms their patterns, trapping them further. The Underground Economy What's Traded Illegally Unregistered cores : Bypassing official harvesting channels Substitution services : Procuring cores for pact-payment Pattern data : Stolen Registry information Unlicensed binding : Echo-services without permits Black-market homunculi : Especially mimics Infection services : Colony hosting outside legal channels Fate-fraud : Forged or manipulated pattern records Deviation assistance : Helping people evade pattern-expectations Criminal Organizations Structure - Often organized by pattern-family (Knot-Born networks, etc.) - Use pattern-illegible members for unpredictable operations - Bribe or coerce Warden Order members - Operate across regions with different enforcement levels Services - Debt elimination (including murdering creditors) - Pattern-laundering (falsifying Registry records) - Protection (from both Wardens and rival organizations) - Procurement (cores, blood, colonies, anything tradeable) Relationship to Legal Economy - Provides services legal economy won't - Employs people legal economy excludes - Operates on same logic (profit, transaction, leverage) - Often partners with "legitimate" institutions quietly The Common Person Daily Economic Life For someone without wealth, special patterns, or practitioner abilities: Employment - Pattern determines options before you apply - Wages set by pattern-class, not just skill - Advancement limited by pattern-ceiling - Termination easy if pattern-excused Credit - High rates if available at all - Collateral requirements often exceed assets - Debt-trap structures common - Pattern-default possible (selling yourself) Housing - Pattern-segregated neighborhoods - Insurance based on district pattern-profile - Mobility limited by pattern-appropriate areas - Quality tracks pattern-privilege Healthcare - Treatment recommendations incorporate pattern-data - "Pattern-appropriate care" means lower quality for constrained - End-of-life decisions consider Residue value - Chronic conditions managed by pattern-expectation Family - Marriage recommendations based on pattern-compatibility - Child-bearing decisions influenced by predicted patterns - Education options constrained by pattern-category - Inheritance affected by pattern-privilege Coping Strategies Acceptance - "My pattern is my pattern" - Find meaning in what fate allows - Orthodox faith provides framework - Community within pattern-class Hustle - Work the system's margins - Find opportunities The Loom undervalues - Build informal networks - Accumulate resources despite predictions Escape - Pattern-illegibility through practice (if you can afford initiation) - Geographical mobility (frontier regions, different enforcement) - Criminal economy (if legitimate economy excludes you) - Pact Summoning (trade pattern for power, lose both eventually) Resistance - Threadist reform movements - Hollow Saint nihilism - Pattern-fraud and deviation - Collective action against pattern-discrimination Most people combine these, shifting between acceptance, hustle, escape attempts, and occasional resistance depending on circumstances. Further documentation needed on: Tax structures, trade routes, currency systems, specific industry details, historical economic development, regional economic variation

docs.text: Fate Futures Financial instruments that pay out based on whether predictions come true: "If subject achieves predicted career trajectory by age 30, contract pays X" "If subject dies by predicted cause within predicted window, contract pays Y" "If subject deviates significantly from pattern, contract is void" Who Trades These Insurance companies (hedging their risk assessments) Investment houses (speculating on populations) Criminal organizations (betting on specific outcomes they can influence) Governments (managing demographic predictions) Pattern Arbitrage Some patterns are mispriced. The Loom's predictions, while accurate on average, have errors in individual cases. Arbitrageurs look for: - Patterns undervalued by The Loom (capable people dismissed as low-potential) - Patterns overvalued by The Loom (impressive readings masking actual mediocrity) - Situations where environmental change will shift pattern-outcomes They invest in undervalued people—education, opportunity, resources—and profit when those people outperform predictions. This is legal. It's also morally ambiguous: you're betting on people, treating lives as investments, profiting from the gap between predicted and actual humanity.
docs.title: Pattern Speculation

docs.text: All credit decisions incorporate Sórscad data: Interest Rates Pattern-privileged: Low rates. The Loom predicts they'll repay. Pattern-constrained: High rates. The Loom predicts elevated default risk. Pattern-illegible (practitioners): Variable. Their patterns are too contaminated for reliable prediction. Collateral What can you pledge? Physical assets (traditional) Future earnings (income garnishment) Pattern Residue rights (if you die, the lender harvests) Pact-substitution rights (you can be offered to an Elsewhere entity) Echo-binding rights (you can be bound after death) The last three are where lending gets dark. Poor borrowers often have nothing to pledge but themselves—their deaths, their souls, their eternal servitude as echoes. Debt Spirals The pattern-constrained start with high rates, struggle to repay, take on more debt to service existing debt, and eventually pledge increasingly extreme collateral. Endpoint possibilities: - Debt-bondage (working off the debt under contract) - Residue-pledge (worth more dead than alive) - Pact-transfer (sold to cover what you owe) - Echo-indenture (bound to serve after death) The system is designed to produce these endpoints. They're not failures of the system—they're the system working as intended.
docs.title: Pattern-Based Lending

docs.text: Elsewhere Entities as Lenders Pact Summoning functions like supernatural credit: - You receive power now - You pay with your core later - Interest accrues (the more you use, the faster you pay) - Default is impossible (the entity always collects) Substitution as Currency Cores are fungible. The entity doesn't care whose core it gets. This creates: - Substitution markets : Where cores are bought and sold - Core brokers : Middlemen connecting those with cores to sell and summoners needing payment - Substitution pricing : Heavy patterns worth more, light patterns worth less - Procurement operations : Acquiring cores through various means (legal and otherwise) The Substitution Hierarchy From most to least valuable: 1. Exceptional patterns (seventh son of seventh son, etc.) 2. Heavy patterns from powerful lineages 3. Standard adult patterns 4. Light adult patterns 5. Child patterns (potential not yet realized) 6. Elderly patterns (mostly spent) 7. Animal patterns (weak, but abundant) This is a price list for souls. It exists. People consult it. How Heavy Patterns Become Available The economic puzzle: if heavy patterns are most valuable, why would their owners ever sell? The wealthy don't volunteer for soul-consumption. The answer is that heavy patterns aren't voluntarily sold—they're acquired through coercion . The Voluntary Market (Light Patterns) - The desperate poor sell their light patterns for immediate cash - Prices are uniformly low (supply is abundant, demand for weak patterns is limited) - Legal, regulated, depressing - Used for minor pacts, bulk entity-feeding The Coerced Market (Heavy Patterns) Heavy patterns enter the market through: Debt Bondage : Pattern-privileged who fall from grace. A noble house's debts can include the heirs' substitution rights. When creditors call the debt, they can sell those rights to entity-brokers. Criminal Procurement : Kidnapping for substitution is a significant black-market industry. Heavy-pattern individuals are targeted, held, and sold. This is why wealthy families maintain security details—and why those details sometimes turn. Legal Execution : Condemned criminals' patterns become state property. For serious crimes, the state auctions substitution rights. Heavy-pattern criminals are worth more dead than imprisoned. Family Arrangements : Some families sell members—typically younger children, spare heirs, or disgraced relatives. Legal in some jurisdictions, gray-market in others. Debt-for-Flesh Contracts : Borrowers who can't repay may convert debt to substitution obligation. They live until the creditor finds a buyer or a summoner with a bill coming due. Price Reflects Procurement Difficulty Substitution prices don't reflect seller valuation (heavy-pattern individuals wouldn't sell at any price). They reflect: - Procurement cost (bribes, kidnapping operations, legal fees) - Risk premium (criminal penalties if caught) - Scarcity (heavy patterns are rare AND well-protected) - Urgency (summoners in debt have deadlines) An entity doesn't care whether the core is volunteered or taken. It only cares about weight. The market serves that indifference.

docs.text: Many positions require specific pattern profiles: Explicit Requirements - "Must have Court-Field or Heights-Field classification" - "No Wound-Self or Shard-Self candidates" - "Minimum Road-Path or Ladder-Path trajectory" Implicit Screening Even without stated requirements, hiring decisions incorporate pattern data: - "We don't discriminate based on pattern—we just look at the whole candidate" - "Their pattern doesn't fit our company culture" - "The Loom predicts retention issues with that profile"
docs.title: Pattern-Gated Careers

docs.text: Certain pattern-combinations are associated with professions: "Lamplighters" (Lantern-Road-Pact-Duty-Court) - Bureaucrats, administrators, reliable employees - Boring but dependable - Automatically considered for stable positions "Storm-Children" (Spark-Crossroads-Twin-Rebel-Wild) - Artists, adventurers, troublemakers - Exciting but unreliable - Automatically excluded from positions requiring stability "Knot-Born" (Wound-Maze-Thorn-Fear-Street) - Criminals, laborers, expendables - Dangerous but useful - Automatically considered for dangerous or demeaning work These stereotypes become self-fulfilling. Denied legitimate opportunity, the Knot-Born turn to illegitimate work. Their criminal records confirm The Loom's predictions. The cycle continues.
docs.title: Pattern Families and Stereotypes

docs.text: Pattern Segregation Different patterns concentrate in different industries: - Heights-Field patterns in management - Forge-Field patterns in manufacturing - Street-Field patterns in informal economy - Underbelly-Field patterns in criminal enterprise This isn't natural sorting—it's structural channeling. Each pattern is directed toward "appropriate" work from Binding Day onward. Wage Differentials Same work, different pay, based on pattern: - Pattern-privileged workers paid more (justified as "retention cost") - Pattern-constrained workers paid less (justified as "risk premium") - The gap is legal, documented, defended as actuarially sound
docs.title: Labor Markets

docs.text: Pattern Residue is produced when patterns dissolve—primarily at death. Natural Production - Every death releases some Residue - More from heavy patterns - More from traumatic deaths - More from pattern-rich populations Sites of Concentration - Battlefields (mass death, often violent) - Plague zones (mass death, weakened patterns) - Execution grounds (controlled, harvestable) - Disaster sites (concentrated mortality) Manufactured Production The demand for Residue creates incentives: - War as industry (mass death with geographic concentration) - Plague management (letting disease run for harvest) - Capital punishment as production (not justice, but fuel) - Blood sports (entertainment plus Residue)
docs.title: Production

docs.text: Harvesting Licensed harvesters extract Residue from death sites. Unlicensed harvesters do the same, illegally. Equipment required: - Collection apparatus (varies by tradition) - Storage containers (keeping Residue stable) - Transportation (Residue degrades; speed matters) Occupational hazards: - Exposure effects (too much contact changes you) - Competition (other harvesters, scavengers, authorities) - Moral weight (you're literally profiting from death) Refinement Raw Residue requires processing for most uses: - Purification (removing contaminants) - Stabilization (extending shelf life) - Concentration (increasing potency) - Packaging (making it tradeable) Refineries are industrial operations—factories of death-product. Distribution Residue reaches end users through: - Official channels (licensed trade, taxation, regulation) - Gray markets (legal but questionable sourcing) - Black markets (illegal, untaxed, often higher quality) Pricing Residue prices fluctuate based on: - Supply (peace = scarce; war = abundant) - Quality (pure vs. contaminated) - Source (some deaths produce better Residue) - Demand (more practitioners = higher prices) During prolonged peace, prices spike. Some institutions have incentives to prevent peace from lasting.
docs.title: The Residue Trade

docs.text: Who Benefits From Death The Loom (fuel for operation) Core Binders (fuel for anchors) Residue traders (profit margin) Magitech industries (raw material) Anyone using Residue-powered devices Who Provides Death The pattern-constrained (dying in wars, plagues, prisons) The poor (selling Residue rights for cash now) The condemned (executed for production) Populations deemed "surplus" The economy of Hálcova is built on bodies. Clean hands are expensive. Everyone is complicit at some remove.
docs.title: The Moral Economy

docs.text: Characteristics - Born with or drawn into favorable patterns - The Loom predicts success; institutions deliver it - Low interest rates, good jobs, favorable treatment How They Stay Privileged - Marry within pattern-class (maintaining lineage patterns) - Leverage pattern-capital into actual capital - Use wealth to insulate from pattern-deviation consequences - Support institutions that validate pattern-prediction Their Perspective - "The system works—look at my success" - "Pattern-discrimination is just actuarial accuracy" - "If their patterns predicted better, they'd do better"
docs.title: The Pattern-Privileged

docs.text: Characteristics - Born with or drawn into unfavorable patterns - The Loom predicts struggle; institutions ensure it - High interest rates, bad jobs, hostile treatment How They Stay Constrained - Denied opportunity that might disprove predictions - Forced into circumstances that confirm predictions - Accumulate debt, criminal records, health problems - Each confirmation further constrains next generation Their Perspective - "The system is rigged—look at my constraints" - "They decided what I'd be before I could decide anything" - "Success despite pattern proves nothing; they just call it deviation"
docs.title: The Pattern-Constrained

docs.text: Characteristics - Practitioners whose patterns are contaminated, faded, or transformed - The Loom can't predict them reliably - Treated with suspicion, opportunity, or both Types - Heavy Core Binders (layered patterns from echo-bleed) - Established Flesh Shapers (hollowed Húslaimh circles) - Deep Pact Summoners (faded Léilcrù from payment) - Depleted Fate Threaders (narrowed Sórscad from extraction) - Long-term Colony Hosts (hybrid patterns from transformation) Their Position - Some institutions exclude them (can't assess risk) - Some institutions seek them (unpredictability is useful) - They exist outside normal class structure - Often form their own communities and networks

docs.text: Pattern Residue isn't just for practitioners—it powers industry. Applications - Pattern-engines (The Loom and derivatives) - Communication systems (pattern-resonance transmission) - Transportation (Residue-fueled vehicles for high-priority use) - Manufacturing (certain processes require Residue catalyst) - Weapons (Residue-enhanced ammunition, siege equipment)

docs.text: Industries dependent on Residue form a political bloc: - They need steady supply (war, plague, execution) - They oppose peace when it threatens supply - They support policies that produce harvestable death - They lobby against restrictions on harvesting This isn't conspiracy—it's interest group politics. The people running these industries aren't monsters. They're responding to incentives. The incentives produce monstrous outcomes.

Long-term exposure: - Physical effects (pallor, temperature sensitivity, pattern-interference) - Psychological effects (death-awareness, morbid outlook) - Social effects (stigma, isolation from non-exposed) Residue-industry workers are pattern-constrained almost by definition. The work confirms their patterns, trapping them further.

docs.text: Entertainment System of Hálcova Overview Entertainment in Hálcova reflects and reinforces the world's fundamental structures: pattern-based stratification, the Church of the Weave's influence, regional identity, and the economic principles that govern daily life. From gladiatorial combat in Fonvárs to naval battles in the Reaches, from high-stakes board games to street performances, entertainment serves as both social pressure valve and mechanism of control. Competitive Formats Mintaharc (Arena Combat) The premier entertainment spectacle of the Heartlands, Mintaharc ("Pattern-War") takes place in Fonvárs Grand Arena, a massive stone structure capable of holding 15,000 spectators. Combat follows strict ceremonial formats that have evolved over centuries. Structure and Participants Arena fighters fall into two categories: voluntary combatants (typically pattern-privileged individuals seeking glory and wealth) and condemned fighters (pattern-constrained criminals offered combat as alternative to execution or Correction). The asymmetry is intentional—watching the privileged test their skills against the desperate reinforces social hierarchies while providing the illusion of opportunity. Professional gladiators train at licensed schools, each associated with noble patrons. The most famous schools include the Iron Thread Academy (Crown-sponsored), the Crimson Weave (Church-affiliated), and the Merchant's Edge (Trade Guild-funded). Fighters sign contracts ranging from one to ten years, receiving housing, training, and a share of winnings in exchange for exclusive combat rights. Combat Categories Traditional matches employ period weapons: swords, spears, nets, and tridents. Armor varies by fighter class—heavily armored "Anchors" face lightly equipped "Threads" in asymmetric contests that test different skills. Team battles pit groups of three to twelve against each other in choreographed scenarios representing historical conflicts. Exhibition matches during major festivals feature Flesh Shaped combatants—individuals who have undergone physical modification specifically for arena performance. These fighters command the highest fees and attract the largest crowds, though Church doctrine officially disapproves of such "vanity modifications." Economics of the Arena Betting forms the financial backbone of Mintaharc. Licensed betting houses accept wagers from 1 to 1,000+ marks, with the largest bets placed by noble houses seeking both profit and prestige through their sponsored fighters. The Crown takes a 10% cut of all legal betting revenue; the Church receives the Residue of any combatants who die in the arena. Fighter compensation varies enormously. A novice condemned fighter receives only the possibility of eventual freedom. A mid-tier professional earns 200-500 marks per bout. Champion fighters command appearance fees of 5,000+ marks plus a percentage of betting revenue on their matches. Deaths occur but are not required—most matches end at first blood or submission. However, certain holiday exhibitions and "justice matches" (condemned criminals facing each other) have higher fatality rates. The Church's Residue collection rights create economic incentive for deaths, though this is never stated publicly. Social Function Mintaharc serves multiple purposes beyond entertainment. It provides visible proof that pattern-privileged status confers genuine advantages (better training, nutrition, equipment). It offers pattern-constrained individuals a theoretical path to freedom and wealth, reinforcing the system's supposed meritocracy. It channels violent impulses into controlled spectacle. And it generates substantial revenue for Crown, Church, and nobility alike. Tengerjáték (Naval Combat) The Reaches' signature entertainment, Tengerjáték ("Sea-Game") stages ship-to-ship combat in protected harbor arenas. Purpose-built vessels crewed by 20-50 sailors engage in battles that combine naval tactics, individual combat, and theatrical spectacle. Venue and Format Major Reaches ports maintain combat harbors—protected basins where spectators watch from surrounding cliffs, towers, and floating platforms. The largest venue, Vízkapu's Grand Harbor, can accommodate battles involving up to six ships simultaneously, with viewing capacity for 8,000 spectators. Ships are purpose-built for combat entertainment rather than actual naval warfare. Hulls are reinforced for ramming but designed to break apart dramatically. Fire weapons use controlled substances that burn impressively without spreading uncontrollably. Boarding ramps deploy with theatrical flourish. Combat Elements Matches typically begin with maneuvering phases where crews demonstrate sailing skill, followed by ranged engagement (ballistae, fire pots, grappling hooks), ramming attempts, and finally boarding actions where crew-to-crew combat determines the victor. Ships may be captured, sunk, or burned depending on match stakes. Crews include both professional naval entertainers and condemned sailors (typically smugglers or pirates captured by League patrols). Professional crews earn shares of prize money and betting revenue. Condemned crews fight for reduced sentences or freedom. Seasonal Structure Tengerjáték follows a seasonal championship format aligned with sailing weather. Spring trials determine which crews qualify for summer tournaments. Autumn championships crown seasonal victors. Winter sees reduced schedules focused on smaller vessels and individual combat rather than full fleet actions. Betting on Tengerjáték reaches staggering volumes during championship events. The Reaches League officially sanctions betting and takes substantial regulatory fees, making naval combat entertainment a significant source of League revenue. Fonálháló (Strategic Board Game) The intellectual counterpart to physical combat sports, Fonálháló ("Thread-Net") is an abstract strategy game representing Loom manipulation. Played on a 19x19 grid using pattern stones and thread tokens, the game has evolved from religious meditation aid to competitive sport over centuries. Rules and Play Fonálháló's core mechanics derive from ancient territory-control games (mechanically similar to Earth's Go), but Hálcovan development has added layers of thematic complexity. Basic Rules : - Two players alternate placing stones on grid intersections - Stones of the same color connected orthogonally form "pattern groups" - Groups must maintain at least one empty adjacent intersection ("breath") to survive - Groups with no breath are "dissolved" and removed from the board - The player who controls more territory when neither player wishes to continue wins The Thread Modification : Where pure Go ends, Fonálháló adds "thread tokens"—a limited supply (typically 5-7 per player) of special pieces that modify gameplay: Anchor Threads : Placed on owned stones, prevent dissolution for three opponent turns. Represents Core Binding's resistance to pattern-disruption. Binding Threads : Connect two owned groups across empty space, sharing breath. Represents Cóitcai connections. Fate Threads : Placed on empty intersections, reserving them for later placement. Represents Sórscad trajectory-claiming. Dissolution Threads : Placed adjacent to opponent groups, reducing their effective breath by one. Represents Hálmaht death-pressure. Thread tokens add strategic depth beyond pure territory control. Managing thread reserves, timing thread deployment, and countering opponent threads creates decision trees that exponentially multiply game complexity. Scoring : Territory (empty intersections surrounded by your stones) plus captured stones minus thread tokens spent. The thread cost creates interesting sacrificial calculations—spending threads for tactical advantage may cost victory if the margin is close. Complexity Analysis The 19x19 grid alone creates approximately 10^170 possible board positions. Adding thread token decisions multiplies complexity further. Professional players estimate Fonálháló exceeds Go's complexity by roughly an order of magnitude due to thread management. Games between masters can last hours. Tournament matches employ time controls and adjudicators who rule on disputed positions. Professional players dedicate decades to mastering strategic principles—even lifelong study doesn't exhaust the game's depth. Professional Circuit Noble houses sponsor professional Fonálháló players, providing stipends, housing, and access to prestigious tournaments. The annual Crown Championship in Fonvárs offers prizes of 5,000+ marks and lifetime prestige. Regional tournaments throughout the Heartlands and Vent Lands maintain active competitive scenes. Professional players earn between 500 marks (regional competitors) to 50,000+ marks annually (Crown Champions). The most famous players become celebrities, their games analyzed and discussed by enthusiasts across pattern-privileged society. Social Significance Fonálháló serves as social signifier—ability to play well indicates education, patience, and strategic thinking valued by pattern-privileged culture. Business negotiations sometimes begin with games, allowing parties to assess each other's character. Marriage arrangements among nobility may include Fonálháló matches as part of courtship. The Church views Fonálháló ambivalently. As meditation on Loom principles, it has religious significance. As competitive obsession, it risks becoming idol. Church-sponsored tournaments emphasize spiritual aspects while secular tournaments focus on competition and gambling. Performance Arts Theater Fonvárs alone hosts twelve major theaters ranging from the Crown Theater (2,000 seats, royal patronage) to intimate playhouses seating 100 or fewer. Theater in Hálcova serves entertainment, education, and propaganda functions simultaneously. Genre Categories Pattern Morality Plays : Church-approved dramatic works illustrating proper relationship between individual and Loom. Plots typically show characters accepting their pattern-assigned roles and finding contentment, or suffering consequences of rebellion. These plays receive Church subsidies and constitute required viewing for pattern-constrained individuals during certain festivals. Historical Dramas : Depictions of significant events from Hálcovan history, particularly the Integration Century and establishment of current social order. These plays celebrate founders and heroes while presenting approved interpretations of contested historical events. Noble houses commission works glorifying their ancestors. Comedies : Humorous works satirizing social types and situations. Unwritten rules prohibit satirizing pattern-privileged individuals or Church officials directly—comedies instead mock pattern-constrained characters, foreign customs, or safely historical figures. The best comedies embed subtle criticism within acceptable frameworks. Echo Performances : Unique to Hálcova, these productions feature Elsewhere-touched actors capable of creating visual illusions through their connection to alternate reality. The effect resembles stage magic but operates through genuine supernatural ability. Echo performances command premium prices and attract audiences from across regions. Economics Ticket prices range from 0.5 marks (standing room, basic playhouses) to 50 marks (private boxes, major productions). Theater companies operate on patronage models—noble houses, guilds, or wealthy merchants sponsor troupes in exchange for dedicated performances and social prestige. Actors occupy ambiguous social positions. Pattern-privileged performers enjoy celebrity status while technically engaging in "common labor." Pattern-constrained actors can achieve wealth and fame but remain legally restricted. The most successful actors leverage their public profiles into political influence. Music Musical traditions vary significantly across regions and classes, from orchestral performances in noble houses to work songs in harvest fields. Orchestral Music Pattern-privileged society supports orchestras of 20-60 musicians performing composed works in concert halls and private venues. Compositions follow formal structures emphasizing mathematical relationships—music theory explicitly connects to Loom principles. Instruments include strings (various sizes of fiddle-family instruments), winds (flutes, horns, reed instruments), percussion, and unique "pattern-resonators" that produce tones through controlled Elsewhere interaction. Orchestral musicians train at conservatories associated with noble houses or Church institutions. Professional musicians earn 300-1,000 marks annually depending on orchestra prestige. Composers may earn substantially more through commissions. Folk Music Regional traditions preserve songs and instrumental styles predating current social structures. The Reaches maintain sea shanty traditions for coordinating ship labor. Heartlands villages keep harvest songs, wedding music, and lullabies. Far Shelf communities preserve the most extensive folk repertoires, including songs the Church considers subversive. Folk music uses simpler instruments: hand drums, simple flutes, stringed instruments playable without formal training. Performances occur at festivals, taverns, and community gatherings. Professional folk musicians are rare—most performers combine music with other occupations. Church Music The Church of the Weave maintains elaborate hymn traditions. Cathedral choirs perform multi-part compositions during services. Hymn texts reinforce theological messages about accepting one's pattern and trusting Loom guidance. Church musicians receive room, board, and small stipends; the most talented advance to prestigious cathedral positions. Illegal Music Threadist songs—compositions expressing resistance ideology—circulate despite Church prohibition. These songs mock pattern-privilege, celebrate legendary rebels, and encode information about resistance activities. Possession of Threadist song texts constitutes heresy; public performance risks execution. Visual Arts Painting, sculpture, and textile arts flourish under patronage systems dominated by Church and nobility. Painting Religious subjects dominate official art: depictions of the Loom, saints, and theological concepts. Portrait painting serves noble vanity. Landscape painting captures idealized visions of Hálcovan geography. The most prestigious painters earn commissions of 500-5,000 marks for major works. Painting styles emphasize mathematical precision and symbolic meaning over emotional expression. Church doctrine holds that true art reveals Loom patterns underlying visible reality. Paintings that simply depict surface appearances are considered lesser works. Sculpture Stone and metal sculpture adorns public spaces, private gardens, and religious buildings. Monument sculpture commemorates historical figures and events. Decorative sculpture enhances architecture. The most ambitious projects require years of work and teams of craftsmen. Pattern-Weaving Unique to Hálcova, this art form creates moving images within woven fabric through techniques involving controlled Elsewhere interaction during the weaving process. Pattern-woven tapestries display scenes that shift and change when viewed from different angles or under different lighting. The finest examples seem almost alive. Pattern-weaving requires both artistic talent and specific sensitivity to Elsewhere energies. Practitioners undergo years of training and many never achieve mastery. Completed works command extraordinary prices—major pattern-weavings sell for 10,000-50,000 marks. Gambling Ecosystem Legal Gambling The Crown and Church jointly regulate legal gambling, extracting revenue while maintaining social control. Arena Betting Licensed betting houses accept wagers on Mintaharc and Tengerjáték matches. Minimum bets start at 1 mark; maximum bets theoretically unlimited but practically capped by house resources. The Crown takes 10% of house profits; the Church receives additional fees for "spiritual oversight." Fonálháló Tournaments Tournament betting operates through official channels with lower margins than arena betting. The intellectual nature of the game attracts pattern-privileged bettors who consider themselves above arena gambling. Dice Games Licensed gambling houses offer various dice games with bets ranging from 0.1 to 10 marks. These establishments pay substantial license fees and submit to regular inspection. Games are theoretically fair, though house advantages ensure long-term profitability. Pattern-Lotteries Church-run lotteries offer chances to win substantial prizes for small wagers (0.5-5 marks). The Church presents lotteries as demonstrations of Loom randomness—winners are "pattern-favored," losers should accept their designated fortune. Lottery revenue funds Church charitable activities. Illegal Gambling Where legal gambling is regulated and taxed, illegal gambling offers higher stakes, better odds, and forbidden thrills. Underground Fights Unlicensed combat takes place in warehouses, basements, and rural locations. Unlike arena combat, underground fights have no safety rules—deaths are common, and some events specifically promise lethal outcomes. Pattern-constrained individuals can bet and fight without the documentation required for legal venues. Rigged Games Criminal organizations operate gambling establishments offering games manipulated to ensure house victory. Victims who complain risk violence; those who win too consistently face accusations of cheating and similar violence. Pattern-Manipulation Betting The most dangerous illegal gambling involves bets on outcomes supposedly influenced by Loom manipulation. Fraudsters claim ability to alter fate itself; desperate bettors pay enormous sums for guaranteed victories that never materialize. Actual Loom interference is extraordinarily rare and unpredictable—most "pattern-manipulation" betting is pure fraud. Fairs and Carnivals Seasonal fairs provide entertainment accessible to all social classes, though experiences differ dramatically based on pattern status. Major Annual Events Évresá (Harvest Festival) Celebrated throughout the Heartlands at autumn harvest completion. Fairs feature agricultural competitions, craft displays, food vendors, and traveling entertainers. Pattern-privileged families attend in reserved sections; pattern-constrained workers receive festival days off to attend general areas. Fágvard (Winter Solstice Fair) Marking the year's longest night, Fágvard fairs run for three days. Bonfires, winter foods, and performances celebrating survival through darkness characterize the festival. The Church incorporates Fágvard into religious observance, adding services and processions to secular celebration. Thread Day Commemorating the Integration Century's conclusion, Thread Day celebrates establishment of current social order. Official ceremonies honor founders; popular celebration involves parades, public performances, and distribution of Church-blessed foods. Attendance at Thread Day ceremonies is mandatory for pattern-constrained individuals. Fair Entertainment Acrobats and Performers Traveling troupes perform feats of physical skill: tumbling, rope-walking, juggling, and staged combat. The best troupes circulate among major fairs throughout the year, earning enough during festival seasons to survive lean periods. Fortune-Tellers Pattern-readers offer predictions based on claimed ability to perceive Loom threads. Most fortune-tellers are frauds using cold reading and psychological manipulation. A few possess genuine sensitivity to pattern information, though their predictions remain probabilistic rather than certain. The Church tolerates fortune-telling as harmless entertainment while officially discouraging reliance on such predictions. Freak Shows Exhibitions of Elsewhere-touched individuals—people whose pattern connections produce visible physical or mental differences. Ethical debates surround these shows: critics argue they exploit vulnerable people, defenders claim they provide income for those otherwise unemployable. The Church officially disapproves but rarely intervenes. Puppet Shows Traditional puppet theater presents simplified versions of morality plays, historical dramas, and comedies. Puppet shows reach audiences unable to afford theater admission. The best puppeteers achieve celebrity status within fair circuits. Class Disparities in Entertainment Pattern-Privileged Entertainment The wealthy experience entertainment as another expression of status and refinement. Private boxes at arena matches offer comfort and privacy. Exclusive theater performances cater to sophisticated tastes. High-stakes Fonálháló provides intellectual competition among peers. Art patronage demonstrates cultural leadership. Costs for pattern-privileged entertainment run from 10-100+ marks per event—affordable for those with substantial income but excluding all but the wealthiest pattern-constrained individuals. Middle Class Entertainment Merchants, skilled craftsmen, and minor professionals access public versions of privileged entertainment. General arena seating (5-15 marks) provides the spectacle without the comfort. Public theater performances (1-5 marks) offer quality entertainment. Tavern gambling (0.1-5 marks) provides excitement within budget constraints. Pattern-Constrained Entertainment The poorest Hálcovans find entertainment where they can. Free arena days (standing room only) occur during major festivals. Street performers provide music and spectacle without admission charges. Illegal gambling offers thrills and the hope of transformation. Seasonal fairs provide annual highlights in otherwise constrained lives. The Church explicitly provides some entertainment for pattern-constrained populations—morality plays with free admission, festival celebrations, public hymn performances. This entertainment combines genuine recreation with ideological reinforcement. Regional Variations Heartlands The cultural center emphasizes sophisticated entertainment: major theater, orchestral music, Fonálháló competition, and arena combat as refined spectacle. Fonvárs sets trends that spread to provincial cities. Reaches Maritime culture shapes entertainment. Tengerjáték dominates spectator sports. Sea shanties and sailors' tales constitute primary music and storytelling traditions. Entertainment has practical edges—skills demonstrated in performance may prove useful aboard ship. Vent Lands Technical innovation influences entertainment. Flesh Shaping exhibitions showcase modification possibilities. Innovation competitions celebrate engineering achievements. Entertainment often serves educational purposes, demonstrating new techniques and technologies. Far Shelf Remote communities maintain traditional entertainment forms less influenced by Church and Crown. Community storytelling preserves oral history. Traditional dances mark seasonal transitions. Resistance songs circulate openly in areas beyond effective central control. Entertainment expresses regional identity and quiet defiance. Connections to Other Systems Entertainment intersects with every major Hálcovan institution. The Church uses performance arts for religious education and ideological reinforcement. The Crown employs spectacle to demonstrate power and provide social pressure release. The economy depends on entertainment spending and related employment. The legal system regulates gambling and prosecutes illegal entertainment. Criminal organizations profit from entertainment's underground economy. For worldbuilding purposes, entertainment provides accessible entry points to Hálcovan culture—characters attend performances, place bets, and discuss games in ways that reveal social structures and personal values.
