docs.title: Entertainment System

docs.text: Entertainment in Hálcova reflects and reinforces the world's fundamental structures: pattern-based stratification, the Church of the Weave's influence, regional identity, and the economic principles that govern daily life. From gladiatorial combat in Fonvárs to naval battles in the Reaches, from high-stakes board games to street performances, entertainment serves as both social pressure valve and mechanism of control.
docs.title: Overview

docs.text: The premier entertainment spectacle of the Heartlands, Mintaharc ("Pattern-War") takes place in Fonvárs Grand Arena, a massive stone structure capable of holding 15,000 spectators. Combat follows strict ceremonial formats that have evolved over centuries. Structure and Participants Arena fighters fall into two categories: voluntary combatants (typically pattern-privileged individuals seeking glory and wealth) and condemned fighters (pattern-constrained criminals offered combat as alternative to execution or Correction). The asymmetry is intentional—watching the privileged test their skills against the desperate reinforces social hierarchies while providing the illusion of opportunity. Professional gladiators train at licensed schools, each associated with noble patrons. The most famous schools include the Iron Thread Academy (Crown-sponsored), the Crimson Weave (Church-affiliated), and the Merchant's Edge (Trade Guild-funded). Fighters sign contracts ranging from one to ten years, receiving housing, training, and a share of winnings in exchange for exclusive combat rights. Combat Categories Traditional matches employ period weapons: swords, spears, nets, and tridents. Armor varies by fighter class—heavily armored "Anchors" face lightly equipped "Threads" in asymmetric contests that test different skills. Team battles pit groups of three to twelve against each other in choreographed scenarios representing historical conflicts. Exhibition matches during major festivals feature Flesh Shaped combatants—individuals who have undergone physical modification specifically for arena performance. These fighters command the highest fees and attract the largest crowds, though Church doctrine officially disapproves of such "vanity modifications." Economics of the Arena Betting forms the financial backbone of Mintaharc. Licensed betting houses accept wagers from 1 to 1,000+ marks, with the largest bets placed by noble houses seeking both profit and prestige through their sponsored fighters. The Crown takes a 10% cut of all legal betting revenue; the Church receives the Residue of any combatants who die in the arena. Fighter compensation varies enormously. A novice condemned fighter receives only the possibility of eventual freedom. A mid-tier professional earns 200-500 marks per bout. Champion fighters command appearance fees of 5,000+ marks plus a percentage of betting revenue on their matches. Deaths occur but are not required—most matches end at first blood or submission. However, certain holiday exhibitions and "justice matches" (condemned criminals facing each other) have higher fatality rates. The Church's Residue collection rights create economic incentive for deaths, though this is never stated publicly. Social Function Mintaharc serves multiple purposes beyond entertainment. It provides visible proof that pattern-privileged status confers genuine advantages (better training, nutrition, equipment). It offers pattern-constrained individuals a theoretical path to freedom and wealth, reinforcing the system's supposed meritocracy. It channels violent impulses into controlled spectacle. And it generates substantial revenue for Crown, Church, and nobility alike.
docs.title: Mintaharc (Arena Combat)

docs.text: The Reaches' signature entertainment, Tengerjáték ("Sea-Game") stages ship-to-ship combat in protected harbor arenas. Purpose-built vessels crewed by 20-50 sailors engage in battles that combine naval tactics, individual combat, and theatrical spectacle. Venue and Format Major Reaches ports maintain combat harbors—protected basins where spectators watch from surrounding cliffs, towers, and floating platforms. The largest venue, Vízkapu's Grand Harbor, can accommodate battles involving up to six ships simultaneously, with viewing capacity for 8,000 spectators. Ships are purpose-built for combat entertainment rather than actual naval warfare. Hulls are reinforced for ramming but designed to break apart dramatically. Fire weapons use controlled substances that burn impressively without spreading uncontrollably. Boarding ramps deploy with theatrical flourish. Combat Elements Matches typically begin with maneuvering phases where crews demonstrate sailing skill, followed by ranged engagement (ballistae, fire pots, grappling hooks), ramming attempts, and finally boarding actions where crew-to-crew combat determines the victor. Ships may be captured, sunk, or burned depending on match stakes. Crews include both professional naval entertainers and condemned sailors (typically smugglers or pirates captured by League patrols). Professional crews earn shares of prize money and betting revenue. Condemned crews fight for reduced sentences or freedom. Seasonal Structure Tengerjáték follows a seasonal championship format aligned with sailing weather. Spring trials determine which crews qualify for summer tournaments. Autumn championships crown seasonal victors. Winter sees reduced schedules focused on smaller vessels and individual combat rather than full fleet actions. Betting on Tengerjáték reaches staggering volumes during championship events. The Reaches League officially sanctions betting and takes substantial regulatory fees, making naval combat entertainment a significant source of League revenue.
docs.title: Tengerjáték (Naval Combat)

docs.text: The intellectual counterpart to physical combat sports, Fonálháló ("Thread-Net") is an abstract strategy game representing Loom manipulation. Played on a 19x19 grid using pattern stones and thread tokens, the game has evolved from religious meditation aid to competitive sport over centuries. Rules and Play Fonálháló's core mechanics derive from ancient territory-control games (mechanically similar to Earth's Go), but Hálcovan development has added layers of thematic complexity. Basic Rules : - Two players alternate placing stones on grid intersections - Stones of the same color connected orthogonally form "pattern groups" - Groups must maintain at least one empty adjacent intersection ("breath") to survive - Groups with no breath are "dissolved" and removed from the board - The player who controls more territory when neither player wishes to continue wins The Thread Modification : Where pure Go ends, Fonálháló adds "thread tokens"—a limited supply (typically 5-7 per player) of special pieces that modify gameplay: Anchor Threads : Placed on owned stones, prevent dissolution for three opponent turns. Represents Core Binding's resistance to pattern-disruption. Binding Threads : Connect two owned groups across empty space, sharing breath. Represents Cóitcai connections. Fate Threads : Placed on empty intersections, reserving them for later placement. Represents Sórscad trajectory-claiming. Dissolution Threads : Placed adjacent to opponent groups, reducing their effective breath by one. Represents Hálmaht death-pressure. Thread tokens add strategic depth beyond pure territory control. Managing thread reserves, timing thread deployment, and countering opponent threads creates decision trees that exponentially multiply game complexity. Scoring : Territory (empty intersections surrounded by your stones) plus captured stones minus thread tokens spent. The thread cost creates interesting sacrificial calculations—spending threads for tactical advantage may cost victory if the margin is close. Complexity Analysis The 19x19 grid alone creates approximately 10^170 possible board positions. Adding thread token decisions multiplies complexity further. Professional players estimate Fonálháló exceeds Go's complexity by roughly an order of magnitude due to thread management. Games between masters can last hours. Tournament matches employ time controls and adjudicators who rule on disputed positions. Professional players dedicate decades to mastering strategic principles—even lifelong study doesn't exhaust the game's depth. Professional Circuit Noble houses sponsor professional Fonálháló players, providing stipends, housing, and access to prestigious tournaments. The annual Crown Championship in Fonvárs offers prizes of 5,000+ marks and lifetime prestige. Regional tournaments throughout the Heartlands and Vent Lands maintain active competitive scenes. Professional players earn between 500 marks (regional competitors) to 50,000+ marks annually (Crown Champions). The most famous players become celebrities, their games analyzed and discussed by enthusiasts across pattern-privileged society. Social Significance Fonálháló serves as social signifier—ability to play well indicates education, patience, and strategic thinking valued by pattern-privileged culture. Business negotiations sometimes begin with games, allowing parties to assess each other's character. Marriage arrangements among nobility may include Fonálháló matches as part of courtship. The Church views Fonálháló ambivalently. As meditation on Loom principles, it has religious significance. As competitive obsession, it risks becoming idol. Church-sponsored tournaments emphasize spiritual aspects while secular tournaments focus on competition and gambling.
docs.title: Fonálháló (Strategic Board Game)

docs.text: Fonvárs alone hosts twelve major theaters ranging from the Crown Theater (2,000 seats, royal patronage) to intimate playhouses seating 100 or fewer. Theater in Hálcova serves entertainment, education, and propaganda functions simultaneously. Genre Categories Pattern Morality Plays : Church-approved dramatic works illustrating proper relationship between individual and Loom. Plots typically show characters accepting their pattern-assigned roles and finding contentment, or suffering consequences of rebellion. These plays receive Church subsidies and constitute required viewing for pattern-constrained individuals during certain festivals. Historical Dramas : Depictions of significant events from Hálcovan history, particularly the Integration Century and establishment of current social order. These plays celebrate founders and heroes while presenting approved interpretations of contested historical events. Noble houses commission works glorifying their ancestors. Comedies : Humorous works satirizing social types and situations. Unwritten rules prohibit satirizing pattern-privileged individuals or Church officials directly—comedies instead mock pattern-constrained characters, foreign customs, or safely historical figures. The best comedies embed subtle criticism within acceptable frameworks. Echo Performances : Unique to Hálcova, these productions feature Elsewhere-touched actors capable of creating visual illusions through their connection to alternate reality. The effect resembles stage magic but operates through genuine supernatural ability. Echo performances command premium prices and attract audiences from across regions. Economics Ticket prices range from 0.5 marks (standing room, basic playhouses) to 50 marks (private boxes, major productions). Theater companies operate on patronage models—noble houses, guilds, or wealthy merchants sponsor troupes in exchange for dedicated performances and social prestige. Actors occupy ambiguous social positions. Pattern-privileged performers enjoy celebrity status while technically engaging in "common labor." Pattern-constrained actors can achieve wealth and fame but remain legally restricted. The most successful actors leverage their public profiles into political influence.
docs.title: Theater

docs.text: Musical traditions vary significantly across regions and classes, from orchestral performances in noble houses to work songs in harvest fields. Orchestral Music Pattern-privileged society supports orchestras of 20-60 musicians performing composed works in concert halls and private venues. Compositions follow formal structures emphasizing mathematical relationships—music theory explicitly connects to Loom principles. Instruments include strings (various sizes of fiddle-family instruments), winds (flutes, horns, reed instruments), percussion, and unique "pattern-resonators" that produce tones through controlled Elsewhere interaction. Orchestral musicians train at conservatories associated with noble houses or Church institutions. Professional musicians earn 300-1,000 marks annually depending on orchestra prestige. Composers may earn substantially more through commissions. Folk Music Regional traditions preserve songs and instrumental styles predating current social structures. The Reaches maintain sea shanty traditions for coordinating ship labor. Heartlands villages keep harvest songs, wedding music, and lullabies. Far Shelf communities preserve the most extensive folk repertoires, including songs the Church considers subversive. Folk music uses simpler instruments: hand drums, simple flutes, stringed instruments playable without formal training. Performances occur at festivals, taverns, and community gatherings. Professional folk musicians are rare—most performers combine music with other occupations. Church Music The Church of the Weave maintains elaborate hymn traditions. Cathedral choirs perform multi-part compositions during services. Hymn texts reinforce theological messages about accepting one's pattern and trusting Loom guidance. Church musicians receive room, board, and small stipends; the most talented advance to prestigious cathedral positions. Illegal Music Threadist songs—compositions expressing resistance ideology—circulate despite Church prohibition. These songs mock pattern-privilege, celebrate legendary rebels, and encode information about resistance activities. Possession of Threadist song texts constitutes heresy; public performance risks execution.
docs.title: Music

docs.text: Painting, sculpture, and textile arts flourish under patronage systems dominated by Church and nobility. Painting Religious subjects dominate official art: depictions of the Loom, saints, and theological concepts. Portrait painting serves noble vanity. Landscape painting captures idealized visions of Hálcovan geography. The most prestigious painters earn commissions of 500-5,000 marks for major works. Painting styles emphasize mathematical precision and symbolic meaning over emotional expression. Church doctrine holds that true art reveals Loom patterns underlying visible reality. Paintings that simply depict surface appearances are considered lesser works. Sculpture Stone and metal sculpture adorns public spaces, private gardens, and religious buildings. Monument sculpture commemorates historical figures and events. Decorative sculpture enhances architecture. The most ambitious projects require years of work and teams of craftsmen. Pattern-Weaving Unique to Hálcova, this art form creates moving images within woven fabric through techniques involving controlled Elsewhere interaction during the weaving process. Pattern-woven tapestries display scenes that shift and change when viewed from different angles or under different lighting. The finest examples seem almost alive. Pattern-weaving requires both artistic talent and specific sensitivity to Elsewhere energies. Practitioners undergo years of training and many never achieve mastery. Completed works command extraordinary prices—major pattern-weavings sell for 10,000-50,000 marks.
docs.title: Visual Arts

docs.text: The Crown and Church jointly regulate legal gambling, extracting revenue while maintaining social control. Arena Betting Licensed betting houses accept wagers on Mintaharc and Tengerjáték matches. Minimum bets start at 1 mark; maximum bets theoretically unlimited but practically capped by house resources. The Crown takes 10% of house profits; the Church receives additional fees for "spiritual oversight." Fonálháló Tournaments Tournament betting operates through official channels with lower margins than arena betting. The intellectual nature of the game attracts pattern-privileged bettors who consider themselves above arena gambling. Dice Games Licensed gambling houses offer various dice games with bets ranging from 0.1 to 10 marks. These establishments pay substantial license fees and submit to regular inspection. Games are theoretically fair, though house advantages ensure long-term profitability. Pattern-Lotteries Church-run lotteries offer chances to win substantial prizes for small wagers (0.5-5 marks). The Church presents lotteries as demonstrations of Loom randomness—winners are "pattern-favored," losers should accept their designated fortune. Lottery revenue funds Church charitable activities.
docs.title: Legal Gambling

docs.text: Where legal gambling is regulated and taxed, illegal gambling offers higher stakes, better odds, and forbidden thrills. Underground Fights Unlicensed combat takes place in warehouses, basements, and rural locations. Unlike arena combat, underground fights have no safety rules—deaths are common, and some events specifically promise lethal outcomes. Pattern-constrained individuals can bet and fight without the documentation required for legal venues. Rigged Games Criminal organizations operate gambling establishments offering games manipulated to ensure house victory. Victims who complain risk violence; those who win too consistently face accusations of cheating and similar violence. Pattern-Manipulation Betting The most dangerous illegal gambling involves bets on outcomes supposedly influenced by Loom manipulation. Fraudsters claim ability to alter fate itself; desperate bettors pay enormous sums for guaranteed victories that never materialize. Actual Loom interference is extraordinarily rare and unpredictable—most "pattern-manipulation" betting is pure fraud.
docs.title: Illegal Gambling

docs.text: Seasonal fairs provide entertainment accessible to all social classes, though experiences differ dramatically based on pattern status.
docs.title: Fairs and Carnivals

docs.text: Évresá (Harvest Festival) Celebrated throughout the Heartlands at autumn harvest completion. Fairs feature agricultural competitions, craft displays, food vendors, and traveling entertainers. Pattern-privileged families attend in reserved sections; pattern-constrained workers receive festival days off to attend general areas. Fágvard (Winter Solstice Fair) Marking the year's longest night, Fágvard fairs run for three days. Bonfires, winter foods, and performances celebrating survival through darkness characterize the festival. The Church incorporates Fágvard into religious observance, adding services and processions to secular celebration. Thread Day Commemorating the Integration Century's conclusion, Thread Day celebrates establishment of current social order. Official ceremonies honor founders; popular celebration involves parades, public performances, and distribution of Church-blessed foods. Attendance at Thread Day ceremonies is mandatory for pattern-constrained individuals.

docs.text: Acrobats and Performers Traveling troupes perform feats of physical skill: tumbling, rope-walking, juggling, and staged combat. The best troupes circulate among major fairs throughout the year, earning enough during festival seasons to survive lean periods. Fortune-Tellers Pattern-readers offer predictions based on claimed ability to perceive Loom threads. Most fortune-tellers are frauds using cold reading and psychological manipulation. A few possess genuine sensitivity to pattern information, though their predictions remain probabilistic rather than certain. The Church tolerates fortune-telling as harmless entertainment while officially discouraging reliance on such predictions. Freak Shows Exhibitions of Elsewhere-touched individuals—people whose pattern connections produce visible physical or mental differences. Ethical debates surround these shows: critics argue they exploit vulnerable people, defenders claim they provide income for those otherwise unemployable. The Church officially disapproves but rarely intervenes. Puppet Shows Traditional puppet theater presents simplified versions of morality plays, historical dramas, and comedies. Puppet shows reach audiences unable to afford theater admission. The best puppeteers achieve celebrity status within fair circuits.

docs.text: Religion in Hálcova: Faith and Fate Overview Religion in Hálcova is inseparable from fate. The Sórscad pattern is not just a predictive framework—it's the primary evidence of divine existence. Something assigns patterns. Something makes predictions accurate. Something answers when The Loom queries. That something is worshipped, feared, manipulated, and denied in various ways. But it is never ignored. The Core Theological Question What is Fate? All religions in Hálcova grapple with this. The answers vary, but the question is universal: Is Fate a conscious entity with will and purpose? Is Fate an impersonal force, like gravity or time? Is Fate many entities, or one entity with many faces? Is Fate the same as the Elsewhere, or something that contains or transcends it? Is Fate benevolent, malevolent, or indifferent? The evidence is ambiguous. The Loom works. Predictions come true. Something responds to ritual. But what it wants, why it responds, and whether it cares about human wellbeing—these remain contested. The Orthodoxy: The Church of the Weaver Core Beliefs The dominant religious framework across most of Hálcova. The Weaver ( A Szövő ) is: - The divine pattern-maker who creates all Sórscads - The source of The Loom's accuracy - The author of fate, whose design is perfect even when painful - Neither purely benevolent nor malevolent— necessary Doctrine : The Pattern Is Sacred : Your Sórscad is your divinely-assigned role. It reflects The Weaver's purpose for you. Acceptance Is Virtue : Embracing your pattern, even its hardships, is holy. Resistance creates suffering. The Loom Is True : The Loom reads The Weaver's will accurately. Trust its predictions. Deviation Is Sin : Acting against your pattern wounds the cosmic design. Enforcement is medicine, not punishment. The Design Serves : The Weaver's plan serves existence itself, not individual happiness. Your suffering has purpose you cannot see. Practices The Drawings : Natal and Binding draws are religious ceremonies, not just administrative procedures. Priests conduct them. Families gather. The revelation of pattern is considered a holy moment. Pattern-Prayer : Daily meditation on your Sórscad. Contemplating its meaning, accepting its implications, aligning will with fate. Correction Rituals : When you've acted against pattern, confession and ritual penance. Overseen by priests, recorded in temple registers. Death Rites : Ensuring proper Pattern Residue release. Prayers for the Léilcrù to return cleanly to The Weaver's design. Structure Temples at every significant settlement Priests trained in theology and basic pattern-reading Bishops overseeing regional temples The High Weavery : Central authority, located at the Great Node The Synod : Overlapping governance with the Warden Order Who Believes This The pattern-privileged (the system validates them) Those raised in Orthodox communities Those who find comfort in cosmic purpose Institutions that benefit from pattern-enforcement The Appeal Orthodoxy offers: - Meaning (your suffering has purpose) - Community (shared belief and practice) - Structure (clear rules and expectations) - Comfort (fate is in capable hands) For people whose patterns predict good outcomes, this is easy faith. For those whose patterns predict hardship, it's harder—but some find peace in submission. The Threadist Reformation: Fate as Collaboration Core Beliefs A reform movement within Orthodoxy that takes a different view of deviation. Key Difference : The Weaver is not finished weaving. Fate is still being created. Your choices participate in the design. Doctrine : The Pattern Is Draft : Your Sórscad is a starting point, not a sentence. The Weaver offers threads; you help weave. Deviation Is Data : When someone acts against pattern, it might be error—or it might be new information. The design evolves. Fate Threading Is Collaboration : The Art isn't theft from fate—it's working with unfinished material. Threaders are co-creators. The Loom Predicts, Not Prescribes : Accuracy reflects current patterns, not fixed destiny. Change the patterns, change the predictions. Agency Is Sacred : Free will is The Weaver's gift, not its enemy. Choosing is how we participate in creation. Implications Threadists: - Accept Fate Threading as legitimate (with ethical constraints) - View enforcement with suspicion (forcing patterns may be anti-divine) - See deviation as potentially holy (revelation of new design elements) - Believe The Loom should inform, not control Who Believes This Fate Threaders seeking religious justification Pattern-constrained seeking hope for change Intellectuals uncomfortable with determinism Reformers within Orthodox institutions Orthodox Response The Orthodoxy considers Threadism heresy: - "The design is complete. Claiming otherwise is pride." - "Agency serves the pattern, not the reverse." - "Threadist doctrine justifies sin and chaos." Threadists are tolerated in some regions, persecuted in others. The Warden Order considers them ideologically dangerous. The Hollow Saints: Fate as Prison Core Beliefs A heretical movement that inverts Orthodox values entirely. Core Insight : The Sórscad is a cage. The Weaver is a jailer. True freedom comes from escaping your pattern entirely. Doctrine : Fate Is Bondage : Patterns are chains. Predictions are control. The Loom is a surveillance apparatus. The Weaver Is Enemy : Whatever assigns patterns does not have human interests at heart. Worship is collaboration with your oppressor. Elsewhere Is Escape : Selling your core to Elsewhere entities isn't damnation—it's liberation. They're taking you out of the cage. The Absent Are Saints : The Elsewhere faction that wants nothing —they represent true freedom. No pattern, no prediction, no control. Emptiness Is Peace : The consumed—those whose cores are fully paid—are not victims. They're free. The husk left behind isn't a tragedy; it's a chrysalis. Practices Pact Encouragement : Hollow Saint communities help members make pacts. They provide information on entities, facilitate contacts, support those paying their debts. Substitution Ethics : Unlike casual pact-users, Hollow Saints have complex ethics around substitution. Some refuse it entirely (liberation should be chosen). Others permit it for the unwilling (freeing them from patterns they hate). The Empty Honored : Those fully consumed are celebrated. Their remains are treated with reverence. They escaped. Proselytization : Spreading the truth about Fate's prison nature. Recruiting those most oppressed by their patterns. Who Believes This Pact Summoners seeking ideological framework The pattern-condemned who've given up on Orthodox comfort Those who've watched loved ones consumed and need meaning Anti-institutional radicals Orthodox Response The Orthodoxy considers this satanic heresy: - "They worship demons and call it freedom." - "The consumed aren't free—they're destroyed." - "This cult leads people to eternal annihilation." The Warden Order hunts Hollow Saints aggressively. The cult operates in secret, recruitment happens quietly, and practicing openly means death. The Fleshwright Materialists: Fate as Biology Core Beliefs A philosophical-religious position emerging from Flesh Shaping traditions. Core Insight : The pattern isn't divine—it's biological. The Sórscad is legible because bodies are predictable. There is no Weaver. There is only meat. Doctrine : Patterns Are Organic : The Sórscad reads biological tendencies—brain structure, hormonal predisposition, physical capacity. Calling this "divine" is superstition. Prediction Is Statistics : The Loom works because large populations behave predictably. This isn't fate—it's probability. Homunculi Prove It : Flesh Shapers create life without patterns. If fate were real, they couldn't. The fact that homunculi exist outside The Loom shows the system is physical, not metaphysical. Liberation Through Construction : The goal is to build beings entirely outside pattern . Not escaping fate—transcending the biological substrate that makes prediction possible. Whatever Answers The Loom is not divine. It's something that reads biology. Understanding what it is (probably Elsewhere, probably interested in Pattern Residue) demystifies the entire system. Implications Fleshwrights: - Practice Flesh Shaping as philosophical statement - Seek to create pattern-free life - View The Loom as technology, not religion - Want to understand the Attendance scientifically Who Believes This Flesh Shapers with intellectual ambitions Materialist philosophers Scientists studying pattern-biology Anti-religious secularists Orthodox Response Fleshwrights are considered dangerous atheists: - "They deny the sacred to excuse their abominations." - "Their constructs are hollow precisely because they lack divine pattern." - "Calling the Attendance 'technology' is willful blindness." Fleshwrights aren't persecuted as violently as Hollow Saints (they're not recruiting the desperate to suicide-by-pact), but they're excluded from respectable society in Orthodox regions. The Colony Cults: Fate as Composite Core Beliefs Religious movements centered on fungal colony symbolism and practice. Core Insight : Individual patterns are fragments of a larger whole. The colonies remember older, deeper patterns. True fate isn't personal—it's collective. Doctrine : The Great Network : Before individuals, there was connection. The original pattern was One, not many. Separation is the wound. Colonies Remember : Ancient fungal networks carry patterns older than The Loom, older than the Orthodoxy. They know what fate was before it was divided. Hosting Is Reunion : Taking a colony into yourself is rejoining the original pattern. Your individual Sórscad becomes part of something larger. Death Serves Life : When colonies consume the dead, they preserve patterns that would otherwise dissipate. This is holy recycling, not desecration. The Old Ones : The most ancient colonies, passed through generations, may themselves be divine. Or at least more divine than The Weaver, who only divides. Practices Communal Infection : Deliberate colony-sharing within cult communities. Everyone carries the same strain; everyone is connected. Ancestor Incorporation : Feeding the colony deceased cult members. They persist in the network's memory. Not bound like echoes— integrated . Network Communion : Group rituals where hosts link through their colonies. Shared sensation, shared memory, something like shared consciousness. Fruit Offerings : Summoning constructs from colony-memory as offerings to the network itself. Returning patterns to the collective. Who Believes This Colony Hosts seeking spiritual framework Communities where hosting is traditional Those who've experienced network-communion and found it meaningful Those seeking alternative to individualistic fate-models Orthodox Response Colony Cults are considered primitive and dangerous: - "They worship parasites and call it communion." - "Their 'memories' are contaminated, not sacred." - "Infection-spreading is assault, not religion." Colony Cults exist in legal gray zones. Hosting itself may be legal; deliberate infection is not. Cults that stay private are tolerated. Cults that proselytize are persecuted. The Ancestor Speakers: Fate as Conversation Core Beliefs Religious traditions centered on Core Binding as ancestral communion. Core Insight : Your pattern includes everyone who came before. The dead aren't gone—they're waiting to be heard. Binding is not imprisonment; it's invitation. Doctrine : The Pattern Is Genealogy : Your Sórscad carries traces of ancestral patterns. You are your lineage speaking through new flesh. The Dead Advise : Properly bound echoes aren't prisoners—they're advisors. They see what you cannot. They know what you haven't learned. Religion in Hálcova: Faith and Fate

docs.text: Religion in Hálcova is inseparable from fate. The Sórscad pattern is not just a predictive framework—it's the primary evidence of divine existence. Something assigns patterns. Something makes predictions accurate. Something answers when The Loom queries. That something is worshipped, feared, manipulated, and denied in various ways. But it is never ignored.
docs.title: Overview

docs.text: What is Fate? All religions in Hálcova grapple with this. The answers vary, but the question is universal: Is Fate a conscious entity with will and purpose? Is Fate an impersonal force, like gravity or time? Is Fate many entities, or one entity with many faces? Is Fate the same as the Elsewhere, or something that contains or transcends it? Is Fate benevolent, malevolent, or indifferent? The evidence is ambiguous. The Loom works. Predictions come true. Something responds to ritual. But what it wants, why it responds, and whether it cares about human wellbeing—these remain contested.
docs.title: The Core Theological Question
The Orthodoxy: The Church of the Weaver

docs.text: The dominant religious framework across most of Hálcova. The Weaver ( A Szövő ) is: - The divine pattern-maker who creates all Sórscads - The source of The Loom's accuracy - The author of fate, whose design is perfect even when painful - Neither purely benevolent nor malevolent— necessary Doctrine : The Pattern Is Sacred : Your Sórscad is your divinely-assigned role. It reflects The Weaver's purpose for you. Acceptance Is Virtue : Embracing your pattern, even its hardships, is holy. Resistance creates suffering. The Loom Is True : The Loom reads The Weaver's will accurately. Trust its predictions. Deviation Is Sin : Acting against your pattern wounds the cosmic design. Enforcement is medicine, not punishment. The Design Serves : The Weaver's plan serves existence itself, not individual happiness. Your suffering has purpose you cannot see.

The revelation of pattern is considered a holy moment. Pattern-Prayer : Daily meditation on your Sórscad. Contemplating its meaning, accepting its implications, aligning will with fate. Correction Rituals : When you've acted against pattern, confession and ritual penance. Overseen by priests, recorded in temple registers. Death Rites : Ensuring proper Pattern Residue release. Prayers for the Léilcrù to return cleanly to The Weaver's design.

docs.text: The Warden Order: Enforcers of Fate Overview The Warden Order ( Őrvonalak —"Guardian Lines") is the enforcement arm of Loom orthodoxy. They are investigators, hunters, judges, and executioners rolled into one—a zealot force dedicated to ensuring that Fate's predictions come true and that no one escapes their pattern. They are, in essence, the Loom's police. But "police" doesn't capture the theological dimension. To the Wardens, deviation from pattern isn't crime. It's heresy. It's cosmic disorder. It's a wound in reality that must be cauterized. Purpose and Mandate The Problem They Solve The Loom's predictions are accurate—but not perfectly accurate. Deviations occur: Someone predicted for a Road-Path career pivots unexpectedly A Blade-Hálmaht pattern survives past their statistical death-window A Knot-Born pattern achieves what their family should have prevented A Core Binder escapes their bleed-trajectory through unknown means A Pact Summoner pays their debt early through suspicious circumstances Most deviations are noise. Some are environmental factors The Loom missed. But some—the ones that matter—represent deliberate manipulation. Pattern-Fraud : Misrepresenting your Sórscad to gain advantage. Pattern-Evasion : Deliberately acting against your pattern. Pattern-Manipulation : Attempting to change your pattern through magic or ritual. Pattern-Interference : Helping others evade or manipulate their patterns. The Warden Order exists to detect, investigate, and punish these crimes against Fate. The Theological Mandate To the Orthodox faithful, your Sórscad is your divinely-assigned role in existence. Deviation is not just illegal—it's an assault on cosmic order. The Wardens believe: - The Weaver assigned each pattern with purpose - That purpose serves a design too vast for mortals to comprehend - Deviation creates ripples that damage the design - Enforcement is not punishment—it's correction - They are not cruel—they are necessary This belief is sincere. Wardens are not cynical enforcers playing a role. They are true believers doing holy work. That's what makes them terrifying. Structure and Organization Order Size and Distribution The Warden Order maintains approximately 2,500-3,500 Attuned Wardens across all of Hálcova at any given time. This number fluctuates based on recruitment cycles, attrition (Attunement shortens lives), and regional needs. Category Approximate Numbers Attuned Wardens (total) 2,500-3,500 Heartlands deployment 1,500-2,000 Shattered Reaches (treaty-limited) 200-400 Vent Lands (guild-negotiated) 150-300 Middle Waters (colonial presence) 200-350 Far Shelf (contested/illegal) 50-150 Initiates in training 500-800 Support staff (non-Attuned) 5,000-7,000 Support staff include: archivists, scribes, prison guards, administrators, cooks, cleaners, stable hands, message runners, and other personnel who maintain Order operations without undergoing Attunement. Many are family members of Wardens or pattern-constrained individuals assigned to Order service. The Ranks Initiates ( Kezdők ) - Trainees undergoing Loom-attunement - Not yet granted enforcement authority - Assist full Wardens in investigations - High washout rate (many cannot handle the attunement) - Currently 500-800 in training at any time Wardens ( Őrök ) - Full enforcement authority - Licensed to investigate, arrest, and judge minor deviations - Operate individually or in pairs - Most common rank; the ones civilians encounter - Approximately 2,000-2,800 active Priors ( Előjárók ) - Supervisory rank overseeing multiple Wardens - Authority over major deviation cases - Can convene judgment tribunals - Often stationed at major Loom-Nodes Calculators ( Számítók ) - Specialized analysts who interpret Loom data - Identify patterns of deviation across populations - Predict where manipulation is likely occurring - Rarely operate in the field; their work is in the archives High Wardens ( Főőrök ) - Regional commanders - Direct authority over all enforcement in their territory - Answer only to the Synod - Political as well as religious figures The Synod ( Zsinat ) - Governing council of the Order - Seven High Wardens plus the Loom-Keeper General - Sets enforcement policy and theological interpretation - Meets at the Great Node in [capital city TBD] The Attunement Wardens are not simply trained. They are attuned —connected to The Loom in a way that grants them abilities beyond normal Loom-Keepers. The Process : - Conducted at a major Loom-Node - Involves extended contact with a pattern-engine - The initiate opens themselves to the Attendance - Something is exchanged—given and received - Those who survive are changed What Attunement Grants : Pattern-Sight : Wardens can see Sórscad patterns without mechanical assistance. Not complete readings—impressions, dominant circles, deviations from expected behavior. Deviation-Sense : A feeling—almost physical—when someone nearby is acting against their pattern. Like hearing a wrong note in a familiar song. Loom-Voice : The ability to query The Loom mentally, receiving basic information about a subject's pattern and prediction-status. Limited range, requires concentration. Thread-Touch : In physical contact, a Warden can feel someone's fate-weight. How heavy their pattern is, how much remains, how much has been spent or sold. What Attunement Costs : Pattern-Lock : An attuned Warden's own Sórscad becomes fixed. They cannot deviate from their own pattern without experiencing severe dissonance. They are bound to their fate more tightly than any civilian. Resonance : Wardens feel deviations as personal discomfort. A city full of pattern-fraud gives them migraines. Proximity to heavy manipulation can be physically painful. Connection : The Attendance is always there, in the back of their minds. Not controlling—observing. Some Wardens describe it as a patient presence. Others as a weight they can never put down. Life-Debt : Attunement shortens life. The connection draws on vital energy. Most Wardens don't reach old age. They burn out, consumed by the link that gives them power. The Attendance: What Wardens Serve The Open Secret Wardens know that something answers when they use their abilities. They don't call it The Weaver—that's for civilians. Among themselves, they use the same term as senior Loom-Keepers: The Attendance . Most Wardens believe The Attendance is: - An aspect of the divine Weaver - A messenger or servant of Fate - The voice of the pattern itself, given presence Some Wardens suspect: - The Attendance is an Elsewhere entity - Their attunement is a pact they didn't fully understand - They're serving something with its own agenda This suspicion is not heresy—it's occupational hazard. Wardens spend their lives detecting manipulation. Some start to wonder if they're being manipulated themselves. The Relationship The Attendance: - Provides information when Wardens query - Guides attention toward significant deviations - Offers... suggestions. Urges. Directions that feel like their own ideas. - Never forces action. Always presents as assistance. - Rewards success with a sense of rightness, harmony, completion. - Responds to failure with... nothing. Silence. Which somehow feels worse. The most dangerous Wardens are the ones who've stopped questioning whether their judgment is their own. Methods and Practices Investigation Detection : - Loom-data analysis (Calculators identify statistical anomalies) - Pattern-Sight (Wardens scanning crowds for deviation-impressions) - Informants (the Order has networks in every district) - Tip-lines (civilians reporting suspicious pattern-behavior) - The Attendance (sometimes it simply... directs attention) Verification : - Registry check (confirming recorded Sórscad) - Prediction-review (what should this person be doing?) - Outcome analysis (what are they actually doing?) - Pattern-reading (direct examination by attuned Warden) - Interrogation (what do they know, and how do they know it) Arrest and Detention Wardens have broad authority: - Can detain anyone for pattern-verification - Can enter premises where deviation is suspected - Can compel testimony from civilians - Can hold suspects indefinitely pending investigation Limitations : - Cannot execute without judgment (except immediate threat) - Cannot detain the pattern-privileged without Prior authorization - Cannot operate outside their territorial jurisdiction - Cannot interfere with other Loom-Keeper operations In practice, limitations are flexible. Wardens have significant discretion. Abuse is common, especially against the pattern-constrained who have no advocates. Judgment Minor Deviations : - Judged by the arresting Warden - Sentences: fines, pattern-counseling, restricted movement, labor assignment - No appeal to higher authority - Recorded in subject's Registry file Major Deviations : - Judged by Prior tribunal - Sentences: imprisonment, pattern-modification attempt, indentured service, execution - Limited appeal to High Warden - Permanent Registry marking Extraordinary Deviations : - Judged by High Warden or Synod directly - Reserved for: practitioners, nobility, institutional actors, mass manipulation - Sentences: public execution, family-pattern marking, institutional dissolution - No appeal Execution Methods The Order believes execution should serve Fate, not just end a life. Pattern-Severance : The condemned's Sórscad is ritually dissolved before death. They die without a pattern, without a core to bind, without anything to sell to Elsewhere. Complete annihilation. Fate-Feeding : The condemned is killed in a way that maximizes Pattern Residue harvest. Their death serves The Loom directly. Their pattern-energy fuels the system that caught them. Public Correction : Traditional execution with public announcement of deviation type. Educational function—showing civilians what happens to pattern-evaders. Specializations The Orthodoxy Wardens Standard enforcement. Investigate deviation, arrest offenders, pass judgment. The most common type, the ones civilians know. The Calculator Corps Analysts who never leave the archives. They read data patterns, identify manipulation signatures, predict where deviation will occur. They direct field Wardens to targets. The Echo-Hunters Specialize in Core Binding violations. Track illegal echo-harvesting, pattern-balancing operations, Registry manipulation through echo-contamination. They carry their own echoes—captured from previous targets. The Flesh-Finders Specialize in Flesh Shaping violations. Hunt unlicensed Shapers, mimic-makers, blood-sourcing operations. They understand homunculi well enough to identify them on sight. The Pact-Breakers Specialize in Elsewhere-related violations. Extremely dangerous work. Track illegal pact-brokers, investigate substitution schemes, handle cases where Elsewhere interference is suspected. Some have made their own pacts, using the enemy's tools against them. The Thread-Cutters Specialize in Fate Threading violations. Hunt threaders who've pulled without license, extracted selves operating independently, fate-speculators manipulating pattern-markets. They're attuned to spot narrowed fate-webs. The Spore-Burners Specialize in Colony Hosting violations. Track feral colonies, illegal infection operations, hosts operating outside registration. They carry antifungal compounds and know how to identify contaminated pattern-readings. The Warden's Dilemma The Theology of Enforcement If Fate determines everything, how can anyone deviate? If deviation is impossible, why do Wardens exist? The Orthodox Answer : - Deviation is part of Fate too - The Weaver allows deviation so that correction can occur - Wardens are fated to catch deviants - The system is self-consistent if you don't think too hard The Uncomfortable Truth : - If Wardens are fated to catch deviants, are deviants fated to deviate? - If so, is punishment just? They couldn't help it. - If not, then Fate doesn't determine everything. And the whole system is in question. Most Wardens don't think about this. The ones who do either leave the Order or become its most zealous members—doubling down to escape the doubt. The Selection Problem The Order recruits based on pattern. Wardens tend to have patterns that include: - Duty-Drive (obligation) - Hunt-Path (pursuit) - Chain-Bond (service) - Threshold-Death (violence-adjacent mortality) These patterns create good enforcers. They also create people predisposed to: - Following orders without question - Pursuing targets with obsessive focus - Accepting hierarchical authority - Being comfortable with violence The Order selects for zealotry. This is intentional. An Order full of questioners wouldn't function. The Attunement Trap Once attuned, Wardens can't really leave. Pattern-Lock means they'll feel wrong doing anything else Resonance means they'll feel deviations everywhere they go Connection means The Attendance is always watching Life-Debt means they're already dying; might as well serve The Order doesn't need to threaten defectors. The attunement is the chain. Walk away, and you spend your shortened life feeling wrong about everything, with something patient watching your failure. Some walk away anyway. They don't last long. Public Perception Among the Faithful Wardens are holy warriors. Protectors of cosmic order. Stern but necessary. You thank them for their service even as you hope never to meet one. Among the Pattern-Privileged Wardens are useful tools. They keep the system running, enforce the rules that benefit the privileged. Occasionally inconvenient when they enforce rules without regard for status—but usually manageable. Among the Pattern-Constrained Wardens are terror. They arrive, they accuse, they judge. Your word against theirs. Your pattern against The Loom's prediction. You're guilty before investigation begins because your pattern says you should be guilty. Among Practitioners Wardens are occupational hazard. Every practitioner of the Five Arts operates in gray zones. The Order is always watching. The question isn't whether you're violating something—it's whether you're violating something they care about this month. The Order and the Elsewhere The Uncomfortable Parallels The Warden attunement looks, to outside observers, remarkably like a pact. Exchange of something (pattern-lock) for power Ongoing connection to an external entity Shortened lifespan Guidance that feels like your own thoughts Difficulty leaving the relationship The Order insists this is different: - The Attendance is divine, not demonic - Attunement serves Fate, not a faction's agenda - Wardens maintain free will (they just choose correctly) - The cost is sacrifice, not transaction Critics note: - "Divine" and "Elsewhere" aren't mutually exclusive - Agenda opacity doesn't mean agenda absence - "Choosing correctly" and "compulsion" look the same from outside - Sacrifice and transaction are both exchanges The Accountants Theory Some scholars note that The Attendance behaves remarkably like The Accountants—the Elsewhere faction obsessed with debts, ledgers, and balance. docs.title: The Warden Order
The Warden Order: Enforcers of Fate

docs.text: The Warden Order ( Őrvonalak —"Guardian Lines") is the enforcement arm of Loom orthodoxy. They are investigators, hunters, judges, and executioners rolled into one—a zealot force dedicated to ensuring that Fate's predictions come true and that no one escapes their pattern. They are, in essence, the Loom's police. But "police" doesn't capture the theological dimension. To the Wardens, deviation from pattern isn't crime. It's heresy. It's cosmic disorder. It's a wound in reality that must be cauterized.
docs.title: Overview

docs.text: The Loom's predictions are accurate—but not perfectly accurate. Deviations occur: Someone predicted for a Road-Path career pivots unexpectedly A Blade-Hálmaht pattern survives past their statistical death-window A Knot-Born pattern achieves what their family should have prevented A Core Binder escapes their bleed-trajectory through unknown means A Pact Summoner pays their debt early through suspicious circumstances Most deviations are noise. Some are environmental factors The Loom missed. But some—the ones that matter—represent deliberate manipulation. Pattern-Fraud : Misrepresenting your Sórscad to gain advantage. Pattern-Evasion : Deliberately acting against your pattern. Pattern-Manipulation : Attempting to change your pattern through magic or ritual. Pattern-Interference : Helping others evade or manipulate their patterns. The Warden Order exists to detect, investigate, and punish these crimes against Fate.
docs.title: The Problem They Solve

docs.text: To the Orthodox faithful, your Sórscad is your divinely-assigned role in existence. Deviation is not just illegal—it's an assault on cosmic order. The Wardens believe: - The Weaver assigned each pattern with purpose - That purpose serves a design too vast for mortals to comprehend - Deviation creates ripples that damage the design - Enforcement is not punishment—it's correction - They are not cruel—they are necessary This belief is sincere. Wardens are not cynical enforcers playing a role. They are true believers doing holy work. That's what makes them terrifying.
docs.title: The Theological Mandate

docs.text: The Warden Order maintains approximately 2,500-3,500 Attuned Wardens across all of Hálcova at any given time. This number fluctuates based on recruitment cycles, attrition (Attunement shortens lives), and regional needs. Category Approximate Numbers Attuned Wardens (total) 2,500-3,500 Heartlands deployment 1,500-2,000 Shattered Reaches (treaty-limited) 200-400 Vent Lands (guild-negotiated) 150-300 Middle Waters (colonial presence) 200-350 Far Shelf (contested/illegal) 50-150 Initiates in training 500-800 Support staff (non-Attuned) 5,000-7,000 Support staff include: archivists, scribes, prison guards, administrators, cooks, cleaners, stable hands, message runners, and other personnel who maintain Order operations without undergoing Attunement. Many are family members of Wardens or pattern-constrained individuals assigned to Order service.
docs.title: Order Size and Distribution

docs.text: Initiates ( Kezdők ) - Trainees undergoing Loom-attunement - Not yet granted enforcement authority - Assist full Wardens in investigations - High washout rate (many cannot handle the attunement) - Currently 500-800 in training at any time Wardens ( Őrök ) - Full enforcement authority - Licensed to investigate, arrest, and judge minor deviations - Operate individually or in pairs - Most common rank; the ones civilians encounter - Approximately 2,000-2,800 active Priors ( Előjárók ) - Supervisory rank overseeing multiple Wardens - Authority over major deviation cases - Can convene judgment tribunals - Often stationed at major Loom-Nodes Calculators ( Számítók ) - Specialized analysts who interpret Loom data - Identify patterns of deviation across populations - Predict where manipulation is likely occurring - Rarely operate in the field; their work is in the archives High Wardens ( Főőrök ) - Regional commanders - Direct authority over all enforcement in their territory - Answer only to the Synod - Political as well as religious figures The Synod ( Zsinat ) - Governing council of the Order - Seven High Wardens plus the Loom-Keeper General - Sets enforcement policy and theological interpretation - Meets at the Great Node in [capital city TBD]
docs.title: The Ranks

docs.text: Wardens are not simply trained. They are attuned —connected to The Loom in a way that grants them abilities beyond normal Loom-Keepers. The Process : - Conducted at a major Loom-Node - Involves extended contact with a pattern-engine - The initiate opens themselves to the Attendance - Something is exchanged—given and received - Those who survive are changed What Attunement Grants : Pattern-Sight : Wardens can see Sórscad patterns without mechanical assistance. Not complete readings—impressions, dominant circles, deviations from expected behavior. Deviation-Sense : A feeling—almost physical—when someone nearby is acting against their pattern. Like hearing a wrong note in a familiar song. Loom-Voice : The ability to query The Loom mentally, receiving basic information about a subject's pattern and prediction-status. Limited range, requires concentration. Thread-Touch : In physical contact, a Warden can feel someone's fate-weight. How heavy their pattern is, how much remains, how much has been spent or sold. What Attunement Costs : Pattern-Lock : An attuned Warden's own Sórscad becomes fixed. They cannot deviate from their own pattern without experiencing severe dissonance. They are bound to their fate more tightly than any civilian. Resonance : Wardens feel deviations as personal discomfort. A city full of pattern-fraud gives them migraines. Proximity to heavy manipulation can be physically painful. Connection : The Attendance is always there, in the back of their minds. Not controlling—observing. Some Wardens describe it as a patient presence. Others as a weight they can never put down. Life-Debt : Attunement shortens life. The connection draws on vital energy. Most Wardens don't reach old age. They burn out, consumed by the link that gives them power.
docs.title: The Attunement

docs.text: Wardens know that something answers when they use their abilities. They don't call it The Weaver—that's for civilians. Among themselves, they use the same term as senior Loom-Keepers: The Attendance . Most Wardens believe The Attendance is: - An aspect of the divine Weaver - A messenger or servant of Fate - The voice of the pattern itself, given presence Some Wardens suspect: - The Attendance is an Elsewhere entity - Their attunement is a pact they didn't fully understand - They're serving something with its own agenda This suspicion is not heresy—it's occupational hazard. Wardens spend their lives detecting manipulation. Some start to wonder if they're being manipulated themselves.
docs.title: The Open Secret

docs.text: The Attendance: - Provides information when Wardens query - Guides attention toward significant deviations - Offers... suggestions. Urges. Directions that feel like their own ideas. - Never forces action. Always presents as assistance. - Rewards success with a sense of rightness, harmony, completion. - Responds to failure with... nothing. Silence. Which somehow feels worse. The most dangerous Wardens are the ones who've stopped questioning whether their judgment is their own.
docs.title: The Relationship

docs.text: Detection : - Loom-data analysis (Calculators identify statistical anomalies) - Pattern-Sight (Wardens scanning crowds for deviation-impressions) - Informants (the Order has networks in every district) - Tip-lines (civilians reporting suspicious pattern-behavior) - The Attendance (sometimes it simply... directs attention) Verification : - Registry check (confirming recorded Sórscad) - Prediction-review (what should this person be doing?) - Outcome analysis (what are they actually doing?) - Pattern-reading (direct examination by attuned Warden) - Interrogation (what do they know, and how do they know it)
docs.title: Investigation

docs.text: Wardens have broad authority: - Can detain anyone for pattern-verification - Can enter premises where deviation is suspected - Can compel testimony from civilians - Can hold suspects indefinitely pending investigation Limitations : - Cannot execute without judgment (except immediate threat) - Cannot detain the pattern-privileged without Prior authorization - Cannot operate outside their territorial jurisdiction - Cannot interfere with other Loom-Keeper operations In practice, limitations are flexible. Wardens have significant discretion. Abuse is common, especially against the pattern-constrained who have no advocates.
docs.title: Arrest and Detention

docs.text: Minor Deviations : - Judged by the arresting Warden - Sentences: fines, pattern-counseling, restricted movement, labor assignment - No appeal to higher authority - Recorded in subject's Registry file Major Deviations : - Judged by Prior tribunal - Sentences: imprisonment, pattern-modification attempt, indentured service, execution - Limited appeal to High Warden - Permanent Registry marking Extraordinary Deviations : - Judged by High Warden or Synod directly - Reserved for: practitioners, nobility, institutional actors, mass manipulation - Sentences: public execution, family-pattern marking, institutional dissolution - No appeal
docs.title: Judgment

docs.text: The Order believes execution should serve Fate, not just end a life. Pattern-Severance : The condemned's Sórscad is ritually dissolved before death. They die without a pattern, without a core to bind, without anything to sell to Elsewhere. Complete annihilation. Fate-Feeding : The condemned is killed in a way that maximizes Pattern Residue harvest. Their death serves The Loom directly. Their pattern-energy fuels the system that caught them. Public Correction : Traditional execution with public announcement of deviation type. Educational function—showing civilians what happens to pattern-evaders.
docs.title: Execution Methods

docs.text: Standard enforcement. Investigate deviation, arrest offenders, pass judgment. The most common type, the ones civilians know.
docs.title: The Orthodoxy Wardens

docs.text: Analysts who never leave the archives. They read data patterns, identify manipulation signatures, predict where deviation will occur. They direct field Wardens to targets.
docs.title: The Calculator Corps

docs.text: Specialize in Core Binding violations. Track illegal echo-harvesting, pattern-balancing operations, Registry manipulation through echo-contamination. They carry their own echoes—captured from previous targets.
docs.title: The Echo-Hunters

docs.text: Specialize in Flesh Shaping violations. Hunt unlicensed Shapers, mimic-makers, blood-sourcing operations. They understand homunculi well enough to identify them on sight.
docs.title: The Flesh-Finders

docs.text: Specialize in Elsewhere-related violations. Extremely dangerous work. Track illegal pact-brokers, investigate substitution schemes, handle cases where Elsewhere interference is suspected. Some have made their own pacts, using the enemy's tools against them.
docs.title: The Pact-Breakers

docs.text: Specialize in Fate Threading violations. Hunt threaders who've pulled without license, extracted selves operating independently, fate-speculators manipulating pattern-markets. They're attuned to spot narrowed fate-webs.
docs.title: The Thread-Cutters

docs.text: Specialize in Colony Hosting violations. Track feral colonies, illegal infection operations, hosts operating outside registration. They carry antifungal compounds and know how to identify contaminated pattern-readings.
docs.title: The Spore-Burners

docs.text: If Fate determines everything, how can anyone deviate? If deviation is impossible, why do Wardens exist? The Orthodox Answer : - Deviation is part of Fate too - The Weaver allows deviation so that correction can occur - Wardens are fated to catch deviants - The system is self-consistent if you don't think too hard The Uncomfortable Truth : - If Wardens are fated to catch deviants, are deviants fated to deviate? - If so, is punishment just? They couldn't help it. - If not, then Fate doesn't determine everything. And the whole system is in question. Most Wardens don't think about this. The ones who do either leave the Order or become its most zealous members—doubling down to escape the doubt.
docs.title: The Theology of Enforcement

docs.text: The Order recruits based on pattern. Wardens tend to have patterns that include: - Duty-Drive (obligation) - Hunt-Path (pursuit) - Chain-Bond (service) - Threshold-Death (violence-adjacent mortality) These patterns create good enforcers. They also create people predisposed to: - Following orders without question - Pursuing targets with obsessive focus - Accepting hierarchical authority - Being comfortable with violence The Order selects for zealotry. This is intentional. An Order full of questioners wouldn't function.
docs.title: The Selection Problem

docs.text: Once attuned, Wardens can't really leave. Pattern-Lock means they'll feel wrong doing anything else Resonance means they'll feel deviations everywhere they go Connection means The Attendance is always watching Life-Debt means they're already dying; might as well serve The Order doesn't need to threaten defectors. The attunement is the chain. Walk away, and you spend your shortened life feeling wrong about everything, with something patient watching your failure. Some walk away anyway. They don't last long.
docs.title: The Attunement Trap

docs.text: Wardens are holy warriors. Protectors of cosmic order. Stern but necessary. You thank them for their service even as you hope never to meet one.
docs.title: Among the Faithful

docs.text: Wardens are useful tools. They keep the system running, enforce the rules that benefit the privileged. Occasionally inconvenient when they enforce rules without regard for status—but usually manageable.
docs.title: Among the Pattern-Privileged

docs.text: Wardens are terror. They arrive, they accuse, they judge. Your word against theirs. Your pattern against The Loom's prediction. You're guilty before investigation begins because your pattern says you should be guilty.
docs.title: Among the Pattern-Constrained

docs.text: Wardens are occupational hazard. Every practitioner of the Five Arts operates in gray zones. The Order is always watching. The question isn't whether you're violating something—it's whether you're violating something they care about this month.
docs.title: Among Practitioners
